Patient Profile:   - Name: John Doe - Age: 57 years - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian   Chief Complaint:  Mr. Doe presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain that started about one hour ago  radiating to his left shoulder and down his left arm. Patient states he was sitting watching television when pain started. He also complains of shortness of breath and nausea. He rates his chest pain as 10/10.  History of Present Illness:  Pain is unrelieved by rest. No aggravating or alleviating factors identified. The patient describes the pain as ""like an elephant sitting on my chest"" and appears pale and diaphoretic.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of high blood pressure managed with lisinopril  type 2 diabetes mellitus being managed with metformin  and hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin. He refers to himself as a 'reformed smoker' having quit 5 years ago after a 30-year pack-a-day habit. Mr. Doe has had increased stress at work over the past several months. No previous history of cardiac disease.  Family History:  His father died of a heart attack at the age of 63 and his mother who is 80 has a history of angina and hypertension.  Review of Systems:  Positive for chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea. Negative for fever  cough  abdominal pain  palpitations  dizziness or fainting spells.  Social History:  He lives alone  and he is employed as a manager in a high-stress job. He quit smoking 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially but has stated that lately  he might have 2-3 beers in the evening to help him de-stress. He has a sedentary lifestyle.  Physical Exam:  - BP: 165/95 mmHg - Pulse: 110 bpm - Respirations: 22/min - Temperature: 37 degrees Celsius (normal) - O2 Saturation: 92% on room air  On examination  the patient appears anxious  diaphoretic and in pain. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals tachycardia but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdomen is soft and non-tender. Extremities show no edema.  This presentation is suspicious for acute myocardial infarction  also known as a heart attack. Immediate assessment and treatment are indicated.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the ER with complains of severe crushing chest pain that commenced approximately 30 minutes prior to arrival. The pain is central  radiating to his left arm and is associated with diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and a feeling of discomfort in his stomach. He rates his current pain as an 8 on a scale of 1-10. His past medical history is significant for type-II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a 20-pack-year history of smoking. He takes metformin for his diabetes  amlodipine for his hypertension  and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia but admits to noncompliance with these medications. There is a family history of premature coronary artery disease - his father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. The patient does not have any known drug allergies. On arrival  his blood pressure is found to be 160/95 mm Hg and he has a pulse rate of 95 beats per minute.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Collins  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with acute central chest pain that initiated approximately 2 hours ago while he was mowing his lawn. He describes the pain as ""crushing"" and ""heavy "" rating it at 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. It radiates towards his left arm and up towards his jaw.  He denies shortness of breath  nausea  or light-headedness but looks visibly stressed and is profusely sweating. His medical history is significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a 40-pack year history of smoking. He admits his compliance with his antihypertensive and antilipidemic medications is sporadic. He has no history of diabetes  and there’s no family history of premature coronary artery disease.   On physical examination  he appears to be in discomfort due to the chest pain  currently was tachycardic at 102 beats per minute and hypertensive with blood pressure reading at 160/95 mm Hg. His body mass index (BMI) is 30 kg/m2  indicating obesity. His cardiovascular examination reveals a normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs or Rubs noted. Lung sounds are clear bilaterally. No pitting edema is noted in lower extremities.  The clinical presentation coupled with his medical history raises immediate concern for acute myocardial infarction.

A 65-year-old African-American male presents to the Emergency Department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw that started approximately 1 hour ago. He states the pain started while he was in his garden attempting to move a heavy planter. He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and feeling lightheaded. The patient's pain is described as 8/10 on the pain scale  it is constant  and does not relieve with rest.  His past medical history includes hypertension  hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus  all of which has been managed with medications for the past 10 years. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 62. Patient denies any known drug allergies. He is a former smoker but quit 5 years ago. He admits occasional alcohol intake  specifically red wine with dinner. He denies any history of drug abuse. His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin.   On examination  the patient appears distressed and anxious. Initial vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  a heart rate of 105 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals a moderately obese male in acute respiratory distress. He has cold  sweaty skin and appears pale. Lung auscultation reveals clear lung fields bilaterally and cardiac auscultation reveals tachycardia but no murmurs. His abdomen is soft and non-tender with no palpable masses. The rest of the examination is within normal limits.   Initial ECG shows ST-segment elevations in the inferior leads suggestive of an acute inferior wall myocardial infarction. Doctors immediately start treatment with aspirin  nitroglycerin and heparin  and prepare for urgent cardiac catheterization.

Patient: Mr. Daniels   Age: 65 years  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Chief Complaint: Chest pain  Presenting Issue: Mr. Daniels presents to the emergency department complaining of crushing central chest pain which began two hours ago and is radiating to his left arm and jaw. He describes associated symptoms including shortness of breath  nausea and diaphoresis. He admits to a feeling of impending doom. Past medical records indicate that he had a cerebral infarct 5 years ago.  Social History: Mr. Daniels lives alone  retired from a high-stress job as an investment banker. He admits to drinking alcohol occasionally.   Family History: His father died of a heart attack at the age of 62. His mother died of stroke aged 68. He has one brother age of 63 with a history of coronary artery disease.  Vital Signs: BP: 160/95 mmHg  heart rate: 105 beats/min  respiration rate: 22 breaths/min  SpO2: 89%  and temperature: 99.6 degrees Fahrenheit.  Physical Exam: Mr. Daniels is grimacing with pain  his skin color is pale and appears acutely ill. Auscultation of heart reveals tachycardia. No murmurs noted. Chest is clear on auscultation. Abdomen is soft and non-tender. Pulse and sensation are present in all extremities. Elevated JVP noted. Failed to parse Markdown Referral: On the basis of symptoms  medical history and physical examination  a preliminary diagnosis of Acute Myocardial Infarction was made. Emergency investigations including ECG and cardiac enzyme tests were ordered  and the cardiology team was immediately informed.

A 64-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and neck. The pain started suddenly while he was mowing the lawn about 1 hour ago  and is associated with diaphoresis (excessive sweating) and nausea. It's described as a 9/10 on the pain scale  not relieved by rest. The patient has a known history of poorly controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidaemia. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking and there is a family history of heart disease. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin. He admits that he has been non-compliant with his medications recently. His blood pressure on presentation is 175/95 mmHg and his heart rate is 110bpm. He appears distressed due to the severity of the pain and is visibly sweating. No prior history of similar symptoms. His last full check-up was 6 months ago  and his doctor had advised him to take better control of his DM and blood pressure. He is retired and lives with his wife.

A 62-year-old African American male  Mr. Smith  an accountant with a 15-year history of uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  presents to the emergency department. He is a non-smoker; however  he has a family history of cardiovascular disease as his father had Myocardial Infarction at age 55. He reports experiencing severe  crushing  substernal chest pain for the past 4 hours that radiates to his left arm and jaw. The pain started suddenly while he was resting at home  it is described as 9 out of 10 in severity  and is not relieved by nitroglycerin he was prescribed by his primary care physician. He also states that he feels nauseous  sweaty  and short of breath.   He has been non-compliant with his diabetic and hypertensive medications - metformin and lisinopril  due to financial constraints leading to poor control of his chronic ailments. His most recent HbA1C was 9.0% and Blood pressure recorded was 150/95 mmHg in the last physicians' visit. He has had no previous history of angina  chest discomfort  MI  or strokes. He has no known drug allergies.   He lives with his wife and  due to his work  leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activities. His diet primarily consists of high-carb and high-sodium foods. He occasionally consumes alcohol  about 4 drinks a week.   On examination  he appears pale  diaphoretic  and is clutching his chest with discomfort. His vital signs on admission are BP 168/95 mmHg  Heart rate 110 bpm  Respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  temperature 98.6F  and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Auscultation of the heart demonstrates tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung auscultation is clear bilaterally. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads suggesting an anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Wilson  a 65-year-old white male  presents himself at the Emergency Room with severe chest discomfort  characterized as a heaviness localized centrally and radiating to his left arm. He reports that these symptoms have persisted for 20 minutes on and off and have not improved with rest.   He also reports associated symptoms of nausea  dyspnea  and diaphoresis. On further questioning  he mentions he experienced mild similar chest pain during exercise over the past week which relieved upon resting  but his current symptoms are far more intense.  Mr. Wilson is retired  married  a former smoker (quit 10 years back)  and doesn't consume alcohol. He has a 15-year history of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which are being managed with Metformin  Lisinopril and Amlodipine. His father had a myocardial infarction in his late 50s.  Vitals show a blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 beats/min  respiratory rate 20 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. On assessment  he appears anxious  diaphoretic and in distress.  His ECG shows ST-segment elevations and pathological Q-waves. The diagnosis of STEMI is made and immediate reperfusion therapy is initiated.

Patient Presentation:  A 58-year-old Caucasian male presents at the emergency department with sudden onset  severe central chest pain radiating to the left arm  which began one hour ago while he was at home resting. He describes the pain as a ""crushing pressure"" unlike anything he experienced before. He reports associated shortness of breath  light-headedness  and nausea. The patient also mentions he has been feeling unusually fatigued and has been experiencing episodes of excessive sweating in the past week.   Relevant past medical history reveals that the patient is a 2 pack a day smoker for the past 35 years  diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago  and dyslipidemia 7 years ago  both of which are managed with medications (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively). The patient's father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. There is no reported history of diabetes or previous strokes. The patient does not regularly exercise and reports a diet high in saturated fats. He denies any use of recreational drugs  but admits to daily alcohol consumption.

Patient Information: A 52-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes.   Chief Complaint: Severe chest pain radiating to the left arm.   History of Present Illness: The chest pain started around 1 hour ago  while the patient was at rest. It is described as pressure-like  non-radiating  and non-resolution despite rest. Associated symptoms include nausea  diaphoresis  and shortness of breath. No associated headaches  fever  cough  or abnormal bowel habits.  Past Medical History: Diagnose with hypertension and type II diabetes for 10 years  poorly controlled  on Metformin and Lisinopril. He is a former smoker  quitting 10 years ago but with a 30 pack-year history of smoking.  Social History: He is currently unemployed  living alone  and denies any alcohol or recreational drugs use.  Family History: The father had myocardial infarction at the age of 56 and died at the age 64 due to stroke. No other relevant family medical history.   Review of System: General: Feeling fatigued. No fever or weight changes. Cardiovascular: Chest pain as described above. No palpitations or fainting. Respiratory: Shortness of breath present. No cough  wheezing  or sputum. Gastrointestinal: Mild nausea  no vomiting  normal bowel movements  no blood in stool or black stool.   Physical Examination: Vital signs show BP 170/95mmHg  pulse 110/min  temperature 36.8°C  and respiratory rate 22 breaths/min. Cardiovascular: Tachycardic  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops  increased JVD. Respiratory: Normal breath sounds  no wheezing  rales  or rhonchi.   Working Diagnosis: Acute myocardial infarction.   Plan: ECG  troponin levels  complete blood count  electrolytes  renal function test  chest X-ray  urgent cardiology consult for possible angioplasty or thrombolytic therapy. Also  continue monitoring and maintain IV access for emergency use.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith  a 58-year-old African American male with a significant past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain for the past several hours. The pain is described as pressure-like  centered in his chest  radiating to his left arm and jaw. He mentions that the pain began while he was doing yard work and did not relent with rest. He also reports associated symptoms including shortness of breath  nausea  sweating  and a sense of impending doom.  Mr. Smith's vitals on admission are as follows: blood pressure 155/98 mmHg  heart rate 92 bpm  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. His BMI is 29.9 indicative of overweight status. Past medical records reveal a non-compliance with his antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications. He denies any history of similar symptomatology and a review of family history indicates his father died due to a heart attack at the age of 56.   Mr. Smith's social history includes smoking half a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years and occasional alcohol consumption. He lives with his wife and is currently employed as a truck driver. He has no allergies and had undergone an appendectomy about 15 years ago. His regular medications include amlodipine and simvastatin  though he admits not taking them regularly.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 58-year-old African American male presenting in the emergency department with crushing  substernal chest pain that has been waxing and waning for the past 24 hours. Apart from chest pain  he reports experiencing lightheadedness  shortness of breath  and excessive sweating. He mentions that the pain radiates to his left shoulder and down the left arm  and it is often accompanied by episodic nausea and vomiting. Previously  he had experienced similar episodes that typically lasted for about 10 minutes  but they were much milder and usually occurred after some intense physical activity.  His past medical history includes hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia. He has been taking Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Rosuvastatin for high cholesterol. He is a 20-pack-year smoker and drinks alcohol socially. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 60.  On inspection  Mr. Smith appears to be in acute distress due to pain. His vital signs reveal a BP of 160/95 mm Hg  a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  a resp rate of 18 breaths per minutes  and a temp of 37°C (98.6°F). His body mass index is 33  indicating obesity. The cardiac exam reveals S4 gallop rhythm  and the lungs are clear to auscultation.  This presentation strongly suggests an ongoing acute myocardial infarction (AMI).

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to his left shoulder and jaw. He describes the pain as a sustained  crushing sensation with a severity of 8 out of 10 on the pain scale.   This is the first time he is experiencing this type of pain. The pain started about 2 hours ago while he was mowing his lawn. Accompanying symptoms include sweating  nausea  lightheadedness  and shortness of breath  and any exertion seems to increase the intensity of the pain. There were no alleviating factors  and rest or sublingual nitroglycerin did not improve his symptoms. The pain woke him up from his sleep.  He has a significant medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  which are being managed with medication (metformin for diabetes  amlodipine for hypertension  and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia). He smokes a half-pack of cigarettes daily for the last 35 years and consumes alcohol moderately. He admits to not exercising regularly. His father died of a heart attack at 64 years old.   These aspects  along with physical examination and relevant investigations  suggest the possibility of an acute myocardial infarction. He denied having cough  fever  palpitations  or loss of consciousness. There is no prior documented history of coronary artery disease or other forms of heart disease.   Upon examination  he appears fearful and is sweating profusely. His vital signs are recorded as follows: Blood pressure: 150/95mmHg; Heart rate: 105 beats/minute; Respiratory rate: 22 breaths/minute; Oxygen saturation: 93% on room air; Temperature: 97.8°F. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) and other relevant tests have been immediately ordered for confirmation of diagnosis.

Patient Presentation: A 60-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. The pain  described as being 10/10  began 2 hours earlier while he was mowing his lawn. He described an associated sensation of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and lightheadedness. The pain is unrelieved by rest.   Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension controlled with medication  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is a family history of coronary artery disease. He is an active smoker and admits to a diet high in saturated fats and a sedentary lifestyle.   Demographics: The patient is originally from Wisconsin  USA  and currently works as a truck driver. He lives with his wife and has two grown children. He consumes alcohol occasionally but denies any illicit drug use.   This presentation is suspicious for acute myocardial infarction  warranting immediate further investigation.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents to the Emergency Department experiencing severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. He describes it as a sensation of ""an elephant standing"" on his chest. The pain started about 2 hours ago while he was mowing the lawn and has progressively worsened. He showed symptoms of shortness of breath  and nausea with one episode of vomiting. He adds that he had a similar but not as intense pain 3 days back which subsided on its own.  The patient has a history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past ten years controlled with Metformin  hypertension managed with Lisinopril  and exhibits a 20-year history of smoking1 pack of cigarettes per day. The patient's father died of a heart attack at the age of 72. The patient has a BMI of 28  indicating overweight status.   On examination  the patient appears ill  anxious  and pale. His vitals are BP: 160/90 mmHg  HR: 110/min  RR: 24/min  Temp: 37.1˚C  O2 Sat: 90% on room air. His heart sounds show tachycardia with no murmurs  lung auscultation reveals clear bilateral breath sounds.  He denies any allergies and his only regular medications are metformin and lisinopril. He does not take aspirin at home. He admits to occasional alcohol intake but denies any illicit drug use.  His clinical picture suggests an acute myocardial infarction  requiring immediate investigation and management. Prompt EKG  cardiac enzymes  and consult to cardiology are underway.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male presents at the emergency department complaining of a 2-hour history of severe  crushing pain in the center of his chest  radiating down his left arm and up to his jaw. The pain began at rest  is 9/10 in severity and is associated with cold sweats  nausea and shortness of breath. He states it feels like ""an elephant is sitting on my chest"".  Patient information:  Mr. Jones is a retired construction worker  currently lives with his wife and is a smoker with a 40-pack year history. He drinks alcohol occasionally. His father suffered a myocardial infarction and died at the age of 60. He is obese with a BMI of 32 and has a confirmed diagnosis of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia 5 years ago  for which he is on Metformin and Atorvastatin respectively. Patient reports non-compliance with his medications and has been relatively free of symptoms until his visit today. No known drug allergies reported.  Last blood pressure reading was 160/100 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Soft S4 gallop noted on cardiovascular examination.  He denies any prior episode like this and has never had any surgeries.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Davis  a 65-year-old African-American male  factory worker  presents to the emergency room with acute chest pain that he describes as severe  crushing  and radiating down his left arm. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. He reports the pain started approximately 3 hours ago while he was lifting heavy weights at the gym.  History:  Mr. Davis has a known past medical history of hypertension which he manages with Lisinopril 10mg daily  as suggested by his physician. He has a history of smoking two packs per day for the past 40 years  which he reduced to one pack per day 5 years ago. He confesses to occasional alcohol use but denies the use of any illicit drugs.  Family history includes his father and his older brother both having myocardial infarction in their 50s. His mother has diabetes and hypertension. This patient has never had a cardiac workup done and has always been asymptomatic. Fitness has always been his main health preventive strategy. Recent lab results revealed a raised LDL cholesterol level of 180 mg/dL.  Social History:   He lives with his wife of 35 years in their suburban home. He has been a factory worker his entire life  mostly involving heavy manual labor. He has been worried about his retirement plans and reports increased stress levels in the past year.   He is brought in by his son  who noticed his father was in distress and made the judgment to bring him to the ER. Upon examination  the patient appears in distress related to his chest pain. His medic alert bracelet identifies him as a hypertensive patient. The patient's vital signs show blood pressure of 155/90 mm Hg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation of 88%  and a temperature of 36.9°C. The patient is alert  oriented  and cooperative despite his significant discomfort.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Morris is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset severe  crushing chest pain that started 2 hours ago. He also reports associated symptoms of nausea  sweating  and shortness of breath. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw. He rates the pain as a 9 on a scale of 10 and says it's unlike any pain he's ever experienced before. The patient denies a recent history of trauma or injury.   Medical History:  The patient's past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. His family history includes his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 75. The patient is a 20-year pack smoker and consumes alcohol moderately. He lives alone  is sedentary  and follows an unhealthy diet. He admits non-compliance with his antihypertensive and diabetic medications. His last check-up was a year ago and has no known drug allergies.  Physical Examination:  Vital signs are: BP 170/90 mmHg  Heart rate 110/min  Respiratory rate 24/min  Oxygen saturation 90% on room air  and Temperature 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit. Heart sounds reveal no murmurs  rubs  or gallops  but there is tachycardia. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation bilaterally. He appears anxious  diaphoretic  and pale. Rest of the examination is within normal limits.  Based on his presentation and medical history  a working diagnosis of Acute Myocardial Infarction is made  and he is immediately sent for an EKG.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and smoking (10 packs/year) presents to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: He reports experiencing sudden  severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating starting approximately 3 hours ago.   History of Present Illness: The patient reports never having felt this type of pain before  which he rates as 9 out of 10 on the pain scale. The pain began while he was doing yard work and did not relieve with rest. He also reports a feeling of impending doom.   Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 15 years ago  which is controlled with medications including Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. Type 2 diabetes was diagnosed 7 years ago and is managed with diet and Metformin. Patient admits to smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 20 years  but no alcohol or illicit drug use.   Review of Systems: Positive for diaphoresis and generalized fatigue which he attributed to advancing age.   Physical examination: On examination  he was anxious  pale  and diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 160/95 mm Hg  a pulse of 105 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals a normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs. Lung fields were clear to auscultation bilaterally.   Given the patient's complaints and history  an EKG was immediately done in the emergency department  which showed ST-segment elevations consistent with an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. The patient was given aspirin  nitroglycerin  oxygen  and was rushed to the cardiac catheterization lab for a percutaneous coronary intervention.

A 54-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain which started an hour ago. The pain radiated to the left arm and was associated with sweating and nausea. He describes the pain as 8 out of 10 on the severity scale which did not decrease even after taking rest. The patient reports a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes metformin and lisinopril regularly. He is a smoker with a 20 pack-year history and has a strong family history of ischemic heart disease: both his father and elder brother suffered from heart attacks in their early sixties.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Smith is a 58-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with a one-hour history of severe chest discomfort  described as a heaviness located in the central and upper chest area. He has a history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus which have been managed with amlodipine  atorvastatin  and metformin respectively. The pain started suddenly while watching television  radiating to the left arm and associated with profuse sweating and feeling faint. He has never experienced such a symptom before. There's no recent history of trauma or injury.    His father died of a heart attack at the age of 62 and his elder brother has recently been diagnosed with coronary artery disease. He is an ex-smoker who quit 5 years ago but admits to consuming alcohol socially. He leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his job as a truck driver and diet is generally high in fat and sodium content.  He is married  lives with spouse  and has two grown-up children. Mr. Smith denies any recreational drug use. He has no known drug allergies.   On further questioning  he rates his pain as an 8 out of 10  it started at rest  is constant  and not associated with any chest movement or respiratory changes. He has taken over-the-counter antacid without relief. Patient indicates he feels nauseous but has not vomited and denies any recent change in bowel motion and urination. He also reports feeling anxious due to this unfamiliar severe pain.  Based on the history  examination findings  and risk factors presented  the working diagnosis is an acute myocardial infarction. Further investigations including an electrocardiogram and cardiac biomarkers have been ordered for Mr. Smith.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. James Wilkins  a 63-year-old African-American male.  Chief Complaint: He presents at the Emergency Department complaining of severe chest pain that started around 2 hours ago while he was mowing his lawn. He explains it as a heavy crushing feeling  central in his chest  radiating to his left arm and jaw. He also reports feelings of nausea  shortness of breath and breaking out in a cold sweat.  Past Medical History: Mr. James has been dealing with Type II Diabetes for the past 12 years and Hypertension for 8 years. His lipid profile was abnormal in his last physical examination  3 months ago  showing elevated LDL and low HDL levels. He is currently managing his conditions on medication - Metformin for his diabetes and Lisinopril for Hypertension. He quit smoking 5 years ago but had been a smoker for almost 30 years before that. His father had died at the age of 60 from a Myocardial Infarction.  Physical Analysis: Upon physical examination  he appears diaphoretic and in distress due to the pain. His blood pressure is 170/95 mmHg and heart rate is 95/min. His heart rhythm is regular but rapid. Heart sounds are distant. There are no clinical signs of heart failure.  Based on the patient's symptom description  risk factors  and physical examination  Acute Myocardial Infarction is suspected  and immediate interventions are necessary.

Patient Presentation:  A 66-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with an acute onset of severe chest pain  radiating to his left arm and neck. The pain started almost 4 hours ago  is described as crushing/squeezing in nature  and was not relieved by rest. The patient also mentions associated symptoms such as diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath.   He has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia managed by Amlodipine 5mg daily and Atorvastatin 10mg daily respectively over the past 10 years. The patient is a chronic smoker (30 pack-years) and leads a sedentary lifestyle. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died from myocardial infarction at age 70.  Upon general inspection  the patient appears to be in pain with beads of sweat on his forehead. Continuous telemetry shows occasional ventricular ectopics. On systemic examination  his pulse was 110 bpm (regular)  blood pressure was 150/100 mmHg  respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute  he is afebrile  and his oxygen saturation was 94% on room air.  His EKG showed ST segment elevation in the anterior leads. Blood tests revealed raised Troponin I levels. The rest of the lab work including complete blood count  liver function test  renal function test  and coagulation profile are awaited.  The patient was given aspirin  sublingual nitroglycerin  and a loading dose of ticagrelor. He has been diagnosed with a likely ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and the cardiology team was notified. The patient was rushed to the catheterization laboratory for immediate percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).   The patient was also counseled about the importance of lifestyle modifications  including regular physical activity and smoking cessation.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 55-year-old Hispanic male  known case of hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus under suboptimal control  with a random blood glucose level generally around 200 mg/dL and blood pressure averages around 150/90 mm Hg.  The patient presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  squeezing chest pain radiating to the left arm  lasting for the past hour. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. He denies any prior episodes of similar pain.   The patient has no known allergies and is a 30 pack-year smoker with occasional alcohol use. No illicit drug use reported. The patient has a family history of early onset coronary artery disease  with his father undergoing a coronary artery bypass grafting procedure at the age of 58. He admits he has not been compliant with his prescribed medications  which include metformin and lisinopril  due to financial constraints.   There is no significant surgical history. The patient is currently unemployed and lives with his wife. He has four children who are all in good health.   On examination  the patient appears distressed with profuse sweating. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 155/95 mm Hg  heart rate of 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals regular rhythm  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Chest auscultation demonstrates clear and equal bilateral lung sounds. Abdomen is soft  non-tender with normal bowel sounds.   Based on the patient's presenting symptoms  medical and family history  and basic physical examination  there is a high suspicion for an acute myocardial infarction. Immediate ECG and cardiac enzymes are ordered to confirm.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Harris  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of severe chest pain  which started 2 hours ago while he was exercising. He describes the pain as intense in character  like a ""heavy weight"" or ""pressure""  located in the center of his chest that radiates towards his left arm and jaw. He also mentions experiencing nausea  shortness of breath  and profuse sweating.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Harris has a 5-year history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He reports a 30-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes a day  but quit four years ago. However  he admits to regular alcohol consumption over the past few decades. He has a family history of ischemic heart disease with his father having a heart attack at the age of 60. He is currently on medications for his hypertension (amlodipine) and diabetes (metformin). He has no known drug allergies.  He reported no previous surgeries and is living alone as a widower.  The combination of patient's symptoms  his risk factors (male gender  hypertension  diabetes  former smoker  family history of heart disease)  and history strongly suggest an acute myocardial infarction. Further investigations including a 12-lead ECG and cardiac biomarkers assessment are planned for this patient.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rosenberg  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself into the Emergency Department complaining of acute onset of severe  crushing chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw  which began at rest about three hours ago. He describes the pain as the ""worst pain"" he has ever experienced  accompanied by dyspnea  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom.  He denies experiencing nausea  vomiting  or fainting. He has prescribed nitroglycerin tablets  but notes they failed to provide any relief from the ongoing chest pain.  Mr. Rosenberg's past medical history reveals he is a smoker with 40 pack-years history. He has hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type II Diabetes Mellitus; all are being managed pharmacologically. He suffered from a previous MI five years ago. His father died due to heart disease at an early age.  He denies substance abuse or consuming alcohol but admits being non-compliant with his diet and medication regimen at times. He currently lives alone  is retired  and denies being involved in routine exercise or any significant physical activity.  On examination  his vitals include BP: 155/92 mmHg  HR: 112 bpm  RR: 20 bpm  and O2: 94% on room air. His Physical examination revealed diaphoresis  pale skin  and he appears visibly distressed. His cardiovascular examination revealed a regular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. EKG showed ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction.  Based on the initial evaluation  differential diagnoses include acute myocardial infarction  acute pericarditis  dissecting aortic aneurysm  and pulmonary embolism. Considering the patient's history  symptoms  and ECG findings  an acute myocardial infarction is suspected.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 56-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years  presents to the emergency department reporting acute onset chest pain. The pain started roughly 2 hours ago while he was carrying groceries from his car. It is described as severe  pressure-like pain located in the center of his chest radiating to his left shoulder and arm. The pain is exacerbated by physical exertion and somewhat relieved by rest.   In addition to the chest pain  he reports associated shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  and a feeling of impending doom. He denies any cough  fever  recent travel  recent surgery  palpitations  or lower extremity swelling. He has no known allergies and current medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin.  His father passed away at age 61 from a heart attack and his mother at age 65 from complications of stroke. He is employed as a construction worker and lives with his wife. He drinks alcohol occasionally but denies any illicit drug use.  On examination  he appears diaphoretic and in distress. He is afebrile  blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air.  Given his symptoms  risk factors  and family history  Mr. Doe is suspected to be experiencing an acute myocardial infarction and immediate action should be taken to confirm the diagnosis and manage his condition.

Patient Information: A 52-year-old African American male  married  working as a construction foreman.  Presenting complaint: Patient presents with new onset chest pain for the past 2 hours  which he describes as a ""heavy pressure"" and ""squeezing"" sensation in the center of his chest.  Associated symptoms: He also reports shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. These symptoms are more severe with physical activity and mildly relieved by rest.  Medical History: Patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is poorly controlled  and Hypertension. No previous history of heart disease.   Family History: Father had a heart attack around the same age.   Lifestyle: Smoker for the past 30 years  trying to quit. Reports high workload stress. Rarely engages in physical exercise. Diet consists mostly of fast food due to work constraints.   Medications: Metformin  Lisinopril. No known drug allergies.  Vital Signs: Blood Pressure- 160/90 mmHg  Heart Rate- 100 beats per minute  Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation: 95% on room air and Temperature: 37.1 degree Celsius.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 60-year-old African-American male who presents to the ER with severe  crushing chest pain that started an hour ago while shoveling snow. He describes the pain as ""like an elephant sitting on my chest"". The pain radiates down both arms  though it is more severe in the left. He also reports shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a sense of impending doom.  His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes  hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes Metformin  Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He has a 40-pack year smoking history and there is a family history of ischemic heart disease; his father died of a heart attack at age 55. He confesses a poor diet and sedentary lifestyle  with infrequent exercise. He denies any history of previous heart surgery or procedures.  Vitals upon arrival: BP 165/95mmHg  HR 105bpm  RR 22bpm  Temp 98.6°F  SpO2 92% on room air. He appears diaphoretic and in distress from pain.  Based on his present symptoms  credible risk factors  and severe  characteristic chest pain  acute myocardial infarction is suspected and the patient is rushed to the cath lab for immediate evaluation and treatment.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of sudden onset  severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. The pain started an hour prior while he was resting  and is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  light-headedness  and a cold  clammy feeling.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of conditions including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which have been managed with metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin for the past eight years. He was a smoker  who quit a decade ago after 20 years of a 1-pack/day smoking habit. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 55 years  and his 67-year-old brother was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease. The patient lives with his wife  has two grown-up children  works as a professional engineer  and has no history of substance abuse. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle  a high cholesterol diet  and he reports poor stress management despite attempting relaxed  regular exercise.   This presentation of sudden-onset  severe  radiating chest pain with accompanying symptoms like shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis in a patient with multiple risk factors for coronary artery disease is suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Thomas  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department.   Chief Complaint: He reports severe chest pain that started around 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as a heavy pressure sensation radiating to the left arm and jaw. The pain is constant and rated at 8 out of 10.   History of Present Illness: He also reports associated symptoms including shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. There have been no episodes of dizziness  syncope or loss of consciousness.   Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension controlled with atenolol and amlodipine  hyperlipidemia managed with simvastatin  and a 20-pack-year history of tobacco use (quit 5 years ago). No known history of diabetes mellitus  kidney disease  or previous cardiac condition. No allergies reported.    Family History:  There is a significant family history  as the father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and mother has type 2 diabetes.   Social History: He is a retired accountant  lives alone at his home  abstains from alcohol use  and has quit smoking five years ago after smoking for 40 years.  Review of Systems: Negative for fever  chills  headache  abdominal pain  changes in bowel and bladder habits  weight loss  or edema. Reports some mild fatigue over the past week.   Physical Examination: On examination  he is diaphoretic and appears anxious. Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg  heart rate of 95 beats/min  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min  temperature of 36.8°C  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. There are no abnormal findings on heart  lung  and abdominal exam.   Preliminary Assessment: Given the patient’s symptoms and risk factors  there is a high suspicion for acute myocardial infarction. This needs immediate evaluation with an electrocardiogram and cardiac enzymes testing.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the Emergency Department with severe  crushing central chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  accompanied by shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. These symptoms began approximately one hour ago at rest. Initial Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 145/90mmHg  heart rate 102 beats/min  respiratory rate 20 breaths/min  oxygen saturation 94% on room air  temperature 98.6 F.  Mr Doe has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years. He has been on regular medication for both conditions  specifically Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension  and Metformin 1000mg twice daily for diabetes. He has a 30-year history of smoking a half a pack of cigarettes daily and admits to consume alcohol occasionally. He has no known drug allergies. His family history reveals his father died of a heart attack at 70 years of age.   Mr. Doe is retired  lives with his wife  and they have economic stability. He has been following a diet and exercise regimen for managing his chronic conditions but with questionable compliance. He denies the use of any illegal drugs and reports being up-to-date with his yearly check-ups.  On physical examination  he appears restless and in obvious distress. Cardiac examination reveals regular rate and rhythm  no murmurs or gallops.   Given the severity of the symptoms and the patient's relevant past medical history of hypertension and diabetes  we highly suspect an acute myocardial infarction. Further diagnostic and therapeutic intervention would be initiated promptly after the results of ECG and cardiac biomarker test results.

A 63-year-old African-American male presented to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. He rates the pain as 8/10 and states that it started while he was mowing the lawn and did not diminish with rest. The patient also reported associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and hyperlipidemia. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years. Both his father and brother had heart attacks in their early 50s. He is currently on metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He has an allergy to penicillin  which causes rash.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency room with a chief complaint of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. The onset of symptoms occurred approximately 2 hours ago while he was mowing his lawn and has been continuous and unrelieved by rest or nitroglycerin.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are both managed with medication (amlodipine and atorvastatin  respectively). He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. Family history is significant for an older brother who suffered a heart attack in his early 60s. Mr. Doe maintains a sedentary lifestyle but does involve in light activities like mowing the lawn. His diet is high in fat and he admits to a history of poor dietary control. Mr. Doe does not report any known allergies.  Review of Systems:  ROS is positive for episodic chest tightness over the past few months  infrequent episodes of indigestion  occasional fatigue post exercise  and poor sleep quality. ROS is negative for recent illness  fever  cough  abdominal pain  urinary complaints  skin changes  or notable weight changes.   Physical Examination:  Upon examination  Mr. Doe appears anxious and sweaty. He has a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals normal S1 and S2 and no murmurs. Pulses are palpable in all extremities. Other systems are clinically unremarkable.

Patient Information: Mr. Franklin Johnson  62-year-old Caucasian male  current smoker  with a history of Type II diabetes and hypertension  has come to the emergency room complaining of severe central chest pain  which he describes as ""crushing"" and radiating to his left arm. The pain started approximately 3 hours ago and has been continuous since then. Mr. Johnson further reports accompanying symptoms of excessive sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath.  Relevant Past History: The patient has a ten-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  currently managed with Metformin  and five-year history of Hypertension  on Lisinopril. He also has a family history of ischemic heart disease  with both his father and an elder brother having had myocardial infarctions before the age 65. He has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years and admits to sedentary lifestyle with occasional alcohol consumption. He denies any drug allergies.  Resultant Statement: This is a 62-year-old Caucasian male smoker with a past medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus who presents to the emergency department with a 3-hour episode of unrelenting central chest pain radiating to the left arm. He also reports sweating  nausea  and difficulty in breathing. His family history and personal lifestyle habits increase his risk for cardiovascular complications.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and a 40 pack-year smoking history  presents to the Emergency Room. He reports experiencing sudden onset of severe  dull  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm for the past 3 hours. The pain is associated with profuse sweating and shortness of breath and rates it as a 9/10 on the pain scale. The pain did not resolve with rest and nitroglycerin.  Mr. Smith states he has been prescribed metformin for his diabetes  and amlodipine for hypertension. He is compliant with his medication and maintains regular follow-up with his primary care doctor. He has no known allergies. His family history is significant for ischemic heart disease with his father having a myocardial infarction at 55 years of age.   On examination  he appears uncomfortable and is sweating. His BMI is 27  BP 160/95 mmHg  HR 110 bpm  RR 20/min  and SpO2 is 94% on room air. His cardiac examination shows tachycardia with no murmurs or gallops. Lungs are clear bilaterally.   An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  and troponin levels were elevated  which are indicative of an acute inferior wall myocardial infarction. The patient was immediately started on aspirin  nitroglycerin  and heparin  and preparations were made for urgent coronary angiography.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Fernandez is a 58-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the Emergency Department with acute onset of severe chest pain that started one hour ago while he was at rest. He describes the pain as ""crushing"" in nature  radiating to his left arm and jaw  and associated with shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea. He rates the pain as 10/10 and states it was not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Fernandez has a history of hypertension for which he takes lisinopril as well as a history of Type 2 diabetes managed with metformin. He was a smoker for 30 years but quit 5 years ago. His father died of a heart attack at 60  and his mother has hypertension.   Social History:   Mr. Fernandez works as a construction worker  lives with his wife and two children  and denies alcohol or illicit drug use. He admits that his diet is high in sodium and he has a sedentary lifestyle outside of his labor-intensive job.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Hamilton is a 52-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the emergency department with sudden onset central chest discomfort  described as a pressure-like sensation radiating to his left arm. Mr. Hamilton is diaphoretic and looks visibly distressed. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidaemia  for which he takes Lisinopril and Simvastatin  respectively. There is a family history of heart disease; his father suffered a myocardial infarction at a similar age.   Mr. Hamilton has been a smoker for 20 years  smoking approximately a pack a day  and admits to a sedentary lifestyle with occasional alcohol intake. The pain began while he was sitting at his desk  around 4 PM and lasted for 20 minutes  until administration of some aspirin  after which it has lessened but not fully resolved. The pain is not positional and does not change with breathing. He reports no recent illness  fever  trauma  or other symptoms.   On clinical examination  his blood pressure is noted to be 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  regular rhythm and his respiratory rate is 22 breaths/minute with an O2 saturation level of 92% on room air. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.   Given the patient's presentation  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking history  and family history of cardiac disease  an acute coronary syndrome  most likely an acute myocardial infarction  is highly suspected. Immediate electrocardiogram (ECG)  cardiac enzymes  and supportive treatment have been initiated.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is an 60-year-old African American male  presenting to the emergency department with severe chest pain for the past 3 hours. He is a long term smoker (15+ years) and has a medical history notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has no known allergies to any medications and is currently on metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin.   The chest pain is central  described as a pressure-like sensation  lasting for more than 15 minutes  and radiates to the left arm. This is associated with shortness of breath  sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. He experienced similar chest pain while playing golf two days ago  but that pain subsided after 5 minutes of rest.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg  heart rate is 110 bpm  respiratory rate is 24 bpm  and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. His body mass index (BMI) is 31. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia without any murmurs  rubs  or gallops  and no cyanosis  clubbing  or Oedema was observed in any of the limbs.   His post-prandial glucose level is 210 mg/dl (normal range: 140-200 mg/dl) and hemoglobin A1c is 9%. His lipid profile shows elevated LDL cholesterol. An electrocardiogram shows ST elevation in leads II  III  and aVF.   Given the patient’s symptoms and ECG data  a diagnosis of acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction is made. The patient is given aspirin and sublingual nitroglycerin in the emergency room and arrangements are made for immediate cardiac catheterization to determine the extent of coronary artery disease and necessary interventions.

Patient Information: Mr. James Thompson  a 63-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: Main complaint is a severe  heavy chest pain that started about 2 hours ago while he was gardening at home. The pain radiates to his left arm and neck. Mr. Thompson also reports associated symptoms such as shortness of breath  nausea  diaphoresis  and a sense of impending doom.  Past Medical History: Upon inquiry  he admits to a past medical history of Type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-year history of smoking 10 cigarettes a day  which he quit 5 years ago. He also discloses that his father had a heart attack at age 55.  Medications: For his diabetes  he is on metformin 500mg twice a day  and for hypertension  he takes amlodipine 5mg once a day. His lipid levels are managed with atorvastatin 20mg daily.  Allergies: He has no known drug allergies.   Review of Systems: Apart from his chief complaint  he categorically denies any other symptoms including fever  cough  headache  abdominal pain  frequent urination  or any noticeable changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Physical Examination: He is visibly distressed and diaphoretic. Vitals include a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg  a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. On cardiovascular examination  his heart sounds are muffled; there are no murmurs or additional sounds.   Based on the history and physical examination an acute myocardial infarction was highly suspected  and lifesaving treatment interventions were promptly implemented.

Patient Information: Mr. Davis  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a significant past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 40 pack-year smoking history.  Chief Complaint: Presents to the emergency department with severe and crushing chest pain for the last three hours  which radiates to his left arm and jaw.  History of Present Illness: The pain was sudden onset and has been progressively increasing in severity. It is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  profuse sweating and a feeling of impending doom. It doesn't get relief from rest or nitroglycerin. Mr. Davis also mentions recent episodes of similar but less intense chest discomfort over the past week.  Review of System: Mr. Davis also reports feeling progressively fatigued over the last few days  minor episodes of lightheadedness but no fainting spells. He also had some nausea before the onset of the chest pain.  Past Medical History: Mr. Davis was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and hyperlipidemia around eight years back  both controlled on medication. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit five years ago when he was advised about his high risk for heart disease   Family History: His father passed away from an acute myocardial infarction at the age of 74 and his older sister  aged 75  suffers from coronary artery disease.   Current Medications: Mr. Davis is currently prescribed atenolol for hypertension  simvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and low dose Aspirin for CV risk reduction.   Social History: Retired from his job as an accountant  lives with his wife and enjoys fishing and reading. He quit smoking five years ago but has been a social drinker  consuming three to four beers weekly.  Physical Examination: Vital signs show elevated blood pressure at 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate is irregular at 105/min  and respirations are increased at 20 breaths per minute. He appears acutely distressed with visible diaphoresis. Auscultation of his chest reveals regular S1 and S2 with no added sounds. Pulses in all limbs are palpable and there are no signs of swelling or discoloration. ECG reveals ST-segment elevations suggesting an acute myocardial infarction.   After the initial assessment and ECG  Mr. Davis is initiated on reperfusion therapy promptly and admitted to cardiac ICU for further management.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John Smith who presents to the Emergency Department accompanied by his wife with complaints of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and arm for the past two hours. The pain is described as unrelenting  a ""heavy pressure""  and is 10/10 in severity. The patient further complains of associated shortness of breath  nausea  profuse sweating  and feelings of impending doom.   The patient has a significant medical history including hypertension for which he takes Amlodipine 5mg daily and hypercholesterolemia for which he is prescribed Atorvastatin 20mg nightly. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago after a 20-year history. He is also noted to have a family history of ischemic heart disease - his father had a myocardial infarction at age 59 and died from subsequent heart failure.   Upon examination  the patient appears pale  fearful  and diaphoretic. His current vitals show an elevated blood pressure of 165/95mmHg  tachycardia with a pulse rate of 110bpm  a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation of 93% on room air  and a temperature of 98.6°F.   The ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads (II  III  aVF) consistent with an acute STEMI. Immediately  the patient was administered Aspirin 300 mg  sublingual GTN  and oxygen was provided. The cardiology team was notified urgently and the patient was transferred for primary percutaneous coronary intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 58-year-old Caucasian male known to be a chronic smoker with a 30 pack-year smoking history. He works as a truck driver  has a sedentary lifestyle and is clinically overweight with a BMI of 28. He has a previous medical history of hypertension and elevated cholesterol for which he is on medication  including amlodipine 5mg daily and atorvastatin 20mg daily.  The patient presents today at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain for the past four hours. He describes the pain as severe  crushing and centrally located  and radiating down his left arm. The pain did not subside with rest. He also reports associated symptoms including cold sweats  nausea  and feeling of impending doom. He denies any cough  dyspnea  or fever. He notes a positive family history of ischemic heart disease  as his father suffered a heart attack at the age of 60.  The patient is visibly in distress  appears pale and diaphoretic. His blood pressure is 150/80 mmHg  pulse 96 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 94% on room air  and temperature is 98.4°F. On examination  heart sounds are normal without any murmurs  and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. ECG shows changes consistent with anterior wall myocardial infarction. Immediate management for suspected acute myocardial infarction has been initiated.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 63-year-old white male  married with three adult children. He works as an operating engineer and reports smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain that radiates to his left arm  which started around 2 hours back while he was at work. He also mentions associated shortness of breath  profuse sweating and a sense of impending doom.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith suffers from hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both diagnosed 12 years ago and for which he takes amlodipine and metformin  respectively. He mentions his father had a heart attack aged 52. He also reports high cholesterol which he was prescribed statins for  but admits to not taking them regularly. He denies any known allergies to medications.   Social History:  Mr. Smith reports an extensive smoking history with a 40 pack-year history of cigarette smoking. He denies illegal drug use  and drinks alcohol occasionally. His diet is described as 'not the best' with frequent consumption of fast food. He lives with his wife at home but admits they have been experiencing recent stress due to financial issues. He has a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  crushing chest pain that started at rest two hours ago. The pain radiates down his left arm up to his jaw. It is associated with cold sweats  shortness of breath  nausea  and a feeling of impending doom.   He has a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia. He quit smoking 10 years ago  after a 30 pack-year history. He is currently on treatment with amlodipine for hypertension  metformin for diabetes  and atorvastatin for his hypercholesterolemia. He denies any known drug allergies.   According to his wife  who accompanies him to the hospital  there is a family history of heart disease with his father dying of a heart attack in his 60s. His wife also reports the patient has been noncompliant with his medications and diet regime in the past few weeks due to depressive symptoms.  On examination  the patient appears diaphoretic and in overall distress. His blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air.  In light of the patient's characteristic symptoms  risk factors  and physical examination  the primary differential diagnosis is acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male arrives to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain from the past 2 hours. The pain is described as a crushing type  located in the center of his chest  radiating to the left shoulder and jaw. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. Upon questioning  the pain is rated 9/10 and is unrelieved by rest.   Past Medical History: Patient has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hiperlipidemia  and a 20-year history of cigarette smoking. Patient has been non-compliant with his prescribed medication regimen which includes metformin  atorvastatin and lisinopril. Patient's father had a heart attack at age 58. The patient does not exercise regularly and follows a high-fat  high-sugar diet.   This patient is at high risk for acute myocardial infarction given his age  male gender  African American ethnicity  comorbidities such as hypertension and type 2 diabetes  smoking history and a poor diet. Immediate actions must be taken to manage the possible myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old African-American male presenting to the emergency department (ED) with a primary complaint of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  associated with diaphoresis and shortness of breath. He reports that he was sitting at home watching television when the pain suddenly began an hour ago and has not subsided. He rates his pain 8 on a scale of 10.  Past Medical History (PMH):   Mr. Johnson is known hypertensive for the last five years and is currently on Hydrochlorothiazide and Lisinopril. He also has a history of Dyslipidemia and is non-compliant with his diet and medication (Atorvastatin). He is a 20 pack-year smoker  currently still smoking. He drinks alcohol moderately but denies illicit drug use. Mr. Johnson has a family history of heart diseases; his father had a myocardial infarction at age 65. His latest ECG performed a year ago was normal.   Social History (SH):   Mr. Johnson lives with his wife and is retired. He smoked a pack of cigarettes every day for 20 years. Has a moderate alcohol intake but denies illicit drug use.   On examination:   He looks uncomfortable  pale  diaphoretic  is fully oriented but in distress due to the pain. He is overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32. Vital signs show blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs or gallops. Pulmonary  Abdominal and Neurological examinations are unremarkable.   Based on the clinical presentation and his risk factors (age  gender  African American race  smoking  hypertension  dyslipidemia  family history  and non-compliance to medication)  an acute myocardial infarction is highly suspected. He is immediately given pain relief  oxygen  aspirin  and nitroglycerin as per treatment protocol and is sent for emergency ECG and cardiac enzymes estimation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Adams is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw that started roughly an hour ago. He rates the pain as 10 out of 10  with associated symptoms of shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. He confirms the pain began at rest  has not subsided with movement  and is unlike any pain he has felt before.   Mr. Adams has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia for which he takes metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin  respectively. He has a 40 pack year history of smoking  but quit 10 years ago. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease  with his father having had a myocardial infarction at 72  and his older brother at 63. Mr. Adams denies any allergies to medications. He does not consume alcohol and denies recreational drug use. His only exercise is a short walk around his neighborhood in the mornings  and his diet includes a high consumption of red meats and fried foods.  Upon physical examination  Mr. Adams appears pale and sweaty. His vital signs show a blood pressure of 150/95 mm Hg  pulse rate of 100 beats per minute  respirations at 22 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.  An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads suggestive of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. He is quickly given aspirin. Subsequent cardiac enzyme tests confirm the diagnosis of an acute myocardial infarction with significantly elevated levels of troponin. Detailed careful evaluation and appropriate treatment were started immediately. He was also referred to a cardiologist for further evaluation and possible intervention.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and neck which started an hour ago. He describes the pain as 'pressure-like' and 'tightening'  and it is unrelieved by rest. Accompanying the chest pain  he has been experiencing shortness of breath  sweating  and lightheadedness.  Past Medical History: He has a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with a beta-blocker and a statin  respectively. He also has a 40 pack-year history of smoking and has been a social drinker. He is known to have a high-stress job and does not participate in regular physical exercise. There is a family history of heart disease  with his father dying from a heart attack at age 55. He has no known drug allergies. Additionally  he reported his compliance with medications is often poor.  Current Medications: Atenolol 50mg once daily  Atorvastatin 40mg once daily.    The patient denies any previous similar episodes or any previous diagnosis of angina  heart disease or diabetes. His last general check-up was two years ago  and at that time his laboratory tests including a complete blood count  liver function test  kidney function test  fasting glucose  and lipid profile were all reported normal. He reports an increasing frequency of exertional dyspnea on walking up a flight of stairs or up a hill for the last six months. He did not seek any medical help for these symptoms.   The patient’s current pain fails to remit despite rest  so this  in combination with his risk factors  raises concern about potential acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 68-year-old African American male presenting in the emergency department with severe  pressure-like chest pain which has been ongoing for the past 2 hours. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of intense anxiety.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellites  all of which have been managed with medication (lisinopril  atorvastatin  and metformin respectively) for the past 10 years. Mr. Smith used to be a significant smoker (30 pack-years  quit 6 years ago) and admits to occasional alcohol use but denies recreational drug usage.  On further inquiry  Mr. Smith states that he has been having minor chest discomfort on exertion for the past week  which he attributed to indigestion. He also recalls episodes similar to his current symptoms which resolved following rest.  There is a relevant family history of ischemic heart disease  with his father having passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.  Physical examination at the time of presentation revealed hypertension with a blood pressure of 175/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 110/min  respiratory rate of 24/min  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Rest of the examination was relatively unremarkable  showing no signs of congestive heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Thompson  a 62-year-old Caucasian man  presented to the emergency department with a severe  crushing chest pain radiating down the left arm. He describes the pain as a heavy pressure on his chest  which started approximately 3 hours before his hospital arrival when he was performing heavy physical labor at his construction job.   Mr. Thompson says the pain is accompanied by shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and lightheadedness. He denied any nausea  vomiting  fever  or recent upper respiratory tract infection symptoms. He also mentioned that his chest pain is not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin.   He has a past medical history of hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago and is a smoker with a 40-pack year history. He is currently on Lisinopril for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes  and Simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He has a family history of ischemic heart disease with his father having a heart attack at the age of 60.  On examination  he appears uncomfortable and anxious. His physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg  pulse of 100 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiac auscultations were normal  no murmurs or crackles were heard. Extremities were cool  and no signs of peripheral edema were found.   Given his symptoms in conjunction with his significant risk factors for coronary artery disease including age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and family history of myocardial infarction  a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction was considered.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of severe  crushing chest pain  radiating down to his left arm and up to his jaw. The pain is continuous  along with a feeling of pressure and tightness in his chest. He also reports feelings of lightheadedness and shortness of breath. He has been sweating profusely and has vomited once since the onset of pain. He denies a history of previous similar episodes.  Past Medical History:   The patient is a known case of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  on regular medication including an ACE inhibitor and a statin for over a decade. He quit smoking around 5 years ago but had a smoking history of 25 pack years prior to cessation. He lives a sedentary lifestyle and reports being overweight with a BMI of 30. His father had a heart attack at age 70. He admits to being non-compliant with diet restrictions and occasionally skips his medications.  Given the acute onset of symptoms and the patient's risk factors such as advanced age  male gender  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  history of smoking and a family history of heart disease  an acute myocardial infarction is suspected.

A 56-year-old African American male presents to the Emergency Department with severe  squeezing chest pain that started approximately 2 hours ago. The pain radiates to his left shoulder  is rated 9/10 and has gradually been getting worse since it started. The patient describes associated symptoms of shortness of breath  profuse cold sweats  and nausea. He reports a past medical history of Hypertension  Type II Diabetes and high cholesterol  for which he takes Metformin and Atorvastatin. He has family history of cardiovascular diseases: his father suffered from a heart attack at the age of 62 and his older brother had an angioplasty in his 50's. The patient admits to a 30 pack year smoking history but denies alcohol or drug abuse. He has tried taking over-the-counter antacids and ibuprofen but it has not alleviated the pain. Upon arrival  the patient is visibly distressed  pale  diaphoretic  and clutching his chest. He also has an obesity body habitus with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J. R.  a 63-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe  and crushing chest pain that started two hours ago. He describes the pain as being located in the center of his chest and radiating down his left arm and up to his jaw. He also reports associated symptoms  including shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea.  His vital signs on arrival are: BP 154/92 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 92% on room air  and temperature 98.9°F.   He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which have been controlled with medication for the past 15 years. He also has a significant 30-pack year smoking history  but quit 5 years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol socially  but denies using any illicit or recreational drugs. His only known allergies are to shellfish and penicillin. He is currently taking metformin  lisinopril  and aspirin daily.   His father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He lives with his wife  retired  and reports that he usually maintains an active lifestyle. He reports having experienced similar but less severe symptoms a week ago while doing yard work  which he attributed to indigestion.
