Physical examination revealed that he appeared distressed and diaphoretic. Cardiac examination showed tachycardia without any murmurs or gallops. Pulmonary examination revealed bilateral clear lung fields. Rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Based on his clinical presentation  past medical history  and risk factors  acute myocardial infarction is suspected. Immediate EKG and cardiac marker tests are being ordered.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the Emergency Department with a complaint of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  accompanied by shortness of breath  dizziness  profuse sweating  and nausea. The pain started all of a sudden about 3 hours ago while he was doing yard work and has been persistent since. He rates the pain as a 10 out of 10 on the pain scale.  Patient History:  Mr. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension and dyslipidemia  both of which are managed with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively). He has a 30 pack-year smoking history  but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies illicit drug use. His family history is notable for coronary artery disease  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. There's no known drug allergy.   His regular medications include Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension and Atorvastatin 40mg daily for dyslipidemia.  Based on his symptoms  risk factors  and past medical history  Mr. Johnson is highly suspected of presenting with an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He describes the pain as a crushing pressure in the center of his chest that started about three hours ago and has not subsided. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw. He also reports shortness of breath  nausea  intense sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the chest.  Mr. Jones has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are managed with medication. He is a 20 pack-year smoker and consumes 2-3 alcoholic beverages per week. His family history includes a father who died in his 60s from a heart attack. His current medications include Metformin and Lisinopril.  Physical examination shows a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 92 bpm  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. He appears anxious and diaphoretic. On cardiac auscultation  there are no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. EKG shows ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF. Bloodwork reveals elevated troponin levels. Patient is provided with aspirin  nitroglycerin  and oxygen  and is prepared for further diagnostic testing and management.   This presentation suggests an acute myocardial infarction  likely an inferior wall MI  given the EKG findings.

Patient Presentation:  A 63-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. The pain began about 3 hours ago while he was gardening and has persisted despite rest. He also reports accompanying symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. He describes the pain as 9 out of 10 in intensity  and unrelieved by over-the-counter aspirin.   His past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has a 35-year pack history of smoking tobacco but quit 5 years ago. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 68. His current medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He is allergic to penicillin  which gives him a rash.   On examination  blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient appears pale and in distress. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with a regular rhythm  and no audible murmur. Lung sounds are clear bilaterally. Abdomen is soft  non-tender with no organomegaly.   ECG shows ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF  suggesting an inferior wall myocardial infarction. The patient has been given nitroglycerin  oxygen and morphine for pain relief in the ER as per acute MI protocol.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: Severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw for the past two hours.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia. No known allergies are reported. He is a former smoker  quit 15 years ago  but had a substantive 20-pack year history prior to quitting.   Family History: His father had coronary artery disease and passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 70.  Medications: The patient is on the following medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  Review of Systems: The patient reports feeling a sense of impending doom  profuse sweating  nausea  shortness of breath  and lightheadedness. He denies recent episodes of fever  cough  or any urinary symptoms.  Physical Examination: The patient appears to be in severe distress  sweating profusely. Vitals show a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate is 105 bpm  respiratory rate of 25 breaths/min  temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F)  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The pulmonary exam has clear and equal breath sounds.   Diagnostic Studies: Initial EKG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF. Labs reveal troponin T levels are elevated at 0.5 ng/mL  the D-dimer test is negative.   Case progression: The patient was diagnosed with acute inferior wall myocardial infarction. Immediate reperfusion therapy was initiated and the patient was transferred to the catheterization lab for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Jennifer Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus  presents to the emergency department with acute onset severe crushing chest pain radiating to her left arm and neck. The pain started approximately 2 hours ago and is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  profuse sweating  and a sense of impending doom. She also reports intermittent chest pain on exertion for the past two months that she self-medicated with over-the-counter antacids.  Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide  atorvastatin  and metformin. She has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago  and consumes moderate alcohol occasionally. Her family history is suggestive of cardiovascular disease  with her father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58.  On examination  she appeared anxious and diaphoretic. Vital signs showed blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia and no murmurs. Lungs were clear on auscultation and there was no peripheral edema. Other systems were unremarkable.  Her ECG showed ST-segment elevation in inferior and lateral leads  suggestive of acute myocardial infarction. Troponin levels were pending. Immediately  a cardiology consultation was requested for a potential emergency coronary angiography. She was also started on aspirin  clopidogrel  nitroglycerin  and morphine for pain management as per the acute coronary syndrome protocol.

Patient Information: A 52-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: Chest pain for the past 4 hours.  History of Present Illness: The chest pain is described as a crushing pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  accompanied by profuse sweating  feeling of impending doom  and severe shortness of breath. No alleviating or aggravating factors are identified.   Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a 20-year history of smoking and occasional alcohol use.  Medications: Atenolol 50 mg once daily and Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.   Family History: Positive for ischemic heart disease with his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 55.    Physical Examination: On examination  the patient is diaphoretic and appears anxious. BP: 170/95 mmHg  HR: 115 bpm  RR: 24 breaths/min  temp: 98.7 F  and pulse oximetry: 93% on room air. Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung examination shows no rales or wheezes.    Working Diagnosis: Based on the above presentation  a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction is considered.   Plan: Stat EKG  cardiac biomarkers  chest X-ray  and urgent cardiology consult. Start on aspirin  nitroglycerin  oxygen  and consider thrombolysis or percutaneous coronary intervention based on cardiology consultation and further investigations.

Patient Presentation:   A 66-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. The pain started suddenly nearly two hours ago while he was resting and is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea and vomiting. He rates the pain as 10 out of 10. He denies any trauma  cough  fever  abdominal pain  recent travel or leg swelling.   Past Medical History:   Significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes lisinopril and atorvastatin  respectively. He is also a chronic smoker and admits to a 20 pack-year history. His father died of a heart attack at 70. He does not have any known history of diabetes or previous heart disease. He denies any drug allergies. His usual diet is high in sodium and saturated fats. He also admits to being fairly sedentary  with little physical activity.  Physical Examination:  Vital Signs: Temp 98.6 F  HR 110 beats/min  RR 22 breaths/min  BP 160/90 mmHg  Oxygen saturation 90% on room air. General: The patient appears anxious and diaphoretic. Cardiovascular: Heart sounds are regular  but tachycardic. No murmurs are noted. Pulmonary: Lung fields are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Neurological: Alert and oriented to person  place  and time.   Initial impression points to an acute myocardial infarction  and the patient is immediately placed on a cardiac monitor. Further investigation and medical intervention is needed as per the hospital protocol for MI.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 67-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and smoking. He comes into the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset  severe chest pain that started 3 hours ago and extends to his left arm. The pain is described as a heavy  squeezing sensation  rated 8/10 and is accompanied by shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea and lightheadedness. He states the chest pain was slightly relieved by nitroglycerin provided by the paramedics en route.  There is no known history of similar previous episodes. He reports being compliant with his antihypertensive and cholesterol medications. He also mentions he's been smoking one pack of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. There is a family history of premature coronary artery disease in his father who had a heart attack at the age of 50. He is not aware of any allergies to medications.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Joseph Adams is a 56-year-old Caucasian male who walks into the emergency department presenting complaints of constricting chest pain that has been radiating to the left arm and jaw  starting around two hours ago while mowing his lawn. The pain is described as severe and crushing in nature  grading 8 out of 10. The pain is associated with profuse sweating and nausea. He has never experienced a similar pain before.   Mr. Adams has a 15-year history of uncontrolled hypertension. He has been on antihypertensive medication  but poor adherence is noted. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years and hyperlipidemia. Both are managed with oral medication. Mr. Adams is a 30 pack-year smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. There is an immediate history of coronary artery disease amongst his family members; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.   On examination  the patient appears to be in distress  pale  sweaty and breathless. Vital signs reveal BP: 160/90mmHg  pulse: 110 beats per minute  respirations: 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation: 94% on room air.   Based on history and present examination findings  Mr. Adams's symptomology is highly suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 60-yearold African American male who presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain that started roughly 2 hours ago. The pain radiates to his left arm and is accompanied by shortness of breath. He describes the pain as being the ""worst pain"" he has ever experienced. He has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes medication. His father passed away from heart disease in his early 60s. He is a 30 pack year smoker and admits that his diet could be better. He has been experiencing episodes of milder chest discomfort over the past month that he attributed to indigestion. Despite his medications  his blood pressure is currently elevated. He states he has not had any issues with flu-like symptoms or fever.   Upon examination  Mr. Smith appears very anxious and sweaty with a slightly elevated respiratory rate. His pulses are rapid and thready. His ECG shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads. He was given immediate treatment for acute myocardial infarction  including oxygen  aspirin  nitroglycerin  and morphine for the pain. His troponin levels were significantly elevated  confirming the suspected diagnosis. He was immediately referred to the cardiology team for angioplasty.

A 62-year-old African American man presents to the emergency department with severe retrosternal chest pain that started two hours ago. The pain radiates to his left arm and is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom. He describes the pain as squeezing in nature and rates it 8/10 in intensity. He tried sublingual nitroglycerin at home which did not alleviate the symptoms. He has had previous similar episodes of chest pain which were less severe and resolved with rest.  Relevant past medical history includes hypertension  dyslipidemia  and diabetes mellitus type 2  for which he takes lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin. He is an ex-smoker  quitting 10 years ago after a 30-year history of one pack per day. His father had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 55. The patient denies any use of illicit drugs  alcohol abuse  or recent trauma. His last routine checkup was a year ago.  Physical examination reveals an anxious  diaphoretic patient in obvious discomfort. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  pulse 105 bpm  respiratory rate 24/min  and temperature 36.8 °C. Heart sounds include normal first and second heart sounds with no murmurs. Breath sounds are vesicular. The abdomen is soft with no tenderness or distension. There are no peripheral oedema or neurological deficits. His BMI is 29  indicating overweight.  The EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads (V1-V4) suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.

A 62-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm that started 45 minutes ago  while he was lifting some heavy boxes in his garage. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. He describes the pain as unrelenting and the worst he has ever experienced.   Past medical history reveals hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago for which he took medication irregularly  type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 7 years ago  hyperlipidemia  and a 45 pack-year history of smoking. He has no known drug allergies. His family history is significant as his father died from myocardial infarction at 67 and his oldest brother had a coronary artery bypass grafting at 60.  He appears diaphoretic  pale  and in obvious distress. His blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals regular rhythm with no audible murmurs. Auscultation of lungs indicates clear breath sounds bilaterally. His ECG shows ST segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF  highly suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith. He works as an accountant and presents to the emergency department reporting severe substernal chest pain of crushing nature which started a couple of hours ago. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw. He describes the pain as 10 out of 10 in severity. He also complains of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  and a sense of impending doom.   Past Medical History:  His medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been taking medication (Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin). He reports a 30-year history of smoking  but quit 5 years ago. His father and uncle both had myocardial infarctions in their early sixties and his paternal grandfather died suddenly of an unknown cause at age 55. He lives alone but his family lives nearby  and he has a high-stress job. He enjoys moderate alcohol consumption but denies any illicit drug use.   The patient has no known drug allergies. His last visit to the doctor was 1 year back and at that time his blood pressure  blood glucose levels  and cholesterol levels were under control. He also reports compliance with medications. He got vaccinated against seasonal flu two months back. His diet is rich in meat and he admits he exercises rarely due to his busy schedule.

Patient Description: Mr. James Brown  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department complaining of a severe  pressure-like chest pain that started about two hours ago while he was eating breakfast. He indicates that the pain radiates to his left arm and jaw.   Past Medical History: Mr. Brown has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he is on Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively. He has been a heavy smoker for the last 40 years and admits to a daily consumption of alcohol.  Family History: He has a family history of ischemic heart disease; his father died of a heart attack at 67 years.  Presenting Symptoms: The pain is worse on exertion  does not relieve by rest  and is accompanied by symptoms of shortness of breath  excessive sweating  and nausea. He has never experienced such symptoms before.  Vital Signs: His blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg  pulse rate is 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  temperature is 37.0 °C and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air.  Based on his risk factors  presenting symptoms  and initial examination findings  a suspicion of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) is raised. An electrocardiogram (ECG) and cardiac biomarkers are immediately ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw. He reports that the pain began approximately 2 hours prior to presentation  while he was doing yard work.   He describes the pain as 10/10 in severity  with associated symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. The pain did not relieve with rest. The patient has a 30-pack-year smoking history  but quit 10 years ago; however  he admits to being non-compliant with his prescribed medications which include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin.  This is Mr. Johnson's first episode of chest pain. His father suffered a heart attack at the age of 70. Upon examination  the patient is in obvious distress with profuse sweating and appears pale. His blood pressure is elevated at 160/100 mmHg  pulse is 110 beats per minute  and respirations are 20 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals distant heart sounds.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Edwards is a 67-year old African-American male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year smoking history  currently a nonsmoker for the past 5 years. He has presented to the emergency department due to severe  crushing chest pain that started around 3 hours ago while he was performing yard work. The pain has not decreased with rest or nitroglycerin use at home.  The pain is centered in his chest and radiates down his left arm and up to his neck. It is described as heavy and pressing  rated as 8/10 in intensity  and is associated with shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a sense of impending doom. The chest pain is aggravated by physical exertion and partially relieved by rest and nitroglycerin administration.  Physical examination revealed that the patient appeared anxious  diaphoretic with pallor. Blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  heart rate was 95 beats per minute  respirations were 20 breaths per minute  and temperature was 98.6F (37°C). His BMI was calculated as 31  indicative of obesity.  Examination of the cardiovascular system revealed weak peripheral pulses  an irregularly irregular heart rhythm  and no audible murmurs. His lung exam was clear to auscultation bilaterally. The other systems were within normal range.   His medications include metformin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and occasional nitroglycerin for anginal episodes. Family history was equally significant for early cardiac disease  his father had a heart attack at age 62. He is married  a retired engineer  and lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. He denies any illicit drug use or alcohol consumption.      Further investigations  including an EKG and troponin levels  were immediately ordered which confirmed the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents himself to the Emergency Room with complaints of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  and jaw  accompanied by shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea for the past 2 hours. Patient describes the pain as a heavy  squeezing sensation in the middle of his chest. He denies any relief with rest. There is no recent history of trauma or injury.  Relevant Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension for which he is on Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years and consumes alcohol occasionally. Patient also mentions a family history of heart disease - his father died from a heart attack at age 70.  Subjective Summary:  The patient's shortness of breath and chest pain have limited his physical activity. He is nervous and visibly anxious. His vitals show a Blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  a irregular pulse rate of 100 beats/min  respirations of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. Given his clinical presentation and past medical history  the patient is suspected to have an acute myocardial infarction and immediate appropriate investigations are initiated.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room complaining about an ongoing severe chest pain constant in nature  radiating down his left arm and up to his left jaw  which began about 2 hours ago at rest. The pain is associated with feelings of shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  diaphoresis  and sense of impending doom. The patient rates the pain as 9/10.  The patient's risk factors include a history of uncontrolled hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He has been a smoker for 40 years  with a 30 pack-year history. No previous history of ischemic heart disease  although his father had a myocardial infarction at age 70. He is currently taking metformin for his diabetes  a thiazide diuretic for his hypertension  and a statin for his hyperlipidemia. No known drug allergies. He describes his stress levels as high  given recent events  and admits to not adhering to his prescribed diet modifications and exercise regime due to those stressors.  On examination  the patient is anxious and sweating. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 25 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation at 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with normal heart sounds  no murmur  or rub.  Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation consistent with a diagnosis of an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).  His labs  including CBC  are within normal limits except for significantly elevated Troponin levels  further indicating myocardial damage. Pre-hospital initiation of aspirin (chewable) was provided by EMS.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 57-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents to the emergency department with acute  severe  retrosternal chest pain which started one hour ago at rest. The pain is crushing in nature and radiates to his left arm and jaw. Associated symptoms include diaphoresis  nausea  and a feeling of impending doom. He rates the pain as a 10 on a scale of 10. The patient also mentions that he had experienced episodes of similar but less severe pain during the past week  which resolved with rest.  Mr. Smith is an active smoker with a 30 pack-year history and reports occasional alcohol intake. His father had a heart attack in his early 60s. The patient admits to non-compliance with his prescribed medication regimen  which includes metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. His vitals on presentation are as follows - blood pressure: 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate: 110/min  respiration: 22/min  and oxygen saturation: 95% on room air.   He appears to be in distress with noticeable pallor and diaphoresis. Physical examination reveals increased heart rate with normal rhythm  and no heart murmurs  gallop  or rub are noticed on cardiac auscultation. Breath sounds are equal bilaterally and no rales were heard on pulmonary auscultation. No peripheral edema is noted. His neurologic examination is within normal limits.  The patient’s chest x-ray reveals no signs of congestive heart failure. EKG shows ST-elevation in anterior leads. The blood investigation reveals a significant elevation in cardiac troponin levels.

Patient Presentation:   A 60-year-old caucasian male is brought to the emergency department with complaints of severe central chest pain that started 3 hours ago. The pain is described as constant  crushing in nature  radiating to his left shoulder and arm  and is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom. He has tried sublingual nitroglycerin at home which failed to relieve the pain.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  all of which are under good control on medications (Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin respectively). He was a regular smoker for 35 years (1 pack a day) but quit smoking five years ago. He reports moderate amounts of alcohol (~2-3 drinks per day). There is a family history of coronary artery disease  as his father had a heart attack at the age of 66. His cholesterol count from a routine health checkup a month ago revealed elevated levels.   Social History: Retired financial analyst. He lives with his wife. She monitors his diet given his diabetes status. His daily physical activity primarily consists of routine walks around the neighborhood but since the cold season started  his physical activity has been limited.  Medication History: He is on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidaemia. He occasionally takes over-the-counter antacids for heartburn and also uses sublingual nitroglycerin whenever he experiences chest discomfort. He has no known allergies.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 55-year-old Caucasian male presenting with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw since last two hours. The pain is accompanied by profuse sweating  shortness of breath  nausea  and a sense of impending doom. He rates his pain as 8 on the Numeric Pain Rating Scale. The pain is continuous and does not aggravate or alleviate with movement. He denies any recent trauma  exertional activity  meals  or emotional stress before the onset of pain.   Patient History:  Mr. Doe admits to a 30-year history of heavy cigarette smoking (1 pack/day). Having worked as a high-stress corporate lawyer for 20 years  he reports an unhealthy diet  sedentary lifestyle  and chronic high stress levels. His medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago  type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 7 years  and high cholesterol for the past decade. Mr. Doe verifies that he is compliant with his prescribed antihypertensive  oral hypoglycemic  and cholesterol-lowering medications.   There is no known drug allergy. He denied alcohol or illicit drug use. No history of transient ischemic attack  stroke  deep vein thrombosis  or pulmonary embolism. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. He lives with his wife and children  and there's no recent or chronic exposure to any environmental toxins.    Physical Examination:  On examination  he looks anxious and distressed. His vital signs show a pulse of 110 beats/min  blood pressure of 162/95 mmHg  a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per min  and O2 saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rhythm without any murmurs  rubs or gallops. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Given the patient's symptoms  medical history and physical examination  a working diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction is considered  and he is immediately sent for an ECG and cardiac markers for further evaluation.

Patient Presentation  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Smith  presents to the emergency department complaining of a dull  constant chest pain that started approximately 2 hours ago. The pain radiates to his left arm and is accompanied by shortness of breath  profuse sweating  nausea  and a sense of impending doom. Mr. Smith is a long-time chief executive officer with a history of stress  heavy smoking  unhealthy diet  and sedentary lifestyle.  Relevant Past Medical History  He has a past medical history of systemic hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus  both managed with medications for over ten years. He has a family history of coronary artery disease with his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.   Mr. Smith does not exercise on a regular basis and acknowledges a diet high in saturated fats. He smokes a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 30 years and occasionally consumes alcohol. He has no known drug allergies.   Current Medications  He is currently taking metformin 500mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10mg once daily and is on low-dose aspirin therapy.

Patient Profile: Mr. Jordan  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  comes to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with a sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  accompanied by sweating  shortness of breath  and mild nausea.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Jordan is a banker who experienced the onset of discomfort at work 40 minutes prior to arrival. He claims that he has never experienced a similar pain before  and resting did not alleviate the pain.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels  both of which have been controlled with medication (lisinopril 10 mg/day and atorvastatin 20 mg/day respectively). He is a current smoker with a 30 pack-year history and admits to a sedentary lifestyle and high-stress job.  Family History: There is a strong family history of cardiac disease  including a father who died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 50 and a mother with ischemic heart disease.  Review of Systems: Negative for fever or chills. Positive for diaphoresis and dizziness.   Current Medication: Lisinopril 10 mg/day and atorvastatin 20 mg/day.  Physical Examination: Patient appears diaphoretic and in severe distress. Vital signs: blood pressure 170/100 mm Hg  heart rate - 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate - 24 breaths/minute  temperature - 37 °C  oxygen saturation - 94% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia  no murmurs or gallops.  Investigations: The EKG reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Cardiac biomarkers are ordered.  Assessment: Based on this history and EKG  the patient is highly likely to be having an acute myocardial infarction. Further assessment and intervention are immediately needed.

Patient Information: Mr. Thomas Shaw  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker.  Chief Complaint: Severe  crushing chest pain that began about three hours ago  radiating to his left arm. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom. He denies having any associated nausea  palpitations or syncope.  Past Medical History: Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago.  Personal and Social History: Mr. Shaw is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history and has quit smoking 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol casually but denies any illicit drug use. He has a family history of early heart disease  with his father dying from an unrecognized heart attack at the age of 55.  Medications: Lisinopril 20mg once daily  Metformin 500mg twice daily.  Review of Systems: No recent fevers  chills  cough or unusual fatigue. No swelling in the legs or weight gain. Denies any headache  dizziness  or changes in vision.   Physical Examination: The patient appears in moderate distress. BP is 155/95 mmHg  HR is 102 bpm  RR is 20 breaths per minute  temperature is 98.7 F  and O2 saturation is 92% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with a regular rhythm but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulses are equal bilaterally. Lungs reveal diminished breath sounds at the bases but no crackles or wheezes. Extremities are cool and clammy but without edema.  Impression: The patient's presenting symptoms  along with his risk factors including age  history of hypertension  diabetes  and a strong family history of early heart disease  are concerning for an acute myocardial infarction. Urgent evaluation with EKG and cardiac enzyme studies is needed.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Baker  a 62-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department (ED). He is currently experiencing severe  crushing pain in the center of his chest that began approximately 2 hours prior. The pain is rated as a 9/10 on the pain scale  and it radiates to his left arm and jaw. He describes the pain as persistent and not relieved with rest. He additionally reports associated symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath.   He has a past medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 25-pack-year smoking history though quit 10 years ago. Mr. Baker also has family history significant for coronary artery disease - his father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. The patient is currently on a regimen of lisinopril  metoprolol  and rosuvastatin. He is allergic to shellfish.   On exam  he appears to be in physical distress with cool and clammy skin. His vital signs show a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Electrocardiography (ECG) revealed ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads – II  III  and aVF. These findings are suggestive of acute inferior wall myocardial infarction.   He was quickly started on aspirin  nitroglycerin  oxygen  and morphine for symptom relief. The team prepared him for immediate cardiac catheterization based on the ECG findings  patient’s symptoms  and the clinical suspicion of acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. X is a 60-year-old white male who came into the Emergency Department accompanied by his wife earlier this morning. He works as a truck driver and has a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for approximately 35 years. He was brought in for the sudden onset of severe chest pain that started about 5 hours ago.   The pain is described as crushing and radiating to his left arm and jaw. It was associated with nausea  sweating and shortness of breath. These symptoms persisted despite resting. There's no similar history before.   The patient has a pertinent history including hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago and hyperlipidemia diagnosed 5 years ago. He is currently taking medication for both - Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He does not have any known drug allergies.   Mr. X’s father experienced a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. He frequently consumes alcohol  drinks about 3-4 beers every evening after work. He has not been physically active and follows a high fat diet. He denies any illicit drug use.   On examination  Mr. X looks anxious and diaphoretic. His body mass index (BMI) is 30.4 which is consistent with obesity. His blood pressure reading is 170/100 mmHg and his heart rate is about 110 beats per minute.   Initial EKG showed ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  aVF indicative of an inferior wall MI. Troponin levels were also found to be elevated  confirming the diagnosis of Acute Myocardial Infarction. He was given aspirin  nitroglycerin  and was immediately sent for percutaneous coronary intervention.   He is due for strict monitoring  further testing  lifestyle modification counseling  and further treatment plan discussion.

A 59-year-old African American male  Mr. Smith  presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  worsening over 2 hours. He describes the pain as a ""heavy pressure."" Mr. Smith also reports associated shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea.  His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidaemia  for which he is on Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin  respectively. As a pack-a-day smoker for 20 years  he quit tobacco ten years ago. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. He has no known drug allergies. On social history  he is retired  lives with his wife  consumes alcohol occasionally  and does not use any illicit substances. He is adherent to his medication regimen.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is 165/90 mmHg  heart rate 100 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  temperature 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. He appears anxious and sweaty. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia without murmur  rub  or gallop. Chest examination shows clear breath sounds bilaterally.  Based on the history and physical examination findings  there is a high suspicion of acute myocardial infarction. He is given aspirin  nitroglycerin  oxygen  and morphine  and urgent electrocardiogram and cardiac markers are ordered.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 67-year-old African American male.  Chief Complaint: “I have been experiencing severe chest pain since morning.”  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith has been experiencing severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm  associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and cold sweats since morning. The pain is continuous and has been progressively increasing in intensity.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of coronary artery disease  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He had a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with two stent placements 7 years ago.  Surgical History: PCI with stent placement.  Family History: Both his father and elder brother had myocardial infarctions in their 60s.   Social History: Mr. Smith is a retired teacher  he quit smoking 10 years ago but has a significant 25 pack-year smoking history. He drinks alcohol socially. He does not exercise regularly.  Drug History: He's on medications including aspirin  a statin  a beta-blocker  and an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.  Vital Signs: Blood pressure 160/95 mmHg  heart rate 100 beats/minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air.  Physical exam: On examination  he appears diaphoretic and in distress. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with a regular rhythm and no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary examination is normal. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Upon evaluation  the working diagnosis is an acute myocardial infarction. Immediate cardiac monitoring  oxygen administration  and prompt treatment  possibly including reperfusion therapy  are warranted.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  is brought to the emergency department with severe chest pain that started around two hours ago. He describes the pain as a heavy pressure sensation in the center of his chest that radiates down his left arm. He also reports shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating. He denies any recent injuries  trauma  fever  cough  or difficulty swallowing.  Mr. Doe is a retired construction worker. He has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been prescribed medication  but admits to inconsistent adherence. He also has a 40-pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. His father had a heart attack at a similar age. The patient is on aspirin and atorvastatin for his chronic conditions.  Additional Assessment:  His vitals on arrival are - blood pressure: 150/90 mm Hg  heart rate: 105 bpm  respiratory rate: 25 bpm  temperature: 37°C  and oxygen saturation: 90% on room air. Physical examination reveals an anxious-looking man in obvious distress. Cardiac examination reveals negligible S3 gallop. Pulmonary and abdomen examination show no abnormalities. He has no peripheral edema. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF. Blood tests also show a rise in troponin levels.   Despite nitroglycerine administration  the patient's chest pain persists. The patient's symptoms  together with the ECG and troponin results  suggest a diagnosis of acute inferior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 65-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the emergency department with 8/10 substernal chest pain  described as pressure-like in nature  and radiating to her left arm. The pain started about 2 hours ago while she was gardening and persists despite resting. Associated symptoms include dyspnea  diaphoresis  and nausea. She denies having any similar episodes in the past.   Ms. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a 30-pack year history of smoking. Her medications include Lisinopril and Simvastatin. She has no known drug allergies. She lives alone and works as an office manager. She is the primary caregiver for her elderly mother.  Physical examination reveals diaphoresis and slightly labored breathing. Her blood pressure is 165/90 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22/min  and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The cardiovascular examination revealed regular tachycardia but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung examination showed no crackles or wheezes and her other systems were unremarkable.  ECGs and laboratory studies  including cardiac biomarkers  have been ordered to investigate further. Based on her presenting symptoms  past medical history  and current presentation  an acute myocardial infarction is highly likely.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and hyperlipidemia  who presents to the emergency department with severe substernal chest pain  characterized as pressure-like and radiating to the left arm. He also reports associated symptoms of diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and nausea. The chest pain started about 1 hour before presentation while he was rest at home. He's a 20-pack-a year smoker and has been non-compliant with his medications for the past couple of weeks. He has no known drug allergies. His mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67. He denies any surgical history. On examination  he appears sweaty and anxious  with an elevated pulse at 100 BPM and blood pressure of 165/95 mm Hg.  This synopsis provided raises the suspicion of an Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) due to his symptoms  risk factors including age  gender  smoking  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia and family history as well as the results of the preliminary exam. The next step would be immediate testing to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of heart damage.

Patient Presentation:   Mr.Johnson  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and up to the jaw. The pain started approximately two hours ago while he was doing yard work and has persisted. The patient rates the pain 9/10 in intensity. He also reported associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and feeling of impending doom.   Patient Demographics:   Mr. Johnson lives in downtown New York City. He is retired having worked as an engineer for over 30 years. He is a smoker with a 30-year pack history and has a moderate alcohol intake.  Relevant Past Medical History:  He has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled through medications. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and statin medications for several months now. His father died of a heart attack at an early age of 55. The patient has no known drug allergies. The patient also admits that he has been experiencing episodes of chest pain over the past several weeks after physical activities but did not seek any medical advice. His current symptoms are much worse than his previous episodes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the Emergency Department  accompanied by his wife. He has a chief complaint of severe  crushing chest pain that started two hours ago while he was mowing the lawn. The pain radiates to his left arm and is associated with diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. Mr. Doe rates his pain as a 9 out of 10.  DOB: 01/01/1957 Occupation: Retired engineer Marital Status: Married Insurance: Medicare  History of Present Illness:  Mr. Doe states that he started feeling ""an elephant on my chest"" while doing house chores two hours ago. He tried to rest  hoping the discomfort would go away  but the pain became worse accompanied by a cold sweat and feeling out of breath. He denied having a similar episode in the past.   Farther History:  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is known to have Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and Hyperlipidemia for the last 10 years. He underwent a coronary stent placement 5 years ago.   Past Surgical History: Appropriate to patient's known past medical history.  Current Medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin.   Social History: He quit tobacco twenty years ago and denies alcohol or recreational drug use. He is alarms at home with his wife and has 2 adult children living out of state. He is a Veteran and served two deployments in Vietnam.  Family History: His father had a history of myocardial infarction and died at the age of 70. His mother died of breast cancer at 68. His older brother is alive and has a history of stroke.   Review of systems: Unable to complete due to acute presentation.

A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with intense  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw which started approximately two hours ago. He describes the pain as being ""like an elephant sitting on my chest"". The pain is also accompanied by shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  and profuse sweating.   Prior to this episode  he had experienced episodes of chest discomfort while climbing stairs which would subside with rest. He did not seek medical attention assuming them to be signs of aging. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years  consuming about a half-pack per day. He has a known medical history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes metformin and amlodipine regularly.  His family history reveals that his father passed from a heart attack at the age of 67. He works as a bus driver  is married  and lives with his wife who reports his recent mood has been increasingly anxious and irritable.  He does not consume alcohol and has no known drug allergies. He denies any recent travel or changes in his diet. His last normal meal was dinner the preceding night. Admits to not adhering to a regular exercise or diet regimen due to the nature of his job.   This patient's symptoms  risk factors  and history are concerning for acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Anderson  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of chest pain that started 90 minutes ago. He describes it as a severe  crushing pain in the center of his chest that radiates down his left arm and up into his jaw. He rates the pain as 10/10 and states it is unlike anything he has ever experienced before. He also reports associated symptoms of severe shortness of breath  nausea  profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom.   He has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  for which he is on medication (Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Metformin respectively). Additionally  he has a 40-year pack history of smoking and only quit recently  about a year ago. Mr. Anderson’s father had died from a heart attack at the age of 59. He has worked in a stressful job as a stockbroker for 30 years and has limited physical activity. He mentions that he has been non-compliant with his medications for the past one week due to financial issues.  On examination  he appears pale  sweaty  and in obvious distress. He is tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.  The above presentation is consistent with an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old African-American male with a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypercholesterolemia  and hypertension  was brought in by his son complaining of a sudden onset  severe  retrosternal chest discomfort radiating to his left arm for the past 4 hours. The patient describes the pain as crushing in nature  not relieved by rest or glyceryl trinitrate that he takes for his chronic stable angina. Over the course of the pain  he also developed sweating  shortness of breath  and a feeling of impending doom. The patient also mentioned 3 weeks ago he had atypical chest pain during the exertion that was eased by rest.  On examination  the patient appeared pale and sweaty. His blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg and heart rate was 110 beats per minute on presentation. Heart examination revealed faint heart sounds with no additional heart sounds or murmur. The chest was clear on auscultation and the abdomen was soft and non-tender.  Past medical and surgical history include Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago  hypercholesterolemia diagnosed 8 years ago  hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago  and a bilateral hernia repair 15 years back. He has been a smoker of 20 cigarettes a day for 40 years. He doesn't drink alcohol. The patient is on Metformin  Atorvastatin  and Lisinopril which he has been taking regularly.

Patient: Mr. John Smith  62-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of a severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and neck  accompanied by shortness of breath  profuse sweating and a sense of impending doom. He indicates the pain began suddenly while he was mowing the lawn about an hour ago and has not subsided despite rest.  Medical history: He has a documented history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he takes Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Metformin accordingly. He reports being a smoker of 25 years but quit 5 years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol occasionally and to a sedentary lifestyle. Family history includes his father dying from a heart attack at age 57.  Medication: Lisinopril 10mg daily  Atorvastatin 40mg at night  Metformin 1000mg twice daily  Allergies: No known drug allergies  Social History: Mr. Smith is a retired machinist  lives with his wife  and they have 3 adult children. He has been a non-smoker for the past 5 years  drinks alcohol socially  and admits to poor dietary habits and lack of regular exercise.  On physical examination: The patient appears acutely distressed  diaphoretic  and pale. Blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg  pulse 90 beats/min  temp 97.5°F (36.4°C)  respiratory rate 18 per minute. On auscultation  heart sounds S1 and S2 are normal. There are no audible murmurs. Chest and lungs are clear to percussion and auscultation. Abdomen is soft  non-tender with normal bowel sounds. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   Trace elements of troponin were found in the bloodstream  along with an EKG displaying ST-segment elevation indicate an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe is a 52-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and arm  associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis (excessive sweating) and nausea. The chest pain is non-pleuritic and is not affected by respiration or movement  which lasted about 20 minutes. The pain description is consistent with class IV on the Canadian Cardiovascular Society angina grading scale. He rates the pain as 8 out of 10.   He has no known allergies. He smokes a half-pack of cigarettes daily since 20 years and endorses moderate regular alcohol use. No illicit drug use is marked.   Relevant past medical history includes hypertension  which has been managed with Lisinopril  and Type-2 diabetes mellitus managed with Metformin for the past six years. His father had coronary artery disease and died at the age of 55 from a myocardial infarction.   Mr. Doe's vital signs are stable  but he appears pale and in distress. His EKG reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior precordial leads  suggestive of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.   In essence  this patient's history  age  race  gender  family history  personal history of smoking and the associated risk factors such as diabetes and hypertension are all consistent with a high suspicion for an acute myocardial infarction.   Further diagnostics to include lab testing for cardiac enzymes  confirmation of EKG results and course of action with respect of possible PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention) need to be taken into consideration immediately.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American male named John Doe presented to the ED with his wife.  Chief Complaint: “Severe chest pain for the last hour.""  History of Present Illness: The patient describes the pain as a ""heavy pressure"" sensation centralized in the chest  stating it radiated to his jaw and left arm. He notes that it started while he was mowing his lawn and did not subside with rest. This pain is associated with shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. Denies any significant relief with 81mg of chewed aspirin taken at home.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and quit 10 years ago. One year ago  he was diagnosed with stable angina and has been on long-acting nitrates and beta-blockers. He admits nonadherence to his diet  exercise  and medication regimen over the past month.  Medications: lisinopril  metformin  atorvastatin  nitroglycerin (as needed)  and metoprolol.  Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack at the age of 68 years.  Social History: The patient is a retired engineer. Denies alcohol usage  illicit drug use. Reports a stressful life in the past few weeks due to personal reasons.  Review of Systems: Negative except as detailed in HPI.   Physical Exam: General: Patient is conscious  oriented but looks acutely ill and anxious. Vital Signs: BP - 150/90 mm Hg  HR - 110 bpm  Temp - 98.6 F  RR - 22/min  SpO2 - 94% on room air. CVS: S1 and S2 audible  no murmurs or rubs noted RS: Clear breath sounds bilaterally with no wheezing or crackles. Other systems are unremarkable.  Based on the clinical presentation  notably including chest pain with characteristic radiation  associated symptoms  and relevant past medical history  the preliminary diagnosis of Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) is considered. ECG has been ordered immediately and the patient has been given sublingual nitroglycerin in the ED. Preparations for fibrinolytic therapy or percutaneous coronary intervention as per protocol and further cardiac monitoring are underway.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Smith  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presents in the emergency department complaining of chest pain of acute onset. He describes the pain as substernal  pressure-like  associated with diaphoresis and shortness of breath. The pain started about an hour ago while he was mowing his lawn  a normally routine activity. Currently  the pain radiates from his chest to his left arm and jaw. The pain does not change with movement or respiration.   Past Medical History: The patient has a ten-year medical history of type II diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  all of which have been managed with metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin respectively. Mr. Smith is known to be a pack-a-day smoker for the past 30 years and has been attempting to quit but has not been successful. He admits to drinking alcohol occasionally. His father had a heart attack at the same age. Last annual physical checkup was 9 months ago and was unremarkable.   Family History: His family history is relevant for premature heart disease; his father suffered a heart attack at the age of 58 years  and his mother has hypertension.   Social History: He is married with two adult children. Before retirement  he was working as a manager in a corporate firm. He is a current smoker and drinks alcohol socially. He denies any illicit drug use. He is not on any regular exercise regimen  and his diet is high in red meats and processed foods.   Current Medications: Metformin 1000mg BID (Type-II Diabetes)   Lisinopril 10mg daily (Hypertension)   Atorvastatin 40mg daily (Hyperlipidemia).

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 60-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with ongoing central chest pain. The patient was having dinner when the pain began approximately 1 hour ago. He describes it as a heavy  pressing pain that has not eased. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw. He also mentions accompanying symptoms of sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath. He rates his pain as 8 on a scale of 10.   Mr. Smith is a known case of type 2 diabetes and hypertension for which he has been taking Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively. The patient has a 20-pack year history of smoking though he quit smoking 5 years ago. His father had a history of coronary artery disease. He denies alcohol or drug use. He is currently retired and lives with his wife.  Vital signs on admission: Blood Pressure - 150/90 mm Hg  Heart rate - 95/minute  Respiratory rate - 20/minute  and SpO2 - 94% on room air.   Based on his symptoms and past medical history  acute myocardial infarction is suspected.

Patient Presentation:   John Doe  a 67-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency room complaint of sudden onset chest pain that has persisted for the last two hours. The patient describes it as a heavy  central chest pain radiating down his left arm with associated shortness of breath  diaphoresis and feeling of impending doom. There is no associated nausea  vomiting or loss of consciousness. He rates the pain as 9/10 on the pain scale.  In regard to his medical history  Mr. Doe has a 20-year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  with poor adherence to medications. He also is a current smoker with a 40 pack-year history. He has no history of heart diseases in the past. He stopped regular physical exercise a decade ago. In relation to his family history  his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 56. On examination  he appears anxious  diaphoretic  and in respiratory distress. His blood pressure is 170/95 mmHg  pulse - 90 bpm  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air.   Initial EKG shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads indicative of an acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction. Serum troponin levels are pending. He has been administered sublingual nitroglycerin  aspirin and attempted pain control with no relief.   Given the presentation and initial findings  the patient is diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction and the Cardiology team is notified for further management and likely cardiac catheterization.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Jones is a 65-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. He reports the pain started while he was mowing his lawn about 2 hours ago and has progressively worsened  rating it a 9 out of 10. He describes the pain as ""like an elephant is sitting on my chest"". He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with these 15 years ago and is on a regimen of metformin and lisinopril. He has no known drug allergies  but has a tobacco use history of 20 pack years  though he quit 10 years ago. He also has a family history of early heart disease  with his father dying of a heart attack at age 60.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he appears diaphoretic and in distress. His vital signs show a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Heart sounds include a regular rhythm  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung exam reveals clear bilateral breath sounds. The remainder of his physical exam is unremarkable.   Mr. Jones's past history and current symptoms point towards a possible diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction.

A 65-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  ongoing for the past 3 hours. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia. He reports that he is a current smoker with a 40-year smoking history of 1 pack per day. There is a family history of ischemic heart disease in his father  who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. He is currently on medication  taking metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin. He also reports feelings of severe sweating  restlessness  and a recent episode of vomiting. He has no known drug allergies. Triage vital signs show blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg and a heart rate of 115 bpm. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads and cardiac enzymes report is pending. The patient’s symptoms along with the preliminary findings from the ECG are consistent with an acute myocardial infarction.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction: A Clinical Case Study   Slide 1: Introduction  - Brief about Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI)  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - Subject: A 57-year-old Caucasian male  - Occupation: Truck driver - Lifestyle: Regular smoker for the past 30 years  moderate alcohol consumption  sedentary lifestyle  Slide 3: Presenting Complaint  - The patient presented with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  dyspnea  nausea  vomiting  profuse sweating  and faintness.  Slide 4: Past Medical History   - Diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the last ten years. - Family history of cardiovascular diseases - the father had a heart attack at the age of 64. - Noncompliance with prescribed medications (anti-hypertensive and anti-diabetic drugs). - Regular checkups indicated moderate control of blood pressure and blood sugar levels.  Slide 5: Physical Examination   - Vital signs: BP - 160/90 mmHg  Pulse - 100 beats/min  irregular  Respiratory rate - 24 breaths/min  Temp: 98.6F - Pale  diaphoretic  and appears anxious - Cardiovascular exam: High pitched  blowing  grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard at the left sternal border. - Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. - Neurological exam: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score: 15/15 - Abdominal Exam: Soft  nondistended  nontender  Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests    - ECG findings: ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  - Lab tests: Elevated cardiac enzymes (Troponin & CK-MB)  Slide 7: Diagnosis  - Acute inferior wall Myocardial Infarction - Risk factors: Age  gender  smoking  sedentary lifestyle  non-compliance with medication  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  family history  Slide 8: Treatment Plan  - Immediate: Morphine for pain relief  oxygen therapy  Aspirin  and Clopidogrel for antiplatelet aggregation  Heparin as an anticoagulant. - Subsequent: Primary Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and Coronary angiography. - Long-Term: Lifestyle modifications (smoking cessation  healthy diet  regular exercise)  medication compliance  and regular follow-up.  Slide 9: Conclusion  - Importance of early detection and adherence to medication in chronic conditions to avoid severe events like AMI. - Highlighting the role of lifestyle modifications in cardiovascular diseases prevention.  Slide 10: Questions & Discussion  - Encourage the audience to ask questions or share related experiences.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction - A Case Study  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - Patient: Mr. John Doe - Age: 52 years old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Lawyer - Lifestyle: Sedentary with high-stress levels - Residence: Urban environment  Slide 3: Past Medical History  - History of Hypertension: Diagnosed 8 years ago  is on antihypertensive medication. - High cholesterol levels: Diagnosed 5 years ago  taking statins irregularly. - No history of diabetes or thyroid disorders. - Father died of a heart attack at 58  mother has type 2 diabetes. - Previous smoker  quit 2 years ago. - Takes aspirin irregularly and reported difficulty with adhering to prescribed medication schedule.  Slide 4: Presentation   - Chief Complaint: Crushing chest pain radiating to left arm  occurring over the past 3 hours  associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis.  Slide 5: Initial Evaluation  - Vital signs: Blood pressure 160/100 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respirations 22/min  temperature 98.4°F (36.9°C)  O2 saturation 96% on room air. - Physical examination: Pallor  cold sweats  looks anxious.  Slide 6: Investigations  - ECG: Shows ST-segment elevation on anterior leads consistent with acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. - Troponin levels: Significantly elevated.  Slide 7: Diagnosis  - Based on clinical examination  ECG findings  and elevated cardiac enzymes  the patient was diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction.  Slide 8: Management  Therapeutic intervention included: - Immediate Initiation of aspirin  nitroglycerin  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and statins. - Urgent coronary angiography showed significant stenosis in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. - The patient underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement in the LAD artery.   Slide 9: Post-Intervention Management  The patient was closely monitored in the cardiac care unit  with plans for a rehabilitation program and further management of risk factors including medication adherence and lifestyle modification counseling.  Slide 10: Conclusion  This case illustrates the typical presentation of an acute myocardial infarction  the significance of quick diagnosis & treatment  and the importance of addressing underlying risk factors for coronary artery disease.

Slide 1: Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction Case Presentation  Slide 2: Patient Demographics: Gender: Male Age: 65 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired construction worker Location: Rural Ohio  Slide 3: Past Medical History: - Hypertension diagnosis for last 15 years - Type II Diabetes diagnosis since 2005 - History of smoking for about 40 years (1 pack/day) - No known previous incidences of cardiovascular disease - Family history reveals father passed away due to myocardial infarction at 73   Slide 4: Presenting Complaint: - Patient arrived at ER presenting severe chest pain for past 3 hours - Pain radiates to the left arm and neck - Accompanied by shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea  Slide 5: Physical Examination Findings: - BP: 170/90 mmHg - Pulse: 98 bpm - Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per min - Oxygen saturation: 92% in room air - Chest: clear to auscultation - Cardiovascular: irregular heartbeat found on auscultation  Slide 6:  Diagnostic Tests: - ECG: Shows significant ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads - Cardiac panel: Troponin levels are elevated  Slide 7: Diagnosis and Management: - Diagnosis: Acute myocardial infarction  - Immediate Treatment: Aspirin  nitroglycerin  and oxygen therapy started - Refer to consultation with cardiology team for further management including possible thrombolysis or percutaneous coronary intervention.
