Slide 1: Introduction  Today  we're going to walk through the case of a patient who has recently experienced an Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) - a term synonymous with a heart attack. Case presentations can aid in understanding and prognosis of the disease.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith. He works as an engineer and leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle. He is a smoker and has a history of alcohol consumption.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mr. Smith was previously diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. Both conditions have been somewhat controlled with medication. Despite advice  he hadn't made significant lifestyle modifications. He has a familial history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having suffered a stroke at age 60.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaint  Mr. Smith woke up in the middle of the night experiencing severe chest pain. He described it as a pressure-type pain radiating to his left arm. Accompanying symptoms included shortness of breath  feeling of impending doom  and sweating.  Slide 5: Examination and Investigation   Upon examination  the patient appeared pale and sweaty. His initial blood pressure was 165/95 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Blood tests were significant for elevated troponin levels. Further assessment through an EKG confirmed ST-segment elevation  indicating a myocardial infarction.  Slide 6: Diagnosis  Based on the EKG results  symptoms  and blood work  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with an Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI).  Slide 7: Management and Follow-up  Mr. Smith was given emergency reperfusion therapy with angioplasty to restore the blood flow to the heart muscles. He was started on antiplatelet drugs  statins  nitrates  and angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors as long-term medications. He was also enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program for lifestyle modifications.  Slide 8: Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of risk factor identification  prompt diagnosis  and appropriate management for patients with Acute Myocardial Infarction. Lifestyle modifications  medication compliance  and follow-up are key elements in preventing recurrent heart attacks and improving prognosis.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) Case Study Sub-title: An Integrative Approach to Cardiac Emergency Care   Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - Gender: Male  - Age: 67 years old - Ethnicity: Asian  - Occupation: Retired engineer  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Hypertension for 10 years  - Type II diabetes mellitus for 7 years - History of smoking - Quit 5 years ago - No known drug allergies - Family history of heart disease.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints The patient was brought to the emergency department with sudden chest pain radiating to the left arm  severe sweating  shortness of breath  and lightheadedness.  Slide 5: Clinical Examination  Observed signs: - Pallor and cold sweat - Respiratory distress - Auscultation: rapid  irregular pulse   Slide 6: Diagnosis Based on the symptoms presented  a rapid ECG was done which confirmed ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).  Slide 7: Initial Treatment  - Immediate admission to cardiac intensive care unit. - Intravenous nitroglycerin for immediate pain relief. - Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel) and anticoagulation (enoxaparin). - The patient was also started on a beta-blocker (metoprolol) to reduce the demand on the Heart.  Slide 8: Further Management - Primary Coronary Intervention On confirmation of STEMI on ECG  primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was planned and performed successfully to relieve the obstruction in the coronary artery.  Slide 9: Follow-up and Rehabilitation - Regular cardiac rehabilitation sessions to help the patient recover and prevent future heart problems. - Optimized medication for co-morbidities (hypertension  diabetes). - The importance of lifestyle modifications emphasized: balanced diet  regular exercise  maintaining a healthy weight  and continued abstinence from smoking.  Slide 10: Conclusion This case emphasizes the importance of rapid diagnosis and intervention in acute myocardial infarction cases to improve patient outcomes  as well as effective management of the patient's comorbidities and adherence to a healthier lifestyle to prevent future cardiac events.  Slide 11: Questions & Discussion This slide is an open invitation for participants to ask questions  share their thoughts  experiences  and best practices concerning the diagnosis  treatment  and management of acute myocardial infarction.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction: A Case Presentation   Slide 1: Introduction  An overview of acute myocardial infarction (AMI)  often referred to as a heart attack  which presents as the interruption of blood supply to a part of the heart  causing heart cells to die.  Slide 2: Patient Introduction Our subject is Mr. James Rogers  a 65-year-old African-American male  retired  with a history of hypertension and type II diabetes. He's a former smoker (1 pack/day for 30 years) and has a family history of coronary heart disease.  Slide 3: Medical History Mr. Rogers has been managing his hypertension and diabetes with oral medications for 10 years. Both conditions have been relatively well-controlled. His last HbA1c reading  six months ago  was 7.2%. He quit smoking 5 years ago. The patient also suffers from hyperlipidemia.  Slide 4: Current Presentation Mr. Rogers arrived at the Emergency Room complaining of acute  severe chest pain radiating to his left upper limb  along with thoughts of impending doom. He also experienced shortness of breath and light-headedness. The initial date of symptom onset was about 4 hours prior to hospital arrival.  Slide 5: Physical Examination  On examination  he appears pale and diaphoretic. His blood pressure readings show 150/95 mmHg  pulse rate 105 beats/min  respiration rate 22 breaths/min  temperature 37.1°C  and oxygen saturation at 92%.  Slide 6: Investigations Investigative results indicate elevated cardiac enzymes (Troponin T and CK-MB). Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows st-segment elevation in the anterior leads  suggestive of an anterior myocardial infarction.  Slide 7: Initial Diagnosis The preliminary diagnosis is acute anterior-wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)  based on his symptomology  medical history  physical examination findings  and ECG changes.  Slide 8: Treatment & Management  Mr. Rogers is given aspirin  clopidogrel  and heparin as preliminary measures. Immediate revascularization via Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) is decided upon. Prescription also includes antihypertensives  statins  and management for diabetes.  Slide 9: Follow-Up Regular follow-up with cardiology is scheduled  and the patient is advised to maintain a diet low in sodium  fat and refined carbohydrates; increase physical activity; and undergo regular screening for his existing comorbidities.  Slide 10: Conclusion  This case scenario emphasizes the importance of prompt recognition and timely treatment of acute myocardial infarction  as well as the critical nature of managing underlying risk factors.

Slide 1:  - Title: Case Study – Acute Myocardial Infarction  Slide 2:  - Title: Patient Demographics  - Details:      - Gender: Male     - Age: 64     - Race: Caucasian     - Occupation: Accountant  Slide 3: - Title: Past Medical History - Details:     - Non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus      - Hypertension     - High cholesterol     - Consumes alcohol moderately      - Smoker for the past 40 years     - Sedentary lifestyle  Slide 4:  - Title: Recent Health Issue  - Details:      - Visited the emergency room  complaining about a sudden onset of severe chest pain     - Symptoms include nausea  shortness of breath  and profuse sweating  Slide 5:  - Title: Clinical Examination & Diagnosis - Details:      - Clinical examination including ECG and blood tests for markers of heart damage     - Chest pain was determined to be angina pectoris  leading to the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction  Slide 6:  - Title: Management & Advice  - Details:      - Immediate initiation of treatment including oxygen  nitroglycerin  aspirin  and beta-blockers     - Recommendation for angiography and potential angioplasty or coronary artery bypass grafting     - Lifestyle counseling including cessation of smoking  regular exercise  and a healthier diet  Slide 7: - Title: Future Considerations - Details:      - Regular check-ups to monitor heart condition      - Consistent medication for diabetes  hypertension  and cholesterol      - Monitor and manage stress levels to avoid another heart attack.  Slide 8:  - Title: Conclusion - Details:      - Given the patient's demographic and medical history  he was at a higher risk for an MI. Prompt recognition and swift intervention were crucial in preventing further damage to the heart muscles and potentially saving the patient's life. Continued management and lifestyle modifications are necessary for preventing a recurrent episode.

Patient Profile: A 64-year-old Hispanic male  Presenting Problem: Patient presents to the Emergency Department with acute chest pain.  History of Present Illness: The patient started experiencing severe  crushing chest pain two hours ago while he was at rest. The pain has been persistent since then  radiating to his left arm and neck. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  cold sweats  nausea  and light-headedness. He denies any recent physical exertion  emotional stress or drug usage. He had a similar episode of chest pain a month ago  which resolved on its own.  Medical History: Known case of Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension for the past 12 years  well-controlled with medication. He quit smoking five years ago but has a 30 pack-year smoking history.  Physical Examination on Presentation: Patient appears sweaty and pale. Vital signs show blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiovascular exam reveals regular rate and rhythm without murmurs or gallops. Pulmonary exam reveals clear lung fields.   Impression: The patient's symptoms of crushing chest pain  radiation to the left arm  associated shortness of breath  along with his risk factors (type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and significant smoking history) are highly suspicious for acute myocardial infarction. Immediate cardiac biomarkers assessment and ECG are warranted. The patient requires urgent management to reestablish coronary blood flow and to treat symptoms. This may involve medications  oxygen therapy  nitroglycerin  and discussions about invasive strategies like angioplasty or bypass surgery. This will highly depend upon the assessment of the patient's hemodynamic condition  the ECG findings  the biomarker results  and the potential benefits and risks.

Problem Representation:  Patient: Mr. James Ryan  59-year-old African-American male.  Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled well with medications. The patient is a current smoker with 30-pack years of smoking history  and has a family history of coronary artery disease with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  Presenting signs and symptoms: The patient presented with severe chest pain of sudden onset radiating to the left arm and jaw  associated with profuse sweating and breathlessness. The chest pain was continuous  pressure-like  and persisted for more than 30 minutes before seeking medical attention. The patient also reported feeling light-headed with noted pallor.  Conclusion: Taking into account his age  ethnicity  sex  medical history of hypertension  diabetes  current smoking status  and family history of coronary artery disease  combined with typical symptoms  Mr. Ryan is at significant risk for acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Immediate cardiological evaluation and potential intervention is warranted to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  crushing chest pain that radiated to his left arm and jaw. It started suddenly about 2 hours ago and is associated with shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom.   Patient History: He is a former smoker  quit 10 years back after a smoking history of 30 pack-years. His father had an MI at age 60. He is on regular medication with metformin for diabetes  losartan for hypertension  and atorvastatin for his high cholesterol.   Clinical Examination: On examination  he appears anxious and distressed  vital signs show blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate is 110 bpm  temperature is 98.6 F  respiratory rate is 22 per minute  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia  no murmurs heard. Lungs are clear  and the rest of his physical exam is unremarkable.  Preliminary Diagnosis: The patient's history  symptoms  and risk factors are suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction (AMI).

A 62-year-old Caucasian male  a former smoker with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type-2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of heart disease  presents with acute central chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain started about 2 hours before presenting to the emergency department  described as severe  crushing in nature  and associated with profuse sweating and difficulty in catching his breath. The patient also reports nausea  lightheadedness  and a feeling of impending doom. He has no known drug allergies and takes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin as daily medications. The patient has no prior episodes of similar symptoms. On presentation  his blood pressure is 180/95 mm Hg  pulse is 107 beats/min  respiratory rate is 22 breaths/min  and temperature is 37.1°C. The severity and duration of the symptoms  along with his risk factors  raise concerns for a possible acute myocardial infarction.

Demographics: A 62-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: He has a significant past medical history for hypertension  type II diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year smoking history. No known prior personal or family history of cardiac events is present.  Presentation: The patient presents to the emergency department with a 5-hour history of severe  central chest pain  described as a crushing sensation radiating to the left arm. Associated symptoms include dyspnea  diaphoresis  and nausea. He denied any history of trauma or injury. He has no recent history of infection  travel  or other illnesses.  Workup: Preliminary examination reveals that the patient is obese with a BMI of 32 and in moderate distress. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 150/95mm Hg  heart rate of 100 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. An emergent electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals ST-segment elevations in the inferior leads  suggestive of an ongoing inferior wall myocardial infarction. Blood investigations revealed raised cardiac enzymes.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  heavy smoker with a past medical history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus. He presents to the Emergency Department complaining of severe  abrupt onset chest pain radiating to left arm for the past two hours. Patient describes pain as crushing  central  and worsening. Associated symptoms include profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and dizziness. No reported nausea  vomiting or history of similar episodes.

Patient is a 62-year-old male  recent smoker with a medical history significant for hypertension and high cholesterol. He presents with sudden onset of severe central chest pain radiating to the left arm that started 1 hour ago while he was at rest  associated with shortness of breath  profuse sweating and nausea. He rates the pain as a 9 on a 10-point scale and describes it as a pressing sensation. The pain is constant and is not relieved by nitroglycerin. EKG on admission revealed ST-segment elevation in leads V1 to V4. Troponin levels were elevated. He described his father having a “heart problem” at a similar age. He is currently alert and oriented but appears distressed due to pain. He denies having similar chest pain before. The patient denies current use of alcohol or illicit substances. He is retired  lives with his wife  and is socially active. He has no known allergies and is currently on atorvastatin and lisinopril for his hypertension and high cholesterol.

Patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a previous medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  who presents with sudden severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw for approximately 3 hours. He describes the pain as a crushing sensation. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. There is a significant family history of heart disease  his father having had a heart attack at the age of 65. He is a past smoker with 30-year smoking history but claimed to have quit 10 years ago. He denied any alcohol or illicit drug use. On examination  he is diaphoretic  appears anxious  and in obvious distress. His pulse is irregular and rapid  his blood pressure is moderately high. The EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads V1-V4 indicating an anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for Type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension. He presents with severe  crushing chest pain of sudden onset that radiates to his left arm and jaw  associated with shortness of breath  sweating and nausea. The pain started approximately 3 hours ago and has not been relieved by rest. Patient has no known allergies. A review of systems is significant for intermittent episodes of chest discomfort during physical exertion over the last 6 months. Patient has been a smoker for the past 40 years and consumes alcohol occasionally. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease with his father dying from a myocardial infarction at age 70. Patient's current medications are Metformin  Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. The review of systems is negative for fever  cough  or gastrointestinal symptoms. No recent changes in exercise or dietary habits are noted. On physical examination  he appears in distress. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg  pulse 110 beats/min  respirations 22 breaths/min  temperature 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit  and oxygen saturation 93% on room air. His cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with normal S1 and S2  no murmurs. Pulmonary exam is clear to auscultation bilaterally. EKG shows significant ST-segment elevations in the anterior lead  consistent with an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient Description: A 65-year-old male  retired truck driver.  Past Medical History: Longstanding history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both controlled with medications. Smoker for the past 40 years.  Presenting problem: The patient comes in with a complaint of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  which began two hours prior to arrival at the ER. The pain started while he was lifting boxes and gradually intensified. He also reports feeling suddenly cold  sweaty  and nauseous with shortness of breath.  Pertinent positives: Severe chest pain  radiating pain to left arm and the jaw  dyspnea  diaphoresis  nausea  hypertension  long-term tobacco use  type 2 diabetes  exertion-triggered symptom onset.  Pertinent negatives: No known drug allergies  no previous history of similar chest pain  no previous episodes of heart failure or angina  denies loss of consciousness or recent head injury.  This patient's complaints and cardiovascular risk factors suggest the diagnosis of an acute myocardial infarction. Prompt evaluation with an electrocardiogram and cardiac enzyme testing  as well as emergent consultation with cardiology  is necessary for establishing the diagnosis and initiating immediate treatment.

A 58 year-old Caucasian male  former smoker with a 10-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with new onset chest pain of 2 hours duration. The chest pain is described as severe  crushing in nature  located in the central chest  radiating to the left arm and jaw  with associated profuse sweating and dyspnea. He has no known allergies. Family history is significant for early heart disease  with a father who suffered a myocardial infarction at age 54. His current medications are lisinopril and atorvastatin. The patient has no prior history of angina or cardiovascular disease. Physical examination reveals a diaphoretic and cachectic male in severe distress  with a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals no discernible murmurs  clicks  or rubs. Pulmonary auscultation reveals clear bilateral lung fields. Electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads (V1-V4).

A 65-year-old African American male  known hypertensive and diabetic  presented with abrupt onset severe chest pain  described as 'squeezing' in nature  spreading to the left shoulder. It persisted for around 45 minutes  accompanied by profuse sweating and nausea. The pain started while he was at rest. He has a history of smoking for the past 35 years. There is no known family history of coronary artery disease. He denied any history of similar episodes in the past and was not currently on any type of anti-platelets or statins. Upon initial evaluation  signs of distress  pallor  and a rapid pulse were noted. The patient's blood pressure on presentation was 160/90 mmHg.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American male  Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been a 2-pack/day smoker for the past 30 years.  Current Clinical Presentation: The patient presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of sudden onset  severe chest pain that started 1 hour ago. The pain is described as crushing  in the center of the chest  radiating to the left arm and jaw. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  profuse sweating  nausea and vomiting. On physical examination  he is diaphoretic  looks pale and is in obvious distress. His blood pressure upon presentation is 150/95 mmHg  pulse is 100 beats per minute  respirations are 20 breaths per minute  and he is afebrile.   This clinical picture is highly suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction. Further investigation including an ECG  cardiac biomarkers and possibly a cardiac catheterization are warranted to confirm this diagnosis and guide treatment.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Hispanic male   Medical History: Known hypertensive for the past 10 years  smoker for the past 30 years  positive for familial heart disease.   Presenting Complaints: The patient came in with complaints of severe  squeezing chest pain radiating to left shoulder and jaw  which started at rest an hour ago. The pain was also associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. No recent history of fever  cough  or weight loss.  Clinical Evaluation: The patient appeared to be in acute distress  with a cold and sweaty complexion. Blood pressure recorded was 160/100 mmHg and pulse was 90 beats per minute  regular but weak. No other significant findings were noted on the systemic examination.  Provisional Diagnosis: The clinical history and presentation are highly suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction.

A 59-year-old Caucasian male  with a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack year smoking history presents with sudden onset  severe  central chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. The pain started while he was in the gym working out  is associated with diaphoresis  nausea and shortness of breath. The patient's father had a history of coronary artery disease in his late fifties. The patient is non-compliant with his hypertensive medication and statin. His vitals on presentation indicate tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. His ECG shows ST segment elevation in anterior leads  suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 64-year-old male presenting with acute myocardial infarction. He has a significant medical history for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He reports sudden onset of severe central chest pain  which radiates to his left arm and more pain with breathing. He also reports associated symptoms of sweating  shortness of breath  and feelings of impending doom. He has a significant smoking history of 20 pack-years and his father had a myocardial infarction at age 62.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  Male  62-year-old  African American  Businessman  Presenting Problem: Intense chest pain  Medical History: Known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia. BMI of 32. Ex-smoker. No known drug allergies. Family history of coronary heart disease (Father had myocardial infarction at age 66).  Presenting Symptoms: The patient was reportedly gardening when he suddenly felt a severe  crushing pain in the center of his chest  describing it as ""like something is pressing down"". Pain radiates to his left arm. Accompanying symptoms include sweating  shortness of breath  lightheadedness and unusual fatigue. Symptoms have lasted for more than 1 hour. No relief seen even after taking rest.  Physical Exam: The patient looks anxious  his blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse is 105 bpm and regular  respirations are 18 per minute  oxygen saturations are 94% on room air. Chest is clear and heart sounds are muffled. No murmurs. His extremities are cold and slightly sweaty.   ECG shows ST elevation in anterior leads  suggestive of acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.  Impression: This 62-year-old man with a past medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia presents with typical severe retrosternal chest pain  radiating to his left arm  and associate symptoms suggestive of Acute Myocardial Infarction. Immediate management and cardiology consultation are needed.

Problem Representation:  A 59-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and tobacco use  presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain  characteristically described as ""an elephant sitting on my chest "" radiating to his left shoulder and arm. The pain started approximately 2 hours ago while he was doing yard work at home but has not subsided after rest. Concomitant symptoms include shortness of breath  profuse cold sweats  nausea  and lightheadedness. There was associated dyspnea and syncope. No history of early heart disease in his family and he denies using any illicit drugs. His BMI is 28  and he seems to be in significant distress with apparent pallor. His last cardiac check-up was two years ago  he has not been compliant with the prescribed statin and antihypertensive medications. The patient has no known allergies. He drinks alcohol socially and has a 20-pack-year smoking history. His diet and exercise habits are poor. He is married and retired from his job as a truck driver. He lives with his wife and they have two adult children. His father had a heart attack at age 66.

A 62-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presents with a chief complaint of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm that started about 1 hour ago. He describes the pain as a heavy pressure sensation and also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis and nausea. He does not have a known history of coronary artery disease  but his father had a myocardial infarction in his early 60s. He is a 40 pack years smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. He does not exercise regularly and is on long-term aspirin  metformin and atorvastatin. On examination  he appears clammy  anxious  and in pain. His blood pressure is elevated at 165/95 mmHg  heart rate is 105 beats/minute  and he has an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior precordial leads  indicative of an acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction.

Patient Representation:   Mr. Brown is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history and a family history of premature cardiovascular disease. Mr. Brown presents to the emergency department with the acute onset of severe  non-remitting  substernal chest pain that radiates to his left arm. The pain started one hour prior while he was shoveling snow and is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom. He took over-the-counter aspirin with slight relief. His vital signs show blood pressure 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 90bpm  respiratory rate 20bpm  and 97% O2 saturation on room air. Physical examination reveals an anxious elderly male in moderate distress  pallor  cool extremities  and diaphoresis. Cardiovascular examination shows tachycardia  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung fields are clear. Electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevations in precordial leads indicative of an anterior wall acute myocardial infarction. His troponin levels are significantly elevated  consistent with acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Demographics: A 64-year-old African American male.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled by oral medications  and is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history. No previous cardiac events  but no regular follow-ups with his primary care physician over the past two years. Family history is significant for his father  who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67.  Relevant Symptoms on Presentation: The patient reports experiencing severe chest pain for the last 6 hours. The pain  which he describes as ""squeezing"" has a rating of 8/10  located in the substernal region and radiating to his left arm. He also reports associated symptoms of nausea  diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and lightheadedness. He denies any similar previous episodes. On physical examination  the patient appears pale  diaphoretic with a clammy skin. Vital signs show blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air.

Patient Representation: Mr. Sanchez  a 62-year-old Hispanic male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with sudden onset  severe  crushing  substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. The pain has lasted for about 3 hours. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and reports a family history of heart disease. Over the past few months  he mentions episodes of chest discomfort during activities which resolved with rest. He takes Metformin and Lisinopril  but admits to occasionally skipping doses. On examination  he is pale  sweaty  and in obvious distress. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse 90 bpm  and respiratory rate 22 breaths/min. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs. Pulmonary exam shows no crackles. EKG demonstrates ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF. He is diagnosed with an acute inferior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient Initials: J.J  Sex: Male  Age: 66 years  Presenting Problem: 66-year-old male with a history of Type II Diabetes and Hyperlipidemia presented with severe chest pain described as ""pressure"" that radiated to his left arm  feeling of breathlessness  and excessive sweating. Pain initiated about 2 hours ago while mowing the lawn. Nitroglycerin did not help relieve the pain.  Physical findings: On examination  patient looks pale and diaphoretic with blood pressure of 160/96  pulse 98 bpm  respiratory rate 25/min  temperature of 98.2 F. Cardiac Auscultation reveals reduced heart sounds.  Laboratory Findings: ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Labs show elevated troponin I levels. Lipid profile shows Hyperlipidemia.  Impression: Acute Anterior Wall Myocardial Infarction.   This patient with risk factors such as Type II Diabetes  Hyperlipidemia is presenting with a major acute myocardial infarction indicated by severe chest pain  associated symptoms  and diagnostic findings.

A 57-year-old Caucasian male with a history of dyslipidemia  hypertension  smoking and no prior myocardial infarction  that came to emergency department presenting with severe  crushing chest pain in the middle and to the left side of his chest which started one hour prior to presentation. The pain was described as 10/10  radiating to left arm  associated with cold sweats  nausea  and shortness of breath. Blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 92% in room air. Electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads. In addition  troponin levels were found to be elevated.

Patient is a 62-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with sudden onset chest pain. The pain  which started two hours ago  is located in the center of the chest and described as a ""heavy pressure."" It radiates to the left arm and is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom. The patient has never experienced a similar episode. He states that his father passed away from a 'heart attack' at age 65 and his older brother also has coronary artery disease. He is a current smoker with a 20 pack-year history and admits to poor adherence to his prescribed medications. The patient also reports a diet high in fats and low in fruits and vegetables. He denies any recent trauma or illicit drug use.

Patient Representation:  Mr. Hill is a 72-year-old retired businessman with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents to ER with a two hour history of severe crushing chest pain  radiating to his left arm and neck  devoid of a clear precipitating factor. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. He reports no relief with rest. There is no relevant surgical history. He is a former 20 pack-year smoker  but quit 10 years ago. His father had a heart attack at the age of 65. His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril and Rosuvastatin. Upon initial assessment  Mr. Hill is pale  diaphoretic  and appears in distress.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African American male.  Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medication. The patient is an ex-smoker with a 20-pack year history.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presented to the emergency room with a one-hour history of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain was accompanied by shortness of breath  dizziness  profuse sweating  and nausea. His vital signs on presentation were: Blood pressure: 165/90 mmHg; Pulse: 95 beats per minute; Oxygen saturation: 92% on room air.  Problem Representation: Given the patient's age  gender  previous medical history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes  the symptom of sudden severe chest pain radiating to the arm along with associated symptoms of perspiration  dizziness  and nausea represent a high likelihood of acute myocardial infarction. Prompt diagnosis through an ECG and cardiac enzyme levels  along with immediate management  is paramount to prevent further cardiac damage and other potential complications.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco use. He presents to the emergency department with a 5-hour history of crushing  substernal chest pain that radiates to the left arm. He describes the pain as 8/10  worsening with exertion and relieved partially by rest. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. He has also experienced diaphoresis during the event. This constellation of symptoms and history suggest an acute myocardial infarction.

Problem Representation: A 55-year-old male smoker  with a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with acute onset retrosternal chest pain radiating to his left arm that started approximately two hours prior to presentation. The pain is described as crushing in nature  not relieved with rest  and associated with shortness of breath  nausea and profuse diaphoresis. His ECG reveals ST segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF and he has elevated troponin levels  indicative of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. His blood pressure on presentation is 150/90 mmHg and his heart rate is 120 beats per minute. He denies any history of previous similar episodes or family history of premature coronary artery disease.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Jones is a 56-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  who presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain that started 2 hours ago. The pain is described as crushing in nature radiating to his left arm and up to his jaw  associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. Mr. Jones mentions he had been feeling fatigued for the past few weeks but didn't think much about it until today's episode. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and has a family history of heart disease. On examination  Mr. Jones appears pale and diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg  heart rate of 100 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. EKG findings show ST-segment elevation in anterior leads suggestive of an anterior wall MI.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He presented to the emergency department complaining of a severe  10/10 central  crushing chest pain that began at rest and radiated to his left arm and jaw. He also reported associated symptoms of shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  and diaphoresis. The pain began 4 hours prior and was not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin tablets. The patient also described a recent history of intermittent  similar but less severe chest pain over the past two weeks. On physical examination  he was diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. ECG showed ST-segment elevations in the anterior precordial leads. Labs were significant for elevated cardiac enzymes. The patient was diagnosed with an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient  Mr. Harvey  is a 62-year-old African-American male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a long history of heavy smoking. Presents to ER with a chief complaint of severe  crushing  substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw that started while he was mowing his lawn 2 hours ago. The pain is associated with profuse sweating  feelings of nausea  shortness of breath  and a sensation of impending doom. He rates his pain as 10/10 and reports that this is the first-time severe chest pain  unlike his previous episodes of angina which were relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. An EKG revealed findings of ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads consistent with an anterior wall acute myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. Presented to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain of sudden onset  radiating to the left arm and neck. The pain started around 2 hours ago while the patient was doing yard work. Denies recent trauma or injury. Reports associated symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. No known allergies. He is a non-smoker and denies illicit drug use  however reports occasional alcohol consumption. He has been compliant with his regular medication regimen of aspirin  metformin  and atorvastatin. No history of similar episodes in the past. Family history is significant for ischemic heart disease with his father having had a heart attack at the age of 59. On presentation  patient appears anxious and in distress. Vitals: BP 165/90  pulse 92  respirations 20  temp 98.7°F  SpO2 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals cool  clammy skin and decreased breath sounds in lower lung fields. Heart sounds normal with no murmur or gallop. Initial EKG findings suggestive of acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Patient ID: 68-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Problem: Patient presents with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm. Reports sudden onset of symptoms while at rest. Patient describes a feeling of heavy pressure and tightness in his chest.  Past Medical History: Patient has a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a tobacco smoker with a 40 pack-year smoking history and a long term moderate alcohol use. No previous known history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction. Family history reveals his father had an MI at age 55.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared distressed and sweaty. Vital signs show a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure at 150/90 mmHg  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation at 94% on room air. Cardiovascular exam reveals regular tachycardia without murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  Diagnostic Evaluation: Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in lead II  III  and aVF suggestive of an acute inferior wall myocardial infarction. Blood test results confirm an elevation in cardiac enzymes including troponin levels.  Impression: Patient's symptoms in association with history  clinical findings  and diagnostic results indicate acute inferior wall myocardial infarction (MI). This presentation might be related to his notable risk factors like chronic hypertension  diabetes and tobacco use. Patient is in urgent need of comprehensive cardiovascular care.

Patient Description: Mr. Williams  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  is a retired construction worker who was brought to the emergency department by EMS.  Presenting Complaint: He reports having experienced severe  crushing central chest pain for the past two hours at rest. The pain is radiating to his left arm and jaw. Mr. Williams also reports experiencing associated symptoms such as shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  and a sense of impending doom.   Relevant Medical History: Mr. Williams has a known medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and is a 20-year heavy smoker. His father died at the age of 62 due to a heart attack.   Current Medication: He is on Amlodipine for hypertension and Simvastatin for hypercholesterolemia. He has no known drug allergies.  Examination & Initial Investigation: On physical examination  the patient is in acute distress  sweaty  and looks pale. His blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg  pulse is 110 bpm  and respiration rate is 22 breaths per minute. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1 to V4.   Problem Representation: Mr. Williams is a 65-year-old male with risk factors such as hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and heavy smoking  presenting with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  along with symptoms of diaphoresis  short breaths  and nausea. ECG findings suggest an ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)  likely an acute anterior-wall myocardial infarction.

Patient Problem Representation:  Mr. Peterson  a 64-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of Stage 2 hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking habit  presents to the emergency room with a chief complaint of severe  unremitting substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw that started approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as ""crushing"" in nature and rates it a 10/10. The pain was not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin usage at home. Accompanying symptoms include nausea  dizziness  and shortness of breath with profuse sweating. He does not have a known history of cardiac disease but his father suffered a heart attack at the age of 58. The patient is visibly anxious  with vital signs  demonstrating tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. Immediate EKG reveals ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF  suggestive of an inferior wall acute myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus - all managed with medications. He is also a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history. He presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with abrupt onset of intense  prolonged substernal chest pain that radiated to the left arm  accompanied by profuse cold sweating. He reports the pain started about an hour ago while he was digging in his garden and has not subsided. He also endorses associated shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. There was a similar but milder episode that resolved spontaneously a few days ago. There is no reported chest trauma and no relief with rest or nitroglycerin. Vital signs on arrival: Blood pressure 145/95 mmHg  heart rate 95 bpm  respiratory rate 22 bpm  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. On examining  the patient appears anxious and in distress but the cardiopulmonary exam is otherwise unremarkable. The rest of the physical exam is non-contributory. Initial EKG shows ST-segment elevation in anterior leads. The patient's presentation and investigations are suggestive of an acute anterior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension and transient ischemic attacks. He presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain that started while he was doing heavy yard work earlier in the day. The chest pain is severe  located in the center of his chest  pressure-like in nature  radiating to his left arm and associated with diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. The patient reports never having had this type of chest pain before. An EKG shows ST segment elevation in the anterior leads and cardiac enzymes are elevated  both suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Profile: 68-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: Hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type-2 diabetes  and a family history of coronary artery disease. The patient is a 20-pack year smoker and abuses alcohol. His hypertension and diabetes have been relatively well-controlled on medication.  Current Symptoms: The patient presents to the emergency department with severe  substernal chest pain that radiated to the left arm  associated with drenching sweats  nausea  and a feeling of impending doom. The chest pain initiated about three hours ago while the patient was performing a strenuous activity in his yard. The patient has never experienced similar pain before.  On physical examination  the patient appears pale and diaphoretic  with a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm. A 12-lead EKG shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads suggestive of a myocardial infarction. Initial laboratory analysis reveals elevated cardiac troponin levels.  These findings are consistent with an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. Given this presentation  immediate activation of the cardiac catheterization lab for potential percutaneous coronary intervention is warranted.

Patient Profile: Mr. Thompson  a 64-years-old African American male.  Medical History: Known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  managed on oral antidiabetics and antihypertensive medications. History of smoking 10 cigarettes daily for over 30 years. No known allergies.  Presenting Complaints: Patient presents to the emergency department with acute-onset severe  crushing chest pain described as “pressure-like” sensation  lasting around one hour  radiating to his left arm  associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and palpitations.   Vital signs on presentation:  Blood Pressure: 170/95 mmHg  Heart Rate: 110 beats per minute Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths per minute O2 Saturation: 92% on room air Temperature: 98.6°F  Physical Examination: Patient appeared anxious and distressed  diaphoretic. No visible cyanosis. Chest examination showed no abnormalities. Heart sounds were regular with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Peripheral pulses were palpable. Rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  Based on the presentation  there is a high suspicion for Acute Myocardial Infarction. Immediate EKG  cardiac biomarkers  chest x-ray  and other relevant labs should be done.

Patient is a 65-year old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  who presents with sudden onset severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  that started 2 hours ago. The pain is associated with dyspnea  diaphoresis and nausea. He has never experienced a similar episode in the past. He has a 20-year history of smoking  but denies any illicit drug use. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and antihyperlipidemia medications. No known drug allergies. He has strong family history of premature coronary artery disease; his father had myocardial infarction at the age of 55. On examination  he appears diaphoretic  pale and is in obvious distress. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  heart rate is 110 beats per minute  and respirations are 20 per minute. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. Point-of-care troponin test is positive.

Patient is a 67-year-old male  known hypertensive and diabetic for the past 10 years  presenting with severe  squeezing chest pain that began suddenly 2 hours before arrival to the emergency department. The pain radiates to the patient's left arm and is associated with diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was diagnosed and managed conservatively approximately 4 years ago  but the patient is not currently on anticoagulants. There is a positive family history of cardiovascular disease as the patient's father had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 65. The patient is a lifelong smoker with approximately 30 pack-years of smoking. He restricts his alcohol intake to occasional social drinking and has a diet high in saturated fats and low in fruits and vegetables. Apart from these  the patient is reportedly under considerable stress due to recent work strain. His current medication includes oral hypoglycemic drug metformin for managing diabetes and antihypertensive medication Amlodipine. On examination  his blood pressure is elevated (160/100 mmHg)  he appears diaphoretic and in distress  with a pain score of 8/10. His EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads  suggestive of an ongoing acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old male  Medical History: Documented hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus both under pharmacological control.  Presenting Complaint: Patient presents with a 6-hour history of severe  crushing chest pain that radiates to the left shoulder and jaw  accompanied by diaphoresis  nausea  and dizziness. The pain was acute in onset and continuous  not relieved by rest. The patient also has a history of increased fatigue and shortness of breath upon exertion for the past week.  On Examination: Patient appears pale and is in obvious distress. Vital signs show blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  and respiration rate of 22 breaths per minute with oxygen saturation at 93% on room air.  Impression: The severity and nature of the chest pain  along with the accompanying symptoms and patient's history  are highly suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction. Immediate management is required to confirm diagnosis and treatment.

Problem Representation:  A 60-year-old African American male  retired welder  with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and 35 pack-years of smoking presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain. He has been experiencing this chest tightness for the past three hours  which he describes as crushing and pressure-like  radiating to his left arm and jaw. The symptoms started at rest  accompanied with shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. He also reports experiencing similar but milder and short-lived episodes of chest discomfort over the past two weeks  usually with exertion. Physical exam reveals a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  pulse of 100 beats per minute  profuse sweating  and bilateral basilar crackles on lung auscultation. An electrocardiogram shows changes consistent with ST-elevation myocardial infarction.

Patient Demographics: Mr. Smith  65-year-old African American male.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with severe chest pain  describing it as a sense of heavy pressure or ""an elephant sitting on my chest"". The pain started abruptly  is diffuse  non-radiating and has persisted for more than 30 minutes.   Relevant Medical History: Mr. Smith is a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus (for 10 years) and hypertension (for 15 years). He has a 30 pack-years history of smoking  which he quit five years back. He has a family history of early coronary artery disease  with his father dying from a myocardial infarction at the age of 52.  Clinical Symptoms: Along with chest pain  he reports associated dyspnea  nausea  and diaphoresis. He denies syncope  changes in bowel or bladder function. On examination  he appears anxious  diaphoretic but maintains consciousness. His pulse is 98 bpm and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmur  rubs  or gallops. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.   In view of age  past medical history  classic symptoms and physical findings  a likely diagnosis of Acute Myocardial Infarction is entertained. Immediate medical attention and further investigations are initiated.

A patient is a 60 year old  Caucasian male with a relevant medical history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. The patient is a current smoker with a 40 pack/year smoking history. He presents today with symptoms starting about 2 hours prior to arrival at the Emergency Department. His symptoms include severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the neck and left arm  along with nausea  profuse sweating  and shortness of breath. He rates his pain as an 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. On arrival  his blood pressure is 160/100  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and his oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. He reports no known family history of coronary artery disease. This is his first instance of these symptoms. The patient denies alcohol or other substance use besides tobacco. His symptoms are suggestive of acute myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a known case of diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. He presents in the ER with severe chest pain of 2-hours duration  described as ""crushing"" and radiating to the left arm and neck. The pain suddenly started while he was at rest  and is associated with excessive sweating and a feeling of tightness in the chest. The patient also reports shortness of breath but no dizziness  nausea  or vomiting. He has a 30-pack year smoking history and his father had a myocardial infarction at 62 years old. The patient's drug list includes metformin  lisinopril  and low-dose aspirin  but he admits to being inconsistent with medication compliance. There's no known history of allergies. Physical examination revealed elevated blood pressure  increased heart rate  pale complexion  and cool clammy skin. No abnormalities were noted on lung auscultation. The ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction. These findings are suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient  retired banker  who is an active smoker  with a history of hypertension and obesity.   Chief Compliant: Presents to the emergency department (ED) complaining of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm that started 2 hours ago.  History of Present Illness: The pain is described as heaviness in the middle of the chest  non-radiating  10/10  with associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  and feelings of impending doom. No alleviating or aggravating factors reported.  Past Medical History: Patient has been hypertensive for the last 10 years controlled on medication; the patient was diagnosed with obesity 8 years ago  with a BMI of 35.5  but has not done much about controlling it.   Family History: Father passed away at 60 due to a myocardial infarction. No similar diseases in the mother or siblings.   Physical Examination: Alert  oriented  and appears in distress. Vital signs are stable- BP: 130/85 mmHg  HR: 115 beats/min  body temperature: 37.7 degrees Celsius  RR: 20 breaths/min. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia. Pulmonary examination is normal as well as the other systems.  Conclusion: Given the patient's presenting symptoms  medical history  and family history  there is a high suspicion for acute myocardial infarction. Urgent intervention (e.g.  EKG  blood tests  and possible cardiac catheterization) may be necessary.

Patient Profile: A 67-year-old African American male  Medical History: The Patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and has been a smoker with a 30 pack-year history. He also has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father having suffered a heart attack at age 60.  Presenting symptoms: The patient presented to the emergency department with severe central chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  which occurred at rest. The pain is described as a pressure sensation lasting for more than 30 minutes. This was associated with nausea  shortness of breath  and diaphoresis. On examination  he appeared pale  sweaty  and had an irregular pulse. His blood pressure reading was on the lower side  and initial EKG showed ST-segment elevation in anterior leads suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.  Problem Representation: This is a case of a 67-year-old male patient with significant cardiovascular risk factors such as type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  smoking  and a family history of coronary artery disease  who presents with symptoms and signs consistent with acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. Immediate intervention is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate therapy.

Patient Information: A 62-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith.  Presenting Issue: Mr. Smith presents with severe  crushing chest pain radiating down his left arm.  History: Patient has a medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus type II. He is a former smoker but quit 10 years ago. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father having suffered from a myocardial infarction (MI) at the age of 66.  Social History: Relevant information includes a sedentary lifestyle and diet rich in high-fat foods.  Presentation: Mr. Smith presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain that started one hour ago. The pain is characterized as ""heavy"" or ""tight "" located in the center of the chest  and radiating down to his left arm. Associated symptoms include diaphoresis  dyspnea  nausea  and a sense of impending doom.  Physical Examination: Vital signs demonstrate mild hypertension (150/95 mmHg)  heart rate of 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. The patient appears pale and sweaty. Cardiac examination reveals an irregular heart rhythm but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung exam demonstrates clear lung fields bilaterally.  Clinical Summary: In the setting of his risk factors and current symptoms  Mr. Smith is presenting with an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The patient's uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and family history make him particularly susceptible to this pathology. The patient's sedentary lifestyle and poor diet further aggravate these risk factors. His presentation warrants immediate intervention to limit myocardial damage and improve survival.

Patient Information: A 59-year-old  African-American male  Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension  Type II diabetes mellitus  and high LDL cholesterol. He is a smoker  with a 30-pack per year history. No previous cardiac problems reported.  Chief Complaint: Patient presented at the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain emanating to his left arm and jaw  which began at rest.  Other Relevant Information: The chest pain was associated with breathlessness  diaphoresis  nausea and vomiting. Evaluation revealed the following: BP: 150 / 95 mmHg  Heart Rate: 110 beats/min  Respiratory Rate: 22/min  Oxygen Saturation: 88% on room air. ECG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V4 suggestive of anterior wall myocardial infarction. Blood tests indicated elevated Troponin levels.  Initial Impression: Acute Anterior Wall Myocardial Infarction (AWMI) most likely secondary to longstanding hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  diabetes and smoking. The patient has acute distress due to cardiorespiratory symptoms suggesting severe myocardial damage.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith  a 62-year-old African American male.  Medical History: History of hypertension and type II diabetes  both controlled with medications. Excessive smoker and occasional drinker. No prior cardiac history reported.   Presenting Problem: Patient presenting with severe  abrupt onset chest pain that started while he was resting. The pain is substernal  radiating to the left arm and jaw  persisting for over 3 hours without relief. He also reports associated symptoms of cold sweat  nausea and shortness of breath.  Conclusion: These clinical features raise strong suspicion for an acute myocardial infarction. The patient's risk factors include advanced age  African American race  hypertension  diabetes and smoking habits. The presence of characteristic chest pain further supports this clinical impression. It is therefore emergently necessary to initiate cardiac monitoring  obtain an ECG  and administer nitroglycerin and aspirin while preparing for potential cardiac catheterization.

Patient Profile: Mr. Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history of diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia for which he takes oral medications controls. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago.   Presenting Problem: Mr. Smith presents to the emergency department with a complaint of crushing substernal chest pain  radiating to his left upper limb  associated with nausea  sweating  and shortness of breath that has persisted for approximately two hours. The pain started while he was doing yard work and did not alleviate with rest. His initial blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg  pulse 100 beats per minute  oxygen saturation 92% on room air.  Suspected Diagnosis: These symptoms are suggestive of acute myocardial infarction  an emergent medical issue that requires immediate attention for diagnostic confirmation and treatment.

Problem Representation:  A 62-year-old African American male presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw which started at rest 3 hours prior to the hospital visit. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. Patient has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker (quit 2 years ago; smoking history of 30 pack years)  has a family history of ischemic heart disease (father died of heart attack at the age of 65)  and doesn't exercise regularly. On physical examination  he appeared in distress  was diaphoretic  had a heart rate of 107 beats per minute  blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His EKG revealed ST elevation in leads II  III  and aVF consistent with an inferolateral myocardial infarction. Initial serum troponins were elevated.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a relevant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  presents to the emergency department with symptoms of acute onset chest pain that started two hours ago while he was lifting heavy boxes at his job. The pain is described as severe  pressure-like  located in the center of the chest  and radiating to the left arm. He also reports shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  and diaphoresis. The patient admits to smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years. He has no known drug allergies  his medications include atenolol  atorvastatin  and metformin. There is a family history of early-onset coronary artery disease  with his father having a heart attack at age 55. These symptoms of chest discomfort and known risk factors for ischemic heart disease raise concern for an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient: A 60-year-old African American male  Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes; former smoker; family history of premature heart disease. Noncompliance with antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications.   Presentation: The patient presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of acute onset of severe  crushing chest pain that radiates to the left arm and neck  associated with shortness of breath  cold sweats  and nausea. The pain started at rest and has been persistent for the past two hours. Patient admits to delaying hospital visit due to mistaking symptoms for indigestion.  Physical examination: Patient appears diaphoretic and in distress with a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 96 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals distant heart sounds with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Electrocardiogram shows elevation in the ST-segment in anterior leads.   Current Problem: The patient's presentation and investigations are consistent with an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old male with a significant medical history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. Earlier today  he started experiencing severe  crushing chest pain. This was accompanied by additional symptoms including shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and nausea. His pain was consistent and started when he was mowing the lawn  initially attributing it to exhaustion. Mr. Johnson's pain did not improve with rest and lasted for more than 20 minutes. He reports no previous episodes of similar pain. He is a former smoker with 30 pack years history and admits to a sedentary lifestyle. His father had a 'heart attack' at the age of 60. These symptoms are highly suggestive of acute myocardial infarction.

Patient's Initials: J.D  Age: 65 years old  Sex: Male  Medical Problem: Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI)  Background information:  J.D  a 65-year-old male  has come with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  hypertension (HTN)  and high cholesterol. He has been a smoker for 30 years  currently smokes a pack of cigarettes per day. He is not physically active and has a family history of heart disease; his father died from a heart attack at 70 years old.  Presenting symptoms:  He presented at the hospital with complaints of intense chest pain radiating to his left arm that started about an hour ago. The pain is crushing in nature  graded as 8 out of 10  making it difficult for him to breathe. He also mentioned associated symptoms such as a feeling of unease  sweating profusely  and light-headedness. Preventive measures such as rest and orally consumed nitroglycerin have not alleviated the pain.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old male  Medical History: Previous history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Ex-smoker and has a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD): both parents had heart attacks in their 60s. Never had cardiac procedures or surgery in the past.  Presenting Concerns:  The patient was brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset severe chest pain which started two hours back while he was resting. The pain is described as a heavy pressure sensation in the center of his chest  radiating to his left arm and neck. Accompanying symptoms include profuse sweating  shortness of breath  nausea  and feeling of impending doom. He rates the pain as 10 out of 10.  Summary:  65-year old male with risk factors for CAD  including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  smoking history  and a family history of CAD presents with symptoms consistent with acute myocardial infarction including severe chest pain radiating to left arm and neck  profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and nausea.

Patient Profile: A 55-year-old African American male  weighing 230 pounds and standing at a height of 6 feet.  Presenting Complaint: The patient initially came in complaining of severe chest pain with radiation to the left arm and jaw area  accompanied by bouts of excessive perspiration and shortness of breath.  Medical History: The patient has a documented history of Hypertension and Type II Diabetes. He is a 20-pack-year smoker  takes oral anti-diabetic drugs and antihypertensive medication but is non-compliant with his medication regimen on a regular basis. He also has a family history of ischemic heart disease with his father having passed away from an acute myocardial infarction at 62.  Exam Findings: On physical examination  the patient appeared diaphoretic and in distress  with a blood pressure of 170/100 mm Hg  heart rate of 100 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed no murmurs  gallops  or rubs  lung auscultation showed clear bilateral breath sounds with no rales. Rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Emergent ECG was performed revealing ST-segment elevations in the anterior precordial leads indicative of acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. The patient was immediately given aspirin and was started on oxygen and nitroglycerin prn chest discomfort.

Problem Representation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department complaining of acute  severe chest pain of 45-minute duration that radiated to left arm and jaw  accompanied with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. His medical history revealed type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. He had a past history of smoking for 20 years but stopped 10 years earlier. His father died due to myocardial infarction at an age of 55. On presentation his heart rate was 110 beats per minute  blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation was 92% on room air  and he appeared distressed and clammy. The patient's ECG showed ST-segment elevation and his Troponin level was elevated. These findings are consistent with an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes. He presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to left arm that started around 2 hours ago. The pain is also associated with profuse sweating  feelings of nausea  and shortness of breath. He rates the pain as 10 out of 10 on the pain scale. He has not experienced this type of chest pain before. The patient denies any recent trauma  fever  cough  or changes in bowel and urinary patterns. He has a 45 year history of tobacco use  and his father had a heart attack at age 70. Physical examination reveals an anxious patient in acute distress  blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Heart sounds reveal no murmurs  but there are reduced breath sounds at the bases bilaterally. An EKG was done immediately which showed ST segment elevation in the anterior leads consistent with an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. The patient was started on nitroglycerin and aspirin  and cardiology was immediately consulted for potential catheterization.

Patient Representation:  A 65-year-old African American male  with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and an ongoing 30-pack year smoking history  presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain for the last 3 hours. The pain is described as crushing  located at the center of the chest radiating to the left arm. It started at rest  is associated with severe breathlessness  diaphoresis  nausea  and a sense of impending doom. Patient denies any similar episode in the past. He has not taken any medication for the same. His blood pressure is 165/100 mmHg  and heart rate is 96 bpm. The patient has not adhered to prescribed antihypertensive medications and has not been taking any statins. There is no known family history of premature heart disease. The patient reports adherence to the DASH diet but admits to a sedentary lifestyle.

Patient Presentation: A 62-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia presents with central  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. The patient reports associated symptoms of severe dyspnea  profuse cold sweat  light-headedness  and nausea. The symptoms began an hour ago  and there is no prior history of similar episode. He takes amlodipine and metformin regularly  but is not on aspirin or statin.  Problem representation: Given his age  racial background  male gender  cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia)  and characteristic symptoms (left sided chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  dyspnea  perspiration  light-headedness and nausea)  the patient is likely experiencing an acute myocardial infarction. Time of symptom onset suggest that the patient is in the window period for acute revascularization treatment.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Relevant Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medication. He has been a smoker for over 40 years  with a 30 pack-year smoking history. He doesn't exercise regularly and has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father experiencing a heart attack in his early 60's.  Presenting Symptoms: Patient presented to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain that he rated as a 10/10 in severity. The pain started about 2 hours ago while the patient was at rest  is located in the center of his chest  and radiates to his left arm and jaw. He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  nausea  sweating  and feeling of impending doom. His chest pain is not relieved with rest or nitroglycerin. His blood pressure on presentation was elevated. His ECG shows ST-elevations in the anterior leads  indicative of an anterior wall myocardial infarction. His Troponin I levels were significantly elevated.   Problem Representation:  This is a 65-year-old male with a significant history of risk factors for coronary artery disease (smoking  hypertensive  hyperlipidemia  sedentary lifestyle  family history of early heart disease)  now presenting with a sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw with associated shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. Clinical presentation and diagnostic studies are indicative of an acute myocardial infarction  likely secondary to thrombotic occlusion of the coronary arteries due to underlying atherosclerotic disease.

Demographics: Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old African American male who lives in an urban setting. He works as a taxi driver and is a smoker for 40 years with a pack per day. He has a history of hypertension which is controlled with medication.  Relevant Medical History: His father suffered a myocardial infarction at 55 years old. The patient has been generally well up until the sudden onset of symptoms. He has been treated for hypertension for the past 10 years. His lipid profile from last year indicated mild hypercholesterolemia.  Relevant symptoms on presentation: Mr. Johnson presents with severe intermittent chest pain of 30-minute duration that wake him from his sleep in the early morning. The pain is central and radiates to his left arm  described as pressing and heavy in character. It is associated with shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea. Rest or nitroglycerin does not relieve the pain. His blood pressure is high at presentation (160/100 mmHg)  heart rate of 88 bpm  respiratory rate of 20 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. On auscultation  no additional heart sounds or murmurs. Cardiovascular examination otherwise unremarkable. ECG findings are consistent with an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Profile: A 63-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: Patient has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus. He has a history of tobacco use and his father died of a heart attack at 65.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents to the ED with an acute onset of severe chest pain that began two hours ago. He describes the pain as ""crushing"" and ""heavy "" originating in the center of the chest under the sternum and radiating to his left arm and jaw. Upon examination  the patient is sweating profusely and appears to be in significant distress.  Associated Symptoms: He also reports feeling nauseous and lightheaded. He has had intermittent shortness of breath but denies any recent cough  fever  or chills.   Potential Diagnosis: The patient's symptoms  history  and risk factors are characteristic of Acute Myocardial Infarction.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Smith  a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of sustained hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presents with sudden onset of severe  substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm. The pain is crushing in nature  lasting for more than 30 minutes  associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  and lightheadedness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Family history reveals early coronary artery disease and sudden cardiac death in first-degree relatives.
