He is relatively active but with a noted increase in stress during the recent weeks after volunteering to help with a local community service project.  Past Medical History: The patient has a previous history of hypertension controlled by medications  specifically Losartan 50mg once per day and Amlodipine 5mg once per day. A.G. does not report any allergies to medications. He also has a 7-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus which is managed with Metformin 1000mg twice per day. The patient's father had died of myocardial infarction at the age of 68.   Presenting Complaint: A.G. presented to the ER with a sensation of heaviness pressing on his chest and pain radiating toward his left arm  coupled with shortness of breath and mild perspiration. The pain was not relieved by rest and was accompanied by bouts of nausea. These symptoms were reported to have started about three hours prior to the hospital visit  upon waking from sleep  and had aggravated progressively.  On Arrival: On preliminary examinations  he appeared pale  sweaty  and distressed. His vitals showed a Heart Rate of 102 beats/minute  Blood Pressure 154/90 mm of Hg  Respirational Rate 22 breaths/minuter  SpO2: 92%  Temperature: 37.2°C/ 99°F. Initial 12-lead Electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and AvF  indicative of Inferior Wall Myocardial Infarction (IWMI). Cardiac biomarkers were sent immediately and returned with elevated Troponin I  confirming the diagnosis.  Treatment: A.G. was immediately administered aspirin 300mg and Clopidogrel 300 mg and was taken for emergency Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI). After angiography  it was disclosed that there was a significant occlusion in the right coronary artery  which was successfully treated with stenting.   Post-Intervention: The patient responded well to the procedure and showed marked symptom resolution. He stayed in CCU (Coronary Care Unit) for three days with continuous monitoring of vital signs and symptoms. Following stable vitals  the patient was then moved to the general ward. He was started on daily Cardiac Rehabilitation Program and was clinically stable at discharge after one week. The patient was instructed to continue medication  refrain from smoking  and follow a heart-healthy diet.

Patient Information:  Mr. Stanley  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  presented to the emergency department with sudden chest pain  shortness of breath  and profuse sweating.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient reported persistent  severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to his left arm  associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. The pain was not relieved with rest and had been ongoing for over three hours prior to presenting. He also reported a sensation of ""impending doom.""  Medical History:  Mr. Stanley has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia. He had been a tobacco smoker for 40 years with an approximate 20 cigarettes/day habit and has a high-fat diet. He does not do any regular physical activity and reports moderate alcohol consumption.  Examination:  On examination  Mr. Stanley was pale  sweating  and appeared anxious. His blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  pulse was 100 bpm  and respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination revealed regular S1 and S2 with no obvious murmurs. Lungs were clear on auscultation.   Investigations:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) identified ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads (V2-V4) and reciprocal ST-segment depression in the inferior leads  a finding consistent with an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI). Blood tests demonstrated elevated troponin levels. A computed tomography (CT) scan was performed to rule out other possible causes of chest pain such as aortic dissection or pulmonary embolism.  Diagnosis:  Considering the severe chest pain  electrocardiographic changes  and elevated troponin levels  Mr. Stanley was diagnosed with an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).  Treatment:  He was immediately treated with aspirin  nitroglycerin  and heparin. Concurrently  preparations for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) were undertaken as per the standard protocol for managing an acute STEMI. After an informed consent  the patient underwent a successful PCI with the placement of a drug-eluting stent in the occluded left anterior descending artery. The patient was then started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel).  Follow up:  Mr. Stanley was counseled on lifestyle modifications that included stopping smoking  starting a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise  and taking prescribed medications which include statins  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and dual antiplatelet therapy. He is scheduled for a follow-up with cardiology in four weeks.   This case illustrates the importance of prompt recognition and management of STEMI. Given the patient's robust response to treatment and necessary lifestyle modifications  his prognosis is expectedly optimistic but does require ongoing medical surveillance due to his complex chronic disease burden.

Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  residing in Atlanta  Georgia. He is a retired software engineer  non-smoker  and non-alcoholic but has had a sedentary lifestyle post retirement. There is a positive family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father suffering a myocardial infarction at the age of 65.  Presenting Issue:  Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department on January 13  2022  with severe chest discomfort and pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  associated with sweating  which started about 2 hours back while he was having dinner. The pain persisted despite rest and seemed to increase with exertion.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known case of Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 8 years and has been maintaining his blood sugars with regular insulin injections and diet regulation. He also has a diagnosis of hypertension for the past ten years  controlled with antihypertensive medication. Other significant medical history includes a diagnosis of dyslipidemia three years ago  which has been treated with statin therapy. He has been non-compliant with his medications lately. He has no known allergies. He has been visiting his primary care physician regularly for his chronic ailments. Prior to this episode  he has not reported any angina or palpitations.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  his blood pressure was 170/96 mmHg  and his pulse was 88 beats/minute and regular. Cardiac auscultation revealed no abnormal heart sounds or murmurs. His body temperature was normal  and his oxygen saturation was 97% on room air. His BMI was 28 which is considered overweight.  Diagnostic Assessment:  His EKG showed ST-Segment elevations in the anterior leads indicative of an acute myocardial infarction. His cardiac biomarkers came back significantly elevated with a troponin level of 3.5 ng/mL (normal: 0.0-0.4 ng/mL). Hemoglobin A1c was 7.7 (normal: 4.8-5.6%)  indicating poor glycaemic control. His LDL cholesterol level came back elevated at 165mg/dL (normal: less than 100mg/dL).   Therapeutic Intervention:  He received aspirin and started on an intravenous nitroglycerin infusion and was immediately scanned for a primary angioplasty to determine the extent of arterial blockage. He was found to have a significant left anterior descending artery (LAD) stenosis. Balloon angioplasty and stenting were successfully performed.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  Post angioplasty  his symptoms resolved and the following day's EKG showed normal sinus rhythm. His blood pressure and glucose levels were closely monitored  and medications were adjusted accordingly. He was discharged home on dual antiplatelet therapy  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  high-dose statins  and insulin regimen with dietary advice and guidance on maintaining a healthy lifestyle. He was referred to participate in cardiac rehabilitation and was counseled to adhere to his medications to prevent further cardiac events. Regular cardiologist and diabetic follow-ups were advised.  This case highlights the importance of timely management of acute myocardial infarction and the need for aggressive control of risk factors including diabetes  hypertension  and dyslipidemia.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a 48-year-old African American Male with Past History of Hypertension and Diabetes  Introduction: Our patient is a 48-year-old African American male  178cm tall  who presented to the emergency department of our hospital with sudden onset of crushing central chest pain radiating to the left arm  which lasted for approximately thirty minutes.  Case Presentation: Mr. X had been in his usual state of health until this sudden episode. He also reported experiencing symptoms of shortness of breath  dizziness  and palpitations. He stated that the pain started while he was mowing his lawn. There was no reported decreased consciousness  seizures  slurring of speech  or weakness of the limbs. Mr. X is a non-smoker and his daily routine includes moderate exercise. He consumes alcohol socially  with approximately one to two drinks weekly.  Medical History: Mr. X was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension 7 years ago  both of which are under reasonable control with oral medications. The patient had no known allergy. His family history revealed that his father had suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 52.   Clinical Findings: On examination  Mr. X seemed anxious and clammy but with no visible distress. His blood pressure was 170/100 mm Hg  pulse rate 110 bpm  and respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed tachycardia but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops were detected. The remainder of the physical examination was generally unremarkable.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: A 12-lead EKG (Electrocardiogram) was immediately carried out  which demonstrated elevation of ST-segments in the inferior leads (II  III  aVF)  suggestive of an ongoing myocardial infarction in the inferior wall. Blood investigations showed elevated cardiac biomarkers – initial Troponin-T was 0.6 ng/mL  rising to 2.1 ng/mL after 6 hours. Further investigations revealed high levels of HbA1c (8.2%) and LDL cholesterol (142mg/dL).  Treatment: Mr. X was taken to the cardiac catheterization lab for an emergency angiography  which demonstrated a 100% occlusion of the right coronary artery (RCA). Percutaneous coronary intervention was performed and successful revascularization achieved via a drug-eluting stent. He was then started on Dual Antiplatelet Therapy (DAPT - aspirin and clopidogrel)  a high-intensity statin  and optimal betablocker therapy.  Conclusion: Mr. X’s case highlights the importance of rapid emergency medical response and risk factor management. His case also underscores the enhanced risk for acute myocardial infarction in patients with a family history combined with chronic medical conditions such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus.    Disclaimer: This is a fictional case report created for illustrative purposes only. Any resemblance to real persons  living or dead  is purely coincidental.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a 62-Year-Old Female Patient  Introduction: This case report discusses a 62-year-old Caucasian female patient who presented with acute myocardial infarction (AMI). This patient had a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.   Case Report: A 62-year-old Caucasian woman with a known medical history of hypertension for 10 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 5 years presented to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to her left arm and neck which she described as being different from any pain she had experienced before. The pain lasted for more than 30 minutes and was associated with sweating and breathlessness. She also reported nausea and dizziness.  On arrival  the patient was in obvious distress. Vital signs showed blood pressure of 170/98 mmHg  pulse rate of 105 beats/min  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Physical examination revealed an anxious  pale looking female in acute pain. Cardiac examination revealed normal heart sounds  no murmurs  rubs or gallops. Lungs were clear  and chest wall was tender to touch and palpation.   12-lead electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  along with reciprocal changes in the precordial leads  indicating an inferior wall AMI. Lab results showed elevated Cardiac Troponin I levels. Complete blood count  kidney function tests  and electrolytes  besides a slight increase in glucose level which could be attributed to diabetes  were all within normal limits.  She was immediately started on treatment with aspirin  sublingual nitroglycerin  oxygen and intravenous morphine for pain. She was hurriedly moved to the cardiac catheterization lab for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). A significant stenosis of her right coronary artery was noticed on angiography. Subsequently  a drug-eluting stent was successfully deployed at this site.  Past medical records revealed that the patient was regularly taking oral anti-hypertensives and oral hypoglycaemic agents. She was a nonsmoker and was not a chronic alcohol consumer. There was a family history of cardiovascular diseases  her father developed a myocardial infarction at the age of 59.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the high cardiovascular risk in patients with hypertension and diabetes. Regular monitoring and stricter control of these comorbidities are imperative. Prompt recognition and management of AMI can significantly influence the prognosis. This patient’s acute symptoms  corroborated with ECG and troponin levels  led to the quick detection of AMI  intervention  and likely significantly increased her chances of survival and quality of life post-MI.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction   Patient Information: Mr. K is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a known past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a current smoker with a 30-pack-year history and occasional alcohol consumption. He is employed as a truck driver and lives with his wife. There is a family history of ischemic heart diseases  with his father experiencing his first myocardial infarction (MI) at the age of 65.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with acute  severe chest pain for the past five hours radiating to his left arm and associated with shortness of breath and profuse sweating.   Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient appeared distressed and was sweating profusely. His temperature was normal (98.6°F)  blood pressure was elevated (160/100 mmHg)  heart rate was fast (110 beats/min)  and respiratory rate was slightly increased (20 breaths/min). On cardiovascular examination  a regular rhythm of tachycardia was noted without murmurs.   Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: An electrocardiogram (ECG) was promptly performed revealing ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction. Serum troponin levels were elevated at 10 ng/mL  confirming the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The remaining labs including a complete blood count  kidney function  and electrolytes were essentially within the normal range.  Therapeutic Focus  Intervention  and Follow Up: The patient was immediately treated with sublingual nitroglycerin  chewable aspirin  and intravenous morphine for pain control. Oxygen was administered due to his shortness of breath and to regulate his oxygen saturation. He was also initiated on a beta-blocker for tachycardia and an ACE inhibitor for blood pressure control. He was rushed to cardiac catheterization for a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) that showed occlusion of his left anterior descending (LAD) artery  successfully treated with stent placement.  Following PCI  the patient was admitted to the cardiac intensive care unit (ICU) for further management and observation. He responded well to the treatment and his chest pain considerably subsided. Over the next few days  his heart rate  blood pressure normalized and he was eventually shifted to the step-down unit before being discharged home on aspirin  a beta-blocker  an ACE inhibitor  a statin  and a recommendation for intense cardiac rehabilitation and smoking cessation counseling.  Conclusion: This case highlights the rapid diagnostic and therapeutic response needed in the presentation of an acute myocardial infarction. Recognition of risk factors  such as age  hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and a family history of coronary artery disease  is vital for early intervention and better prognosis.

Case Report: A 58-year-old Male with Acute Myocardial Infarction  Presentation:  A 58-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with severe  central chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain started while the patient was pleasantly playing golf. The patient described the pain as ""crushing"" and it was associated with diaphoresis  dyspnea  and nausea.   There was no history of trauma  fever  or similar episodes in the past. History of Mr. J revealed him to be a chronic smoker for the past 35 years  consuming approximately 1 packet/day. He reported past daily consumption of moderate alcohol but he quit drinking 7 years ago. There were no recently new stresses in life  no depression  but his job as a financial manager involves highly stressful situations.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 62  and his eldest brother had an unexpectedly early onset of coronary artery disease at the age of 46. He was diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago and has been on antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril 20mg/day). He had been poorly compliant with his prescribed regimen for some time due to side effects of dry cough  thus leading to poor blood pressure control. Furthermore  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus two years ago  which is controlled with metformin (500mg OD). However  his compliance for glucose level monitoring is benign due to the unavailability of glucose monitoring devices.  Examinations and Investigations:  On examination  the patient appeared acutely distressed. His pulse was 98 beats per minute (bpm)  and blood pressure was 170/98mm Hg. Cardiovascular examination revealed normal first (S1) and second (S2) heart sounds  without any added sounds or murmur.  An ECG was immediately performed revealing persistent ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads (V1-V4)  consistent with an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.  Troponin I was positive as expected post-4 hours of chest pain and 12-hr troponin I showed an increasing trend which confirmed the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction.  Management and Prognosis:  The patient was immediately started on aspirin  sublingual nitroglycerin and intravenous heparin  bisoprolol for blood pressure control  as well as atorvastatin for cholesterol. Mr. J was taken to the catheterization lab for a coronary angiogram  which showed significant left anterior descending artery (LAD) stenosis. He successfully underwent primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and a drug-eluting stent was placed.  After one week of hospital stay in the cardio-intensive care unit for careful monitoring and treatment  the patient was discharged with a comprehensive medication regimen and was referred to a cardiac rehabilitation center.  This case report emphasizes the importance of controlling risk factors for cardiovascular diseases including smoking  hypertension and non-compliance to medications  especially in individuals with a family history of cardiovascular diseases.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction   Patient Information:  Mr. X  a 62-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type II  and hyperlipidemia presented with severe chest pain radiating down his left arm. He is a former smoker and continues to consume alcohol moderately. There is a notable family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with Type II diabetes in 1998 for which he has been on Metformin therapy. He has been managing hypertension with Lisinopril since 2002  and has hyperlipidemia treated with Atorvastatin since 2005. His last medical checkup was six months ago and his hypertension and diabetes were reported as being adequately controlled. The patient does not have any known allergies. He reported no previous history of angina  myocardial infarction  or other heart-related diseases.   Presenting Complaints:  The patient was admitted to the emergency department with symptoms of chest pain that he described as a heaviness and which had developed earlier that day. The pain was unrelieved by rest. He also described shortness of breath  a cold sweat  and the apparent onset of nausea.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  the patient appeared pale  sweaty  and in clear distress. His blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  pulse was 98 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was 22 respirations per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed a normal rhythm with no audible heart murmurs or other abnormalities. An initial electrocardiogram was conducted  which demonstrated ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction (MI).   Diagnosis:  The patient was diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction. Cardiac enzyme studies were done immediately  revealing substantially elevated levels further supporting the diagnosis. A subsequent echocardiogram suggested a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction  indicative of impaired heart function.  Management and Progress:  Mr. X was urgently admitted to the Cardiac Care Unit and thrombolysis was initiated immediately  following which the patient's chest pain significantly subsided. He was put on beta-blockers  angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors  and statins  in addition to low-dose aspirin. His condition remained stable and he was discharged after seven days with scheduled follow-up appointments and strong recommendations for lifestyle modification.  Learning Points:  This case illustrates the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment in acute myocardial infarction to prevent major complications. Attention to modifiable risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and lifestyle habits is crucial in preventative care. It also emphasizes the critical role of primary care physicians in the ongoing care of patients with chronic diseases like diabetes and hypertension  as these are recognized risk factors for developing acute myocardial infarction.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a 58-year-old Male  Patient Information:  A 58-year-old male presented to the emergency department complaining of severe chest discomfort. He is Caucasian  has a sedentary job as an accountant  and lives with his wife in a suburban area. The patient is a smoker with a 30 pack-year history  and consumes alcohol moderately on the weekends. He has known hypertension (HTN) and type-2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM) for which he takes medication irregularly.  Clinical Findings:  The patient complained of squeezing chest pain radiating down his left arm and up to his jaw lasting for more than an hour before presentation. He also reported feelings of nausea  sweating  and shortness of breath. His heart rate was elevated at 110 beats per minute and his blood pressure was high  at 160/95 mmHg. His body mass index (BMI) was calculated as 27.4  categorizing him as overweight.  Diagnostic Assessment:  With the clinical picture suggestive of Acute Myocardial Infarction (MI)  an electrocardiogram (ECG) was swiftly undertaken. The ECG showed significant ST-segment elevation in the anterior-septal leads  confirming the diagnosis of an ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI). Cardiac enzymes  including Troponin I  were markedly raised. His fasting glucose level was elevated  as well as a slightly elevated cholesterol level.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Immediate medical management was initiated with aspirin  clopidogrel  and heparin. The patient was administered sublingual nitroglycerin for chest pain and intravenous furosemide for congestion symptoms. He was urgently referred for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Coronary angiography revealed a significant stenosis in the proximal part of the left anterior descending artery (LAD)  for which a drug-eluting stent was successfully put in place.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Post-PCI  the patient's chest pain significantly improved. His postoperative course in the coronary care unit was uneventful. He was started on beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  statins  and dual antiplatelet therapy. He was counseled on the importance of adherence to his medication regimen  smoking cessation  dietary changes  and regular exercise. An appointment was arranged with a cardiologist in four weeks and outpatient cardiac rehabilitation was organized.  Patient Perspective:  The patient was grateful for the quick diagnosis and intervention  acknowledging his irregular medication habits. He expressed readiness to commit to necessary lifestyle changes and regular follow-ups.  Informed Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of immediate recognition and management of STEMI  and the critical role of patient’s commitment to medication adherence and lifestyle modifications in preventing further cardiac events.

Patient Information:  Mr. J  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker with a history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and hyperlipidemia  presented to the emergency department (ED) with severe chest pain. He is retired and lives with his wife  with two children residing nearby. He does not drink alcohol and claims to follow a balanced diet and moderately active lifestyle.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient came into the ED complaining of severe chest pain of sudden onset that started two hours prior. The pain was localized in the center of his chest  radiating to his left arm  and was accompanied by shortness of breath  diaphoresis (excessive sweating)  and a feeling of impending doom.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J has a significant medical history. He was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 15 years ago and diabetes mellitus type 2 ten years ago. Medications include losartan  metformin  and simvastatin. He has regular check-ups with both his primary care physician and cardiologist  showing control of his hypertension and diabetes. However  his adherence to medications and lifestyle modifications has been poor.   Physical Examination:  On initial assessment  Mr. J was conscious but appeared distressed. Vital signs recorded BP of 150/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min  temperature of 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed tachycardia and distant heart sounds but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung fields were clear.  Investigations:  His EKG showed signs of ST-segment elevation in the anterior and lateral leads  indicating an acute myocardial infarction (MI). The initial lab results showed elevated cardiac enzymes (Troponin I level of 4.2 ng/mL and CPK-MB of 60 U/L). Lipid profile showed high LDL cholesterol levels (160 mg/dL). His CBC showed a slightly elevated white cell count and HbA1c level was 8.2%.  Treatment:  Mr. J was immediately started on a high-flow oxygen mask  IV nitroglycerin  and aspirin 300mg for pain. He was rushed to the cardiac catheterization lab for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) which showed a proximal occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD). Angioplasty with stenting was successfully performed.   Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient was transferred to the cardiac care unit (CCU) post-procedure. He remained hemodynamically stable and his symptoms gradually resolved. His medications were adjusted  with the addition of a beta blocker  aspirin  clopidogrel  and a statin. He was advised to follow a strict diet  regular exercise  and stop smoking. He is to follow up with the outpatient department for further management and continual monitoring.  In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of early recognition  proper risk stratification  and prompt intervention in acute MI  underscoring the critical role of adherence to antihypertensive  anti-diabetic  and lipid-lowering therapies in patients with known coronary risk factors.

Case Report   Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a 64-Year-Old Male with a History of Hyperlipidemia  Summary: A 64-year-old male presented with sudden onset chest pain radiating to the left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath and sweating. The patient had a history of hyperlipidemia but no previously diagnosed cardiovascular disorders. He was later diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction (AMI).  Patient Information: The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian male  retired  originally from the Midwest region of the United States. He is a non-smoker with moderate alcohol intake  married  has three children  and has a previous medical history of hyperlipidemia  managed by diet and Rosuvastatin (10mg/day).  Clinical Findings: The patient was restful when brought in  noteworthy for diaphoresis and mild distress due to chest pain. He reported a sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain that woke him from his sleep. The pain radiated to the left arm and was accompanied by shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. His initial blood pressure was 160/90mmHg  pulse rate was 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  and the temperature was 36.5°C.  Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram (EKG) revealed ST-elevations in the anterior-septal leads (V1-V5)  indicative of an anterior wall AMI. Troponin I level came back at 4.5ng/ml  significantly above the upper limit of normal. Cardiac catheterization revealed 100% occlusion of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the patient's history  physical exam  and initial investigations  a diagnosis of ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) was made. The patient was taken immediately to the Catheterization Laboratory for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). A balloon angioplasty was performed  and a drug-eluting stent was placed in the occluded segment of the LAD.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Post-PCI  the patient reported a subsided chest pain. EKG returns to near-normal with residual ST-segment changes. Troponin levels trended downward over the next 48 hours. The patient was discharged on post-AMI medications which included Aspirin  Clopidogrel  Rosuvastatin  and Metoprolol. A follow-up outpatient appointment was planned in a week.  Learning Points: This case underscores the importance of rapid recognition and treatment of STEMI and the critical role of primary PCI in achieving myocardial reperfusion. Also  it highlights that patients with risk factors  such as hyperlipidemia  need strict control and routine follow-up to prevent major cardiovascular events.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction: A Case Report on a 56-year-old Male  Introduction: A case of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) occurred in a 56-year-old Caucasian male identified as GW. GW was admitted to the emergency department of Johns Hopkins Hospital presenting the classic symptoms of AMI.  Patient Information: The patient  GW  is a 56-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus. He is a long-term smoker with a pack history of 30 years and regularly consumes alcohol  approximately 14 units per week. There are no known drug allergies. The patient lives in Baltimore  Maryland  is retired  and lives with his wife. He previously worked as a long-distance truck driver  leading a predominantly sedentary lifestyle.   Case Presentation: GW was brought into the Emergency Department presenting severe chest pain  radiating to his left arm  along with shortness of breath and profuse sweating. The symptoms started about 1 hour prior to the presentation. GW's previous medical history was significant for hypertension and type II diabetes  both being treated with Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively. However  he had been non-compliant with his medications.  Examination and Diagnostic Assessment: On initial vital check  GW had a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg  pulse of 120 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22/min  and oxygen saturation was 94% in room air. Chest auscultation noted decreased breath sounds  and cardiovascular examination revealed pathologic S3 heart sound. ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) was diagnosed based on electrocardiogram (ECG) findings  showing ST elevations in leads II  III  and aVF. Laboratory tests indicated elevated Troponin-I levels.  Diagnostic Intervention and Treatment: GW received sublingual nitroglycerin for initial chest pain management and was immediately taken to the cardiac catheterization laboratory for further intervention. He underwent a successful primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) of the right coronary artery  which was 100 percent occluded. Post-procedure  beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and statins were prescribed  beside continued management for diabetes and hypertension.  Conclusion: The patient was diagnosed with right coronary artery AMI. With an intervention including PCI  risk factor modification  and improved medication compliance  the patient is demonstrating appropriate recovery. This case highlights the importance of prompt recognition and treatment for AMI in patients with risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and diabetes mellitus to prevent severe complications.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a Low-Risk Patient with No Known Comorbidities  Introduction:  This report involves a 50-year-old male presenting with acute myocardial infarction despite the absence of traditional lifestyle factors posing significant risk or known comorbidity.  Patient Information:  Mr. X is a 50-year-old Asian-American male mechanic with an exemplary lifestyle. He neither smokes tobacco nor consumes alcohol and has a balanced diet and regular physical activity routine. There was no family history of cardiovascular diseases.   Clinical Findings:  The patient had been suffering from intermittent chest pains for the past week  which he initially attributed to work-related stress and muscle strain. However  the increasing severity of chest pain  paired with shortness of breath  prompted him to visit the hospital. His vitals were stable with blood pressure at 140/90 mm of Hg  a heart rate of 92 bpm  and SpO2 92% on room air.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Immediately  an Electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed  showing signs of ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads (II  III  AVF) and ST-segment depression in the anterolateral leads (I  aVL). This pattern is indicative of potential inferior wall myocardial infarction. Laboratory investigations revealed an elevated Troponin I level (1.2 ng/ml)  and other readings were within normal limits. The patient's Fasting Blood Sugar (92 mg/dl)  Lipid profile (Total cholesterol: 170 mg/dl  HDL: 43 mg/dl  LDL: 92 mg/dl  Triglycerides: 130 mg/dl)  and HbA1c (5.3%) were all within the normal range revealing no signs of diabetes or dyslipidemia.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction  treated urgently with dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  sublingual nitroglycerine  and IV morphine for pain. A loading dose of atorvastatin (statin) was also administered. Due to ongoing chest pain and persistent ST changes  he was taken for emergency coronary angiography  which revealed a complete occlusion of the mid-right coronary artery (RCA). Consequently  a primary PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention) was performed  stenting the RCA and successfully restoring its blood flow.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Post-procedure  the patient's symptoms resolved  and ST-segments on ECG considerably improved. He was discharged after five days of hospitalization with life-long medications  including dual antiplatelets  statins  beta-blockers  and ACE inhibitors. The patient was also referred to a cardiac rehabilitation program. Further  he was instructed to have regular follow-ups for the close monitoring of his condition.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the unpredictable nature of coronary artery diseases and the crucial role of early intervention in managing acute myocardial infarction  even when typical risk factors are absent.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in an Elderly Male Patient with Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus  Patient Information:  A 69-year-old Hispanic male presented to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both managed with medications. He is a former smoker  having quit approximately 15 years ago  but has a 20 pack-year history. The patient lives with his wife and has 2 adult children. He has been retired for 9 years and enjoys gardening and light exercise.  Chief Complaint:  The patient described the chest pain as severe  central  and crushing  radiating towards the left arm and jaw. The pain had started about 2 hours before he came to the hospital. Also  he reported experiencing nausea  sweatiness  and mild shortness of breath.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient appeared sweaty and in discomfort. His blood pressure was 155/90mm Hg  pulse 96 beats/minute  temperature 37.2°C (99°F)  and respiratory rate 20 breaths/minute. Cardiovascular examination revealed regular rhythm with no murmurs  and chest was clear on auscultation.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An ECG was performed immediately which showed ST elevation in leads II  III  aVF indicative of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Troponin I levels were significantly elevated. A complete blood panel showed a slight elevation in blood glucose and HbA1c levels  which is expected in someone with the history of diabetes mellitus. Renal function and electrolyte levels were within normal limits.  Treatment:  The patient was treated promptly with aspirin  sublingual nitroglycerin in the emergency department. A successful primary percutaneous coronary intervention was performed which showed a total occlusion of the right coronary artery that was then treated with angioplasty and stenting. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy  beta-blockers  and statins. His blood glucose levels were managed with insulin during the hospital stay.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient gradually improved and his chest pain completely resolved. He was discharged on the fifth day post-angioplasty. At his 1-month follow-up  he reported no further chest pain and was tolerating his medications well  with improved control of his blood pressure and blood glucose levels.  Conclusion:  This case report highlights the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment of acute myocardial infarction in a high-risk individual with significant comorbidities  such as diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Ongoing secondary prevention and meticulous management of these comorbidities remain essential in reducing the risk of future cardiovascular events.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a 65-Year-Old Male with a History of Hypertension and Hyperlipidaemia  Case Presentation  Patient Information  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  who presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaint of sudden onset of chest pain  which had begun 4 hours prior to his hospital arrival. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  but no known history of heart disease or myocardial infarction. He reports a family history of heart disease  with his father having suffered a fatal heart attack at 67. The patient is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago  but he admits to continued moderate alcohol consumption (approximately four standard drinks per day). His diet is reportedly high in animal fats and processed foods.    Clinical Findings  Physical examination in the ED revealed a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  heart rate of 102 beats/min  respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. The patient appeared distressed and diaphoretic. On cardiovascular examination  no heart murmurs were detected; however  heart sounds were rapid and regular. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevations in the anterolateral leads  indicative of possible acute myocardial infarction. Lab results showed a significant increase in the cardiac biomarkers troponin T (6.2 ng/ml; normal range 0-0.04 ng/ml) and Creatine Kinase-MB (CK-MB; 90 U/L; normal range 0-25 U/L).  Diagnosis  Based on the clinical findings  the patient was diagnosed with acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).  Treatment  The patient was treated promptly according to the standard of care for STEMI. He received aspirin  clopidogrel  and a loading dose of a high-intensity statin in the ED. Intravenous nitroglycerin was used for control of chest pain. After stabilization in the ED  he was transferred to the cardiac catheterization lab for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).  Outcome  The primary PCI was successful in treating a large thrombus in the left anterior descending artery. The patient’s symptoms of angina resolved  and follow-up ECG in the coronary care unit was normal.  Follow-up  In context of his high risk for future cardiac events given his hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history  and lifestyle  the patient was referred for counseling on diet  exercise  smoking cessation  and limiting alcohol intake. He was discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  a beta-blocker  an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor  and a statin  with planned follow-up in the outpatient cardiology clinic.  Conclusion  This case illustrates the importance of recognizing  managing and providing prompt treatment for acute myocardial infarction  addressing underlying risk factors and the institution of secondary prevention strategies to reduce recurrent cardiac events.  Learning points  This case reminds clinicians of the necessity of early recognition and interventional management for acute myocardial infarction. It further emphasizes the importance of managing and modifying the risk factors for coronary artery disease  particularly in patients who have already experienced an acute myocardial infarction.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction in Elderly Patient with Diabetes and Hypertension  Patient Information: Mr. A  74-year-old African-American male  83 kg  175 cm tall  moderate smoker with a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  presented to the emergency department (ED) with severe and sudden onset chest pain  radiating to left arm and neck.  Clinical Findings: The severe chest pain lasted for over an hour and was described as 'crushing' in nature. Accompanying symptoms were diaphoresis  paleness  breathlessness  and the sensation of impending doom. On physical examination  blood pressure was found to be 160/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  pulse rate was 102 beats/min  and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. No specific chest abnormalities were detected on auscultation; peripheral pulses were present and equal bilaterally.  Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads (II  III and aVF) and slight depression in I and aVL  consistent with acute inferior wall myocardial infarction (MI). Troponin I levels were 18 ng/mL  well above the reference range of 0.00-0.03 ng/mL. Other laboratory findings showed elevated blood glucose  creatinine  and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol  reflecting his history of Diabetes Mellitus and poor lipid control.   Therapeutic Intervention: Mr. A was administered chewable Aspirin 300 mg  Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg sublingually  and Morphine for pain control. Clopidogrel of 600 mg was also given. He was rushed to the catheterization laboratory for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Coronary angiography revealed a thrombotic occlusion of the right coronary artery (RCA). Balloon angioplasty was undertaken followed by stent placement with resulting TIMI 3 flow.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Post-procedure  the chest pain was resolved and the patient was stable. The patient was transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit (CICU) for monitoring. Dual antiplatelet therapy was continued along with Beta-blockers  ACE inhibitor and Statin for secondary prophylaxis of coronary artery disease. The ECG changes normalized over the next 48 hours. Cardiac rehabilitation was planned and the patient was counseled about lifestyle changes  dietary modification  strict glycemic control  regular follow-up  and medication compliance.   Patient Perspective: The patient expressed gratitude for the emergency care received and was relieved of the sudden chest pain. He expressed willingness to comply with the recommended lifestyle changes and medical therapy for a better prognosis.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient.  This case report underscores the importance of prompt recognition and treatment of acute myocardial infarction  especially in high-risk patient populations with a history of diabetes and hypertension  to prevent significant morbidity and mortality.

Case Report  Patient Profile: Mr. S  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department alone. He works as a mechanic in a private automotive car shop. He has a history of smoking for the past 40 years with approximately 20 cigarettes a day. The patient's alcohol consumption is minimal; he only drinks socially during holidays or special occasions. He has a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity and a high-fat  low-fiber diet.  Past Medical History: Mr. S has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years and has been taking anti-hypertensive medication (amlodipine 5mg once daily) and oral antidiabetic therapy (metformin 500mg twice daily). His blood pressure and blood sugar levels have been moderately controlled. The patient's father had a history of myocardial infarction and passed away at the age of 65.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. S presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain of nine-hour duration. The pain was described as heaviness in the center of the chest  radiating to the jaw and left arm. He also reported associated symptoms of shortness of breath  sweating and mild nausea. He did not experience any faintness  dizziness  or palpitations.   Diagnosis and Management: The initial electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated ST-elevation in the anterior chest leads (V1-V4)  suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction. He received immediate therapy with aspirin  sublingual nitroglycerin  and intravenous heparin.   Management included urgent reperfusion therapy to limit the size of the infarction. This was achieved using thrombolytic therapy intravenously due to the absence of a quick-access cardiac catheterization facility. An early invasive strategy consisting of angiography and angioplasty was suggested as a follow-up.   The patient experienced relief from the chest pain following treatment initiation and stabilization was achieved. Mr. S was strongly advised to quit smoking and referred to cessation programs. He was also advised to modify his diet and increase his physical activity. Medication was adjusted to include a dual antiplatelet regime (aspirin and clopidogrel)  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and cholesterol-lowering medication (statins).  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of prompt identification and management of acute myocardial infarction  especially in high-risk individuals. In addition  it emphasizes the need for consistent control of risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes and the importance of lifestyle modification including smoking cessation  diet modification  and physical activity.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a 72-Year-Old Male   Patient Information: Mr. XYZ  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the Emergency Department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain with radiation to the left arm and jaw. The patient had a past medical history of hypertension and dyslipidemia and was a longstanding smoker for the past 50 years  though he quit 10 years ago. He is not a known diabetic  and there is no family history of heart diseases reported.  Clinical Findings: Upon arrival at the emergency department  the patient was pale  diaphoretic  and appeared in distress. His blood pressure was 150/80 mmHg  heart rate was 102 bpm  and respiratory rate was 21 breaths per minute. Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed significant ST elevations in anterolateral leads suggesting an acute myocardial infarction. Laboratory findings showed an elevated troponin I level of 0.60 ng/mL (normal value: ≤0.04 ng/mL)  confirming severe myocardial injury. His cholesterol panel revealed LDL cholesterol of 190 mg/dl  triglycerides of 210 mg/dl  and HDL cholesterol of 35 mg/dl.   Treatment and Outcome: The patient was diagnosed with an acute ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) and immediately started on aspirin  clopidogrel  and heparin. He was then transferred to the catheterization lab for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Coronary angiography showed a 100% occlusion in the left anterior descending artery (LAD). Balloon angioplasty was performed followed by the successful placement of a drug-eluting stent. Post-PCI  the patient’s symptoms subsided  and follow-up ECG showed resolution of ST elevations. The patient was then started on a statin  beta-blocker  and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor with advice to continue dual antiplatelet therapy.  Discussion: The case emphasizes the crucial role of rapid identification  risk stratification  and management of patients with acute STEMI. The patient’s smoking history  advanced age  hypertension  and dyslipidemia were significant contributing factors to his disease. Early revascularization with PCI along with optimal medical therapy effectively improved the clinical outcomes. Interventions for cigarette smoking cessation  control of hypertension  and management of dyslipidemia are vital in preventing future coronary events in such patients.   Patient consent was obtained for providing this case report.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a Middle-Aged Diabetic Female  Introduction:  A 52-year-old female with a known history of Diabetes Mellitus Type II  high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia presented with acute onset of severe central chest pain  radiating to the left arm.  Demographic Information and Medical History: Mrs. T is a Caucasian female  living in a metropolitan area with a good support system consisting of her husband and two adult children. She is a former smoker with a 20-year history but quit smoking 10 years prior to presentation. She consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. The patient held a sedentary desk job with minimal physical activity.   She had been diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus type II fifteen years prior  and had been managing it with Metformin and lifestyle modifications. Her adherence to dietary regulations had been variable and her HbA1c levels were generally high  indicating poor control of her diabetes. Additionally  she was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia eight years back  and has been on medication (Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for her hyperlipidemia). Her cholesterol levels have been mostly well-controlled with medication.  Acute Presentation: She reported waking up from sleep with severe and squeezing chest pain that started at around midnight. The pain persisted and increased in intensity over a couple of hours  then radiated down the left arm with associated shortness of breath and diaphoresis. These symptoms prompted her to seek immediate medical attention.   Investigations: A 12-lead EKG revealed ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF  indicative of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Troponin levels checked upon arrival were significantly elevated and further confirmed the diagnosis. Her echocardiogram indicated impaired left ventricular function with an estimated ejection fraction of 45-50%.  Treatment: With a diagnosis of ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)  she was promptly started on Monotherapy (Aspirin  Ticagrelor) and low molecular weight heparin. She was transferred for an emergency coronary angiogram  which revealed a 100% occlusion of the right coronary artery. An angioplasty was performed  and a drug-eluting stent was placed successfully.  Conclusion: The occurrences of acute myocardial infarction in Mrs. T aligns with her risk factors of diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. This case highlights that the control of modifiable risk factors  such as diabetes and sedentary lifestyle  is pivotal in the prevention of serious cardiovascular instances.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information: Mr. K  a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a reported weight of 85kg and height of 170cm  presented to the emergency department with symptoms of chest pain.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented with a chief complaint of a severe crushing pain in his chest  which had spread to his left arm and jaw  began earlier that morning. The pain was associated with extreme fatigue  cold sweat  and a feeling of impending doom.  Past Medical History: Mr. K has a documented history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  controlled with Metformin 500mg twice a day  and hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril 20mg daily. He has also previously been diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia  for which he takes Atorvastatin 40mg daily. The patient has a 40-pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He admitted to regular alcohol intake but denied any illicit drug use. There's no history of allergy on record. Family history revealed that his father passed away from myocardial infarction at age 65.  Physical Examination: Physical examination revealed pallor  diaphoresis  and an anxious-appearing patient. Vital signs obtained were: blood pressure (BP) 155/95 mmHg  heart rate (HR) 110 beats/min  respiratory rate (RR) 22 breaths/min  Oxygen saturation (SaO2) 94% on room air   and temperature (T) 37.1⁰ C (Celsius). Cardiac examination showed tachycardia with regular rhythm  without gallops or murmurs. His lungs were clear to auscultation  and the abdomen was unremarkable. No peripheral edema was noted.  Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram (ECG) performed immediately showed elevation of the ST-segment in the anterior leads (V1-V4)  indicative of an ongoing anterior myocardial infarction. His cardiac enzyme levels were elevated with Troponin I levels at 2.5 ng/mL and CK-MB at 55 IU/L  further confirming the diagnosis.   Therapeutic Intervention: Mr. K was administered aspirin 300mg and sublingual glyceryl trinitrate promptly. Simultaneously  a reperfusion strategy was initiated  and the patient was taken for a primary Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI). The procedure showed a 95% stenosis in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery  which was successfully opened up and stented. The chest pain resolved post-PCI  indicating the success of the procedure.  Follow-up: The patient was initiated on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel  along with continuation of the statin and ACE inhibitor. Following the event  Mr. K was referred to a cardiac rehabilitation program involving exercise training  diet counseling  and educational services. He was advised to maintain regular follow-ups for his current medications and health status.  This case illustrates an acute myocardial infarction in the setting of a classic risk profile. It emphasizes the importance of timely recognition of symptoms  acute intervention  and secondary preventive measures in managing such patients.

Patient Information:  A 64-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the emergency department with a primary complaint of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and shoulder  which had started suddenly around 2 hours ago.  History of Present Illness:  The patient described his chest pain as heavy  like ""an elephant sitting on his chest "" and was rated 8 on a scale of 10  consistent with the symptoms of acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Additionally  the patient reported feelings of breathlessness and episodes of dizziness.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years; both diseases were managed with medication. He is a smoker for approximately 40 years and is used to smoking a pack a day. He has a history of hyperlipidemia. The patient's father passed away at the age of 66 from a heart attack. The patient is now retired but used to work in a job with high physical demands.   Clinical Findings and Diagnosis:  On arrival  the patient had a sinus tachycardia of 117 bpm  blood pressure 160/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit  and oxygen saturation of 92%. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed elevated ST segments in leads II  III  and avF  indicating inferoposterior AMI. Blood tests showed elevated troponin levels. The patient was diagnosed with acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).  Treatment and Intervention:  The patient was immediately treated with aspirin and nitroglycerine upon arrival at the hospital. He was then transferred to the cath lab for emergent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Coronary angiography showed a significant obstruction in the right coronary artery (RCA)  which was successfully dilated and stented. The chest pain resolved after the intervention  and subsequent ECG showed resolution of ST-elevation. The patient's condition stabilized after PCI.  Follow-Up:  The patient was admitted to the coronary care unit for close monitoring for 72 hours post-procedure. During his hospital stay  he was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  a beta-blocker  an ACE inhibitor  and a statin.   Upon discharge  the patient was referred to cardiac rehabilitation and a smoking cessation program. Follow-up was arranged with a cardiologist in 2 weeks.  Discussion:  This case demonstrates the importance of quick diagnosis and prompt intervention in the management of STEMI that can greatly improve the patient's prognosis. In addition  given the patient's history of smoking  hypertension  and diabetes  this case underscores the importance of managing modifiable risk factors to prevent cardiovascular events.

Case Report:  Patient Information: The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who works as a mechanic. The patient is currently divorced and lives alone. The patient has one daughter who happens to be a nurse practitioner.  Presenting Complaint: The patient was reported to have woken up in the middle of the night with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm. He was brought into the emergency department (ED) by his daughter.   Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) and Hypertension that was poorly controlled due to non-adherence to medication. He was a pack-a-day smoker for approximately 40 years and has a history of heavy alcohol consumption. There's no known history of drug allergies. Despite having a family history of prematurity of coronary artery disease  he has not been regular with his health check-ups.  On Examination: The patient appeared pale and was profusely sweaty. His pulse rate was 110 bpm and his blood pressure recorded was 140/90 mmHg. A physical examination showed no significant lung or abdominal findings. Cardiac auscultation revealed normal S1 and S2 sounds with no added sounds. His peripheral pulses were equally palpable bilaterally and no significant peripheral edema was noted.  Investigations and Diagnosis: An urgent 12 lead-ECG was done which showed significant ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF suggestive of inferior wall myocardial infarction. Troponin I levels were significantly raised. A chest radiograph was done and was normal. Fasting Lipid profile showed high LDL (180mg/dl)  low HDL (35mg/dl)  and a slightly increased level of triglycerides (155mg/dl)  suggesting dyslipidemia.   Management and Follow-up: The patient was immediately started on mono antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin)  dual Antiplatelet therapy was deferred due to transfer for primary PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention). He was also started on IV morphine for pain and high flow oxygen was given. STEMI protocol for thrombolysis was contemplated but was deferred considering the window period and immediate transfer for PCI. The patient was finally transferred to a tertiary care center for further management. The patient was timely followed up with his progress and recovery.  Learning Points: This case underlines the importance of proper management of risk factors such as hypertension  type II DM  smoking  and dyslipidemia to prevent coronary artery disease and hence Acute Myocardial Infarctions. This report also emphasizes on timely recognition of symptoms and immediate presentation to the healthcare facility which can lead to life-saving interventions.  Note: Identifying information has been altered to respect patient confidentiality.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a 52-year-old male patient  Case Report:  Patient Information:  The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male  employed as an accountant  currently a resident of New York City  and presented to the hospital with chest pain radiating to the left arm. He is 5'10"" tall  weighs 230 lbs  and is described as moderately engaged in physical activities. The patient is a current smoker with a 20-pack year history.  Medical History:  The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  which was diagnosed five years ago. Utilizing Lisinopril 20 mg daily  he has been managing his condition; however  the patient's compliance with medication is not consistent. Moreover  he had been diagnosed with high cholesterol two years ago but has not been receiving medication. His family history includes his father dying of a heart attack at 57  and his mother has type-2 diabetes. The patient has no known drug allergies.  Present Illness:  The patient reported acute  severe substernal chest pain that started while he was resting. The pain was continuous  pressure-like and radiated to the left arm. It was associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nauseous feelings. He initially neglected it as an episode of heartburn but when pain didn't subside even after 2 hours  he was brought to the hospital by his wife.  Hospital Course:  On physical examination in the ER  he appeared diaphoretic. Vital signs were remarkable for blood pressure of 165/95 mm Hg  a regular pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 22 bpm and he was afebrile. On auscultation  his heart sounds S1 and S2 were regular without any appreciable murmurs.   He was given sublingual nitroglycerin without relief of chest pain. The cardiologist performed an electrocardiogram (ECG)  which revealed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads (V2-V4)  indicative of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.   The patient was immediately started on Aspirin  Clopidogrel  Statin  and intravenous morphine for pain management. He was then rushed to the cath lab for an emergency percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).  On angiography  a 100% occlusion of the proximal segment of the left anterior descending artery was found. A stent was successfully deployed. Later  he was transferred to the coronary care unit (CCU) for further monitoring of his condition.   During his hospital stay  the patient was counseled on smoking cessation  the importance of medication adherence  control of high blood pressure  lipid profile management  and achieving a healthier lifestyle. He was also screened for depression and anxiety  and psychiatric consultation was provided because acute myocardial infarction can often lead to psychological adjustments.  Discharge and Follow-up:  At discharge  the patient was prescribed a dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  a statin at a high-intensity dosage  a beta-blocker  and an ACE inhibitor. He was also referred for cardiac rehabilitation. The importance of medication adherence and lifestyle changes were emphasized.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the common presentation of an acute myocardial infarction in a middle-aged male patient with suboptimal control of his cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension  a family history of premature cardiovascular disease  and a history of smoking. This underlines the importance of managing these risk factors to prevent severe cardiac events like this.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a 64-Year-Old Hypertensive Male   Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian male who resides in Portland  Oregon. He is a retired engineer  married with three children  and an active smoker. He admitted to alcohol consumption of 2-3 units per week and denies any illicit drug use. He has had chronic hypertension for the last 15 years  managed with hydrochlorothiazide and metoprolol. The patient also has a family history of cardiac diseases where his father died of myocardial infarction around the same age.  History of Present Illness:   The patient arrived at the emergency department with acute chest pain for the last 2 hours—described as centrally located  severe  and radiating to his left arm. The pain was associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. There was no history of trauma or similar episodes in the past. The patient was brought to hospital immediately by his wife.   Physical Examination and Investigations:   Upon arrival  the patient appeared in distress; his BMI was 27 kg/m²  blood pressure was 176/98 mmHg  pulse rate was 106 beats/min  respiratory rate was 22 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation on room air was 92%. EKG showed ST-elevation in leads V2 – V5  suggestive of anterior wall myocardial infarction. Blood tests revealed elevated Troponin-I levels at 3.29 ng/mL (normal: 0.00-0.04 ng/mL).  Hospital Course:  The patient was initially managed with aspirin  sublingual nitroglycerin  and intravenous morphine for pain in the ED. He was then referred to cardiology and underwent urgent primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Coronary angiography showed a thrombotic closure in the proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD)  which was subsequently dilated and stented. Post-PCI  he was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel  along with statin  beta-blocker  and an ACE inhibitor for secondary prevention.   The patient's hospital course was complicated by tachyarrhythmia on the 3rd day  which was managed with amiodarone. His condition improved by the 6th day; symptoms of chest pain and breathlessness were significantly reduced.   The patient was discharged on the 10th day with medications including aspirin  clopidogrel  carvedilol  ramipril  and rosuvastatin  and was advised for lifestyle modifications (cessation of smoking  reduced alcohol intake  diet modifications  and regular exercise).  Follow-up and Prognosis:   The patient was scheduled for outpatient follow-up in the cardiology clinic after two weeks. He was also referred for cardiac rehabilitation. The patient was explained of his condition  importance of adherence to medications  and lifestyle modifications for optimal recovery and prevention of future cardiovascular events.   This case underscores the importance of timely intervention in acute myocardial infarction for a favorable prognosis and underlines the need for stringent control of risk factors  particularly smoking and hypertension  in preventing the incidence of coronary heart disease.

Patient Information  Name: Peter Thompson  Age: 65 years  Gender: Male Occupation: Retired  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Date of Admission: January 20  2022  Presenting Complaints  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain of sudden onset that lasted about two hours. He described the pain as ""crushing"" and ""tight""  which radiated to the left arm and was associated with cold sweats  shortness of breath  and feelings of impending doom.  Past Medical History  Mr. Thompson has a known history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  both of which have been managed with medications for the past ten years. He also has a history of tobacco use  smoking one pack per day for about 30 years  although he quit smoking 5 years ago. He does not have any known allergies. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.  Clinical Findings  On initial examination  the patient was diaphoretic and appeared uncomfortable. His vital signs showed a blood pressure of 160/100 mm Hg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed regular rhythm without any murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The remainder of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigations and Diagnosis  An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed immediately which showed ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads  a characteristic finding of an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The patient’s troponin level was significantly elevated. A complete blood count  renal function test  and lipid profile were also carried out. The patient was diagnosed with an acute myocardial infarction. A coronary angiogram was performed revealing a 90% blockage in the left anterior descending coronary artery.  Treatment and Outcome  Mr. Thompson was immediately started on aspirin  clopidogrel  and IV heparin  with emergency percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) performed on the left anterior descending artery  which was successful. He was started on beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  statins  and dual antiplatelet therapy as per the protocol for post-PCI management.  The patient's post-procedure recovery was uneventful. He was relieved of his chest pain and was stable throughout his hospital stay. He was advised to continue his medications and stop smoking completely. The importance of a balanced diet  regular exercise  and follow-up visits were explained.  Mr. Thompson was referred to a cardiac rehabilitation program to receive additional education and support for lifestyle modification. He was discharged from the hospital after six days.   Follow-up  The patient was reviewed in the cardiology outpatient clinic after one month. He reported compliance to medication and lifestyle changes. His checkup was satisfactory with stable vital signs  and he is scheduled for routine follow-up visits. The prognosis is currently promising.

Patient Information: Mr. X  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired industrial worker  non-smoker  presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe chest pain.  Presenting Concerns: Mr. X complained of sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm which started two hours ago while he was gardening at home. He described the pain as ""squeezing"" in nature; he also experienced shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea.   Past Medical History: Mr. X had a previous history of controlled hypertension for 15 years and type II diabetes mellitus for 10 years. He was on regular medication  including Lisinopril 20mg once daily  and Metformin 500mg twice daily. He had no known allergies.   Clinical Findings: On examination  he appeared anxious  diaphoretic  and in apparent distress. His pulse rate was 110 beats/min  blood pressure was measured to be 170/100 mmHg  respiratory rate- 22 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation was 90% on room air. On auscultation  slight crackles were present at the bases of both lungs  but heart sounds were normal with no murmurs. Rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment: ECG was performed and showed ST-segment elevations in the inferior and lateral leads  suggesting an acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Blood tests were conducted which indicated raised cardiac Troponin levels  confirming the diagnosis. His blood glucose was slightly elevated (200 mg/dl) but HbA1c levels were within target range (<7%).  Therapeutic Intervention: Immediate treatment consisted of giving him sublingual nitroglycerin  oxygen via nasal cannula  chewing aspirin 325mg  and intravenous morphine for pain. He was urgently transferred to the catheterization laboratory for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The procedure showed a single-vessel disease  with a 95% stenosis in the mid segment of the right coronary artery which was successfully dilated and stented.  Follow Up: Post-procedure  Mr. X was closely monitored in the Cardiovascular Intensive Care Unit. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors  and statins. His chest pain completely improved and his vitals stabilized. The patient was discharged after five days with scheduled follow-ups at the cardiology clinic.   This case underscores the necessity of prompt diagnosis and intervention in AMI to improve outcomes. Follow-up will focus on managing the patient’s risk factors to prevent future cardiac events.   Informed Consent: Informed consent for patient information to be published in this report was taken in written form from Mr. X.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  reported to the emergency department with acute chest pain  sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath. The patient is married  an occasional smoker  and drinks alcohol sometimes. He has a previous medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both under control with medication. Additionally  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago and has been taking Metformin. He has a family history of coronary artery disease; his father had a myocardial infarction in his late sixties.  Immediate Case Description:   Upon presentation to the emergency department  Mr. Smith's symptoms started at rest and had been ongoing for 30 minutes. The chest pain was severe  squeezing type  radiating to the left arm and jaw. On examination  he appeared anxious and was profusely sweating. The initial blood pressure reading was 160/90 mmHg with a heart rate of 110 bpm.  Clinical and laboratory findings:  The electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads (V1-V4)  indicative of an anterior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). His troponin I levels were also elevated above the normal reference range  providing further evidence towards acute myocardial infarction.   Management:  An immediate single loading dose of 300 mg oral aspirin was given. Additionally  he was administered sublingual glyceryl trinitrate to relieve the chest pain. He was then transferred for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). A coronary angiogram was performed  revealing a complete occlusion of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. A drug-eluting stent was successfully placed in the occluded segment of the LAD.  Post-procedure and prognosis:  The procedure was successful  and Mr. Smith's chest pain resolved gradually over the post-procedure period. He was then started on dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and clopidogrel)  along with statin  ACE inhibitor  and a beta-blocker  according to the protocols for post-myocardial infarction care. After a few days in the cardiac care unit for monitoring  he was discharged in stable condition. Mr. Smith was counseled on lifestyle modifications for secondary prevention  including smoking cessation  moderation of alcohol intake  maintaining a healthy diet  and regular physical activity. He was advised to continue his medications and regular follow-up every month.  This case underscores the importance of immediate recognition and treatment of STEMI  which can remarkably decrease the morbidity and mortality associated with this condition. The clinician must also emphasize on regular follow-up and lifestyle modifications to the patients for secondary prevention of recurrent events.

Patient Information:   Mr. A  a 62-year-old male of Asian descent  presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. A sales manager by profession  he is a chronic smoker with a 40 pack-year history  regular alcohol consumer (around 21 units/week)  and leads a sedentary lifestyle.   Past Medical History:   Mr. A has a reported history of hypertension for the past ten years  for which he takes Amlodipine 5mg daily. He also reported occasional episodes of dyslipidemia. However  he is non-compliant to statin therapy. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago and is managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily. There have been no reports of previous myocardial infarctions or cerebrovascular accidents. No known drug allergies are reported. There is a strong family history of cardiovascular disease; his father passed away from a heart attack at 65.  Presenting Complaints:   The patient described the pain as a heavy sensation in his chest  8/10 on the pain scale  which started 2 hours prior to hospital presentation. The pain was accompanied by episodes of nausea  dizziness  and profuse sweating.   Clinical Findings:   On physical examination  the patient appeared pale and diaphoretic. His BMI was calculated as 29.8. Pulse rate was found to be 110 beats per minute and BP was recorded as 165/100 mmHg. Respiratory rate was 20 per minute with oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed regular S1 and S2 without any murmurs.  Diagnostic Assessment:   An immediate ECG was carried out  revealing new ST-segment elevation in the anterior and lateral leads  suggestive of an acute anterior-lateral wall myocardial infarction. His blood tests showed elevated troponin levels. Lipid profile revealed high LDL cholesterol levels along with low HDL cholesterol levels.  Therapeutic Intervention:   Mr. A was immediately given aspirin 300mg and sublingual GTN  followed by clopidogrel 600mg  to address the platelet aggregation. He was also administered intravenous morphine for pain relief. He underwent primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) which confirmed a significant blockage of his left anterior descending artery (LAD). Successful stenting of the LAD was performed.   Follow-up and Outcomes:   Mr. A was moved to intensive cardiac care unit for post-procedure observation and monitoring. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors and statins as per AHA/ACC guidelines for the management of STEMI. Serial ECGs and cardiac markers were monitored. His condition improved steadily with resolution of chest pain.
