Additionally  the patient is known to indulge in a diet high in saturated fats and has led a fairly sedentary lifestyle post retirement  with minimal physical activity.   There is a notable family history of ischemic heart disease; his father passed away at the age of 70 due to an acute myocardial infarction.  Key Complaints: The patient was brought to the emergency department by his wife when she found him experiencing severe discomfort in the middle of his chest. He described the pain as 'crushing ' radiating to his left arm and jaw  persisting for more than one hour. He also reported experiencing feelings of extreme fatigue  difficulty catching his breath  and a sense of impending doom. The symptoms had started approximately 2 hours prior to his hospital arrival.  Patient was conscious  disoriented  looked pale and was sweating profusely upon admission. He was anxious and indicators of peripheral vasoconstriction were notable. Before arrival  he had self-administered aspirin  however  reported no relief. His wife mentioned a recent episode of 'heartburn' after meals and difficulty sleeping at night  but they did not think much of it. His electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed immediately  indicating abnormalities suggesting myocardial damage. These  along with the patient's symptoms and background  suggested a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction.    Note: The case aims at drawing attention to the typical risk factors associated with Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI)  as well as the importance of early recognition and immediate response. The patient's smoking habits  diet  family history  and lifestyle significantly contribute to the risk of developing AMI. The symptoms presented are classic and should immediately raise a red flag for any practicing physician or medical students.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Richard Davis  a 62 year old Caucasian male and a retired bank manager  comes to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: He complains of sudden severe chest pain that started a couple of hours ago while he was mowing the lawn. The patient describes the pain as a heavy pressure  ""like an elephant sitting on my chest"". He also reports radiating discomfort to his left arm and shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: He has a known medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has been prescribed Metformin  Losartan  and Atorvastatin respectively. Mr. Davis is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  and admits to irregular exercise and a diet high in saturated fats.  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 60. His mother had a stroke at 70 and is living with type 2 diabetes. His older sister has a history of coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  the patient was noted to appear diaphoretic and in distress  and complained of feeling nauseous. His blood pressure was a slightly high at 150/90 mmHg  the pulse was 95 beats/min and irregular  and his respiratory rate was 20 breaths/min.   This case should prompt the students to think about Acute Myocardial Infarction  considering the patient's age  medical history  the nature of the pain and associated symptoms. The patient's lifestyle  family history of cardiac diseases and presence of risk factors - hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia - all contribute to the suspicion of myocardial infarction. Immediate intervention and management should be discussed after diagnosing the condition through necessary investigations.

Case Report - Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics: Patient Name: John Doe (Pseudonym) Age: 54-years old Sex: Male Occupation: Mechanic Residence: Urban Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: The patient is a known hypertensive for the past ten years and is on regular medication (ACE inhibitors). He has smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 20+ years and has a history of episodic alcohol consumption. There is a family history of ischemic heart disease  with his father having died of acute myocardial infarction at the age of 59-years old.  Key Complaints: John Doe presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain that started around 2 hours prior to admission. The pain was located in the center of the chest and was described as 'crushing' in nature  radiating to his left shoulder and down his left arm.   He reported associated symptoms such as profuse sweating  nausea  and a sense of impending doom. The pain did not subside with rest. He also reported shortness of breath and palpitations. John had experienced similar (though less severe) episodes of chest pain over the past week but had attributed it to indigestion.  Notably  there had been no complaints of fever  cough  abdominal pain  or any neurological symptoms. He rated his chest pain as 8/10 in the pain scale.  [For the complete case study  consider including further information on clinical examination  investigations  diagnosis  management  and follow-up in your training material.]

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. R.T.  62-year-old Caucasian male residing in an urban area. He works as an investment banker and leads a sedentary lifestyle. He is a smoker with a 40-pack-year history. He is slightly overweight with a BMI of 27.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes controlled with metformin  a 5-year history of hypertension managed with amlodipine and lisinopril  and high cholesterol levels maintained with atorvastatin.   Key Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe chest pain of about 3 hours duration. The pain started while he was resting  and is described as a heavy  crushing type located in the central thoracic region  radiating to his left shoulder and jaw.   Accompanying symptoms include dyspnea  nausea  and cold sweating. He denies any aggravating or relieving factors. No similar episode in the past.   This case report should set the stage for students to further question about cardiovascular risk factors  detail more about the characteristic of the chest pain  perform proper physical examination focusing on heart and related systems  consider immediate treatment options  and discuss prevention and long term care.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Name: John Doe Date of Birth: February 21  1965 Age: 56 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Construction Worker Country: USA  Past Medical History: The patient has a 20-year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He was diagnosed with Hyperlipidemia 5 years ago. The patient is a current smoker  smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. There is a family history of heart disease with his father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. The patient's medication regimen includes metformin  lisinopril  and rosuvastatin. He has no known drug allergies.   Recent History (Key Complaints): John Doe presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain that started 2 hours prior to admission. The pain is described as heavy and crushing  located in the center of the chest and radiating to the left arm and neck. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a sense of impending doom. He also mentions experiencing nausea and vomiting at home. He reports difficulty in catching his breath when climbing stairs in recent weeks. On arrival  he appears pale and anxious  and is observed to be in significant distress. There is no report of trauma  and no recent history of injury.   Conclusion: The patient's symptoms  coupled with his high-risk medical and family history  suggests an Acute Myocardial Infarction. However  diagnosis needs to be confirmed with an ECG and cardiac enzyme studies  and the extent of myocardial involvement and patient's management plan needs to be determined.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics: - Name: John Smith - Sex: Male - Age: 65 - Occupation: Retired engineer - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Marital Status: Married - Smoking Status: Smoked for 30 years  quit 10 years ago - Alcohol Intake: Moderate (1-2 drinks/day) - Other substance use: None    Past Medical History: - Hypertension: Diagnosed at age 55  managed with a Calcium Channel Blocker (Amlodipine)  - Type II Diabetes: Diagnosed at age 60  controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents (Metformin)  - Family History: Father died of coronary artery disease at age 70 - Last Clinical Visit: Routine Check-up  6 months ago - Health Screenings: Adherence to annual health screening - Exercise: Engages in moderate-intensity workout 3 times a week - No previously documented allergies   Key Complaints: Mr. Smith visited the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain that started about an hour ago while he was gardening. He describes the pain as ""severe pressure"" on his chest and rates it as 8/10 in severity. The pain radiated down to his left arm and up to his neck and jaw. He also complained of profuse sweating  mild shortness of breath  and nausea. He denied syncope  dizziness  or complaints of any similar episodes in the past.   Note: As you guide students through this case  emphasis should be placed on identifying risk factors (long-term smoker  hypertension  type II diabetic  male over 45)  recognizing typical and atypical symptoms of acute myocardial infarction  and engaging the correct emergent course of action. Discussion regarding pathophysiology and various diagnostic imaging and laboratory tests for MI would also be warranted.

Case Report:   Overview:  Mr. Smith  a 59-year-old African American man has been admitted to the emergency department (ED) due to sudden severe chest pain with radiating discomfort to his left arm.  Patient Demographics:  - Age: 59 years  - Gender: Male  - Ethnicity: African American  - Occupation: Electrician  - Smoking History: 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 27 years  - Alcohol: Occasionally  - Physical Activity: Sedentary - BMI: 29.8 (Overweight)  Past Medical History:  - Aware of hypertension for 5 years  on medication (Metoprolol and Lisinopril)  - High cholesterol level for 7 years  on medication (Simvastatin) - Non-Insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus (NIDDM) for 2 years  on medication (Metformin) - Family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Key Complaints/Presenting Symptoms:  - Severe  heavy chest pain (central and radiating to the left arm) ongoing for approximately an hour  - Feeling of pressure or discomfort in other areas of the upper body  including the arms  left shoulder  back  neck  jaw  or stomach  - Shortness of breath with or without chest-discomfort  - Light-headedness - Breaking out in a cold sweat  - Nausea and vomiting   These symptoms started while he was lifting heavy electrical equipment at work. He initially dismissed these symptoms as just related to his work  but the symptoms persisted even after rest  prompting him to seek immediate medical attention.

Patient Case Scenario:  Jessica Taylor  a 62-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the Emergency Department (ED) at 8:00 PM with sudden onset chest pain. She's been a clerical worker for 30 years and recently retired. She lives alone  but her daughter resides close by and checks on her regularly.   Past Medical History:   Mrs. Taylor has a history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and Type II Diabetes. She's been managing these conditions with medication: hydrochlorothiazide 25mg  simvastatin 20mg  and metformin 500mg twice daily respectively. She had quit smoking 10 years prior  prior to which she had a 20-pack year history. There is a family history of heart disease; her father dying of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65.   Key Complaints:  The patient describes the chest pain as crushing in nature  situated in the center of her chest and radiating towards her left arm. She rates the pain as an 8 on a scale of 1-10. The pain started approx 1 hour ago when she was watching television  not exerting herself. Additionally  she mentions she’s been feeling lightheaded and experienced an episode of nausea and vomiting at home. She was brought in by her concerned neighbor who found her clutching her chest in distress.   The patient denies any similar episodes in the past and symptoms like cough  shortness of breath  leg swelling or recent travels. Her vital signs on arrival were blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate 90 bpm  respiratory rate 20 bpm  temperature 98.6 F and oxygen saturation 96% on room air.  The goal of this training case is to guide medical students through a clinical scenario of acute myocardial infarction that encompasses presentation  diagnosis  management  and potential complications. Students should focus on interpreting the presented signs and symptoms  taking into consideration the past medical history and risk factors  and formulating a diagnosis and treatment plan.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Jamison Age: 59 years old  Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Accountant  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 6 years ago  managed with hydrochlorothiazide and diet/lifestyle modification. 2. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 5 years ago  managed with atorvastatin. 3. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 3 years ago  managed with metformin. 4. History of smoking: 1 pack per day for 20 years  quit 10 years ago. 5. Family history positive for heart disease: Father had myocardial infarction at age 62.  Key Complaints: Mr. Jamison presented to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset  severe chest pain occurring at rest  three hours prior to arrival at the hospital. The chest pain was retrosternal  pressured in character  radiating to the left jaw and arm  associated with shortness of breath  and profuse sweating. He rated it as 9 on a pain scale from 1 to 10. There was no notable relieving factor  whereas exertion seemed to worsen his pain. He also reported feeling nauseated but there was no episode of vomiting.   The history also included episodes of angina (retrosternal chest discomfort) for the past few months  specifically on climbing up stairs or heavy lifting but the pain would typically subside upon rest. He did not seek medical attention for these episodes.   He denied any recent changes in diet  physical activity  illicit drug use or related symptoms such as headache  palpitation  dizziness  loss of consciousness  cough  fever  or lower limb swelling. His last routine check up was 4 months ago and his diabetes and hypertension were well-managed at that time.   This case study will serve as a basis for medical students to understand the presentation  evaluation  differential diagnoses and management of patients with acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Information: Patient Alias: Mr. Smith Age: 67 years old Sex: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Job occupation: Retired automotive technician  Case History:  Mr. Smith  a 67-year-old retired automotive technician  presented at the emergency department (ED) complaining of sudden onset severe central chest pain radiating towards the left arm. The pain started abruptly about 2 hours ago while he was gardening. He describes the pain as a heavy  squeezing sensation associated with dizziness  mild shortness of breath  and profuse sweating. He denies any nausea  abdominal pain  or palpitations but admits to feeling a slight sense of impending doom.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been hypertensive for the past ten years and has had type-2 Diabetes Mellitus uncontrolled with metformin for the past 7 years. He has a 15-year history of smoking a packet of cigarette every day but quit 3 years ago. His father had a history of a heart attack in his sixties. He has been non-compliant with his medication and lifestyle modification.  Family History:  Both parents deceased. Father had a history of ischemic heart disease  he died of myocardial infarction in his 70s; Mother died of a stroke  also in her 70s. He has two younger brothers  ages 63 and 65 both of whom are alive and well.   Social History:  Retired automotive technician  long history of smoking  only recently quit smoking 3 years ago  occasional alcohol use  no illicit drug use. Lives alone but has a social circle of friends who check on him.   During the process of taking his history  you notice Mr. Smith becomes increasingly ashen and short of breath. You immediately arranged for an ECG and cardiac biomarker studies  prepared to manage an acute myocardial infarction.  Summary:  This case is about Mr. Smith  a senior patient with multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease  including advanced age  a history of hypertension  smoking  uncontrolled diabetes  and relative non-compliance with prescribed medication  who presents with symptoms highly suggestive of acute myocardial infarction.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Information: - Name: Mr. Smith - Age: 58 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: Driver - Race: Caucasian  Chief Complaints: Mr. Smith presents to the emergency department with a primary complaint of severe chest pain. He describes the pain as a heavy pressure sensation  ""almost like an elephant sitting on my chest"". The pain started about an hour prior to presentation and has progressively worsened. He also reports light-headedness  shortness of breath  a sudden and severe bout of sweating  and a sense of impending doom.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has been a smoker for approximately 30 years and consumes alcohol socially. He is known to have hypertension and diabetes  however  both conditions are poorly controlled due to lack of medication adherence. He has a strong family history of heart disease  with his father having passed away from a heart attack at the age of 60. Mr. Smith leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle and is overweight. He has no prior history of significant cardiac events.  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Smith appears pale and anxious. His blood pressure is 160/90mmHg  pulse is regular but rapid at 110 bpm  and respiratory rate is elevated at 22 breaths per minute. On auscultation  no murmur or rales were noted in the lungs. His abdomen is soft and non-tender and his lower extremities show mild bilateral pedal edema. Initial ECG shows significant ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction.  Conclusion: Based on the patient's symptoms  clinical findings  and ECG result  an acute myocardial infarction (AMI) is the primary diagnosis. This case emphasizes the identification of key risk factors for AMI  such as smoking  hypertension  diabetes  family history of heart disease  and obesity. This case illustrates the importance of understanding and promptly acting upon the classic signs of AMI to facilitate early diagnosis and timely management.   Clinical pearls: - Chest pain described as a pressure sensation is characteristic of AMI. - ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) is considered a medical emergency. - Patients with poorly controlled risk factors like hypertension and diabetes have a higher risk of developing AMI. - Mental stress or a sense of impending doom is often reported by patients suffering from AMI. - Early diagnosis and prompt initiation of therapy are crucial in managing patients with AMI.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired lawyer  non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption. Lives with his wife in the suburbs and has two adult children.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin  hypertension controlled with lisinopril  and hypercholesterolemia managed with atorvastatin. There is a family history of cardio-vascular disease (CVD); his father had a myocardial infarction aged 70.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe was brought into the Emergency Department (ED) around 1:30 PM. He complained of severe  crushing chest pain that started at rest earlier in the afternoon. He described the pain as ""heavy weight on the chest”  irradiating to his left arm and up to his jaw. He also complained about shortness of breath  sweaty skin and acute nausea. The pain did not recede with rest. The symptoms were not relieved by nitroglycerin given by the ambulance team. As per his wife  Mr. Doe looked pale and was feeling lightheaded before the ambulance arrived.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics:  Mr. James Smith is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  a managerial executive by profession who resides in urban Cincinnati  Ohio. He is a former smoker  having quit 5 years prior  but admits to occasional alcohol intake. He lives with his wife and two children. He leads a stressful life due to his demanding job and admits he does not get much time for physical exercise.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which were diagnosed 8 years ago. Compliance with medication has been intermittent over the years. He has no known drug allergies. Mr. Smith does not have any surgical history. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65.  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith was rushed to the emergency room with a complaint of severe  crushing type chest pain for the last 2 hours  which was radiating to his left arm. The pain was not relieved by rest and gradually became more intense. He reported associated shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom.  He denies any complaints of recent weight loss  persistent cough  hemoptysis  or any bowel/bladder abnormalities. He complains of frequent episodes of belching and heartburn for the last few weeks  which he attributed to stress and gastritis. He had consulted his general physician for the same and was on antacids and proton pump inhibitors.  In this case  the chief complaints are consistent with the clinical picture of acute myocardial infarction. Further management would include immediate stabilization  symptom control  and confirmation of the diagnosis by ECG and cardiac markers. Patient education regarding the importance of lifestyle modification and medication adherence will also be crucial. Proper treatment and management can play a significant role in the prognosis of Mr. Smith's condition.

Patient Information:  - Name: John Doe - Age: 62 - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired firefighter  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe visited the emergency department with severe chest pain  radiating towards the left arm and neck. The pain  which started 3 hours ago  is described as a heavy  squeezing sensation. Accompanying symptoms include profuse sweating  extreme fatigue  and shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:   - Hypertension (treated with Losartan 50mg daily) - Hyperlipidemia (treated with Atorvastatin 20mg daily) - Smoker - 20 cigarettes per day for 40 years - Doesn't exercise regularly or maintain a balanced diet  with a preference for processed and fast food - Family history includes a father who died from a stroke at age 65 and mother who had heart disease.  Physical Examination:  - BP: 150/95 mm Hg - Pulse: 110 bpm - Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths per minute - Oxygen Saturation: 94% on room air - Temperature: 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit   No abnormal findings were noted on physical examination of the chest and lung fields. He appeared anxious and diaphoretic. His pulses were present and equal bilaterally  and there were no signs of peripheral edema.   This case demands further evaluation for acute myocardial infarction given the combination of risk factors (age  sex  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking history)  clinical presentation  and family history. Immediate electrocardiogram (ECG)  cardiac enzyme tests  and other necessary diagnostic procedures should be undertaken to confirm the diagnosis and manage the condition promptly.

Patient Demographics:  Gender: Male Age: 65 years old Race: African American Occupation: Retired  Previously employed as a bank clerk Home: Lives with wife in a suburban neighborhood.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension - diagnosed 10 years ago and under control with medication. 2. Hyperlipidemia - diagnosed 5 years ago and under control with statins. 3. Type 2 diabetes mellitus - diagnosed 6 years ago  managed with insulin and diet. 4. History of tobacco use -15 pack years (quit smoking 8 years ago). 5. No known drug allergies. 6. Family history: Father died due to myocardial infarction at age 62.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Johnson arrived at the emergency department complaining of acute  severe chest pain he characterized as ""crushing"" in nature  radiating to the jaw and left shoulder. He also reported shortness of breath  dizziness  and profuse cold sweats. These symptoms had begun approximately 2 hours prior to arrival while he was gardening at home. He tried resting  thinking it was heartburn  but his symptoms did not improve.   His wife drove him to the hospital as he began to feel more breathless and the pain did not subside. He denied any nausea  vomiting  lower extremity edema or recent illnesses. He had never experienced such symptoms before.  Upon arrival  the patient appeared anxious and was in visible discomfort. His vital signs upon arrival were blood pressure 160/90 mmHg  pulse 100 beats per minute  respirations 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air.  This case opens a scenario to teach medical students about acute myocardial infarction  its pathophysiology  clinical presentation  differential diagnoses  diagnostic tests  and timely management.

Patient Description:   Mr. Edward  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a known past history of ischaemic heart disease (IHD)  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension  presents himself at the Emergency Department (ED).   He complains of experiencing severe  crushing  left-sided chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  which started around 2 hours ago while he was mowing the lawn. He also mentions feeling nauseous  profusely sweating  and experiencing dizziness along with the chest pain.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Edward has been treated for IHD for the past eight years. He underwent a coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) procedure five years ago. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension approximately 10 years back  for which he is on metformin and a combination of ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers  respectively. Additionally  he has a 40-pack year smoking history  though he quit smoking following his CABG.  Present Complaints:  1. Severe  crushing chest pain - predominantly left-sided 2. Pain radiating to his left arm and jaw 3. Nausea 4. Profuse sweating 5. Dizziness  Initial impression based on the given history  risk factor profile and symptoms strongly suggest an acute myocardial infarction (AMI). An immediate ECG  troponin levels  full blood count  coagulation profile and bedside echocardiography will be required to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment. This is a case that requires urgent medical attention and immediate management to limit myocardial damage.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department. He is a retired oil rig worker and lives with his wife. His closest child lives an hour away. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes a day and admits to drinking alcohol moderately.  Medical History: Mr. Smith has a documented history of hypertension  diagnosed 8 years ago  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 15 years ago. Both conditions are managed with medication (Lisinopril for hypertension; Metformin for diabetes). His grandfather died of a heart attack at 70  and his father had coronary artery disease. Patient is overweight with a BMI of 29. He states that he is more sedentary than active.  Primary Complaint: Mr. Smith came to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset intense chest pain persisting for the last 2 hours. The pain is localized in the center of the chest  radiating to his left arm and jaw. He describes the pain like ""an elephant standing on his chest"" with shortness of breath. The onset of pain started when he was resting after dinner and has not subsided despite trying to rest and taking his hypertension medication. Along with the chest pain  he mentions he is feeling unusually fatigued and dizzy and has also broken out into a cold sweat.  Given the patient's gender  age  history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  family history of heart diseases  and the nature of pain  he is at high risk for cardiovascular disease. The combination of symptoms  especially the characteristic chest pain radiating to arm and jaw  is strongly suggestive of an Acute Myocardial Infarction. Further diagnostic tests like ECG and cardiac enzyme tests should be performed immediately to confirm the diagnosis and territory of myocardial infarction  after which an appropriate treatment plan can be formulated.

Case Report:  Patient Presentation:  Mr. J. Collins is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm  shortness of breath  and excessive sweating. He describes the pain as a pressing  heavy sensation  and rates it as a 9 on a scale from 1-10. The pain has persisted for the last 4 hours. The patient has no known allergies.   Patient Demographics:  Mr. Collins is a retired civil engineer who lives with his wife. He has a 40 pack-year history of cigarette smoking and quit 5 years ago. He reports having an occasional alcoholic drink and denies recreational drug use.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Collins has a known medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  relatively well managed with current medication. His father died at the age of 60 due to a heart attack. There is no documented diagnosis of diabetes but the patient's recent lab results reveal elevated fasting glucose levels  warranting evaluation for possible diabetes in the future.   Key Complaints:  1. Severe chest pain - described as crushing  located in the center of the chest  and radiates to the left arm. 2. Shortness of breath. 3. Excessive Sweating.   Other findings:  On physical examination  Mr. Collins appears anxious. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rhythm with an S4 gallop. Breath sounds are diminished at the lung bases with rales and other signs of pulmonary congestion. Blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg and pulse 90 beats per minute  regular.  The intention of the case study:  This case is intended to help medical students identify  assess  and manage acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The associated pain  dyspnea  and diaphoresis are typical features of this diagnosis. The presence of Mr. Collins' risk factors (age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  past smoking  positive family history) increases the likelihood of AMI. His physical examination findings are supportive of the diagnosis and require prompt management and potential interventions.

Patient Case Report:  Patient Profile: - Name: John Doe - Age: 64 - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired construction worker - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Marital status: Married  Past Medical History: - Diagnosis of hypertension and hyperlipidemia - 15 year history of type 2 diabetes and is non-insulin-dependent - Ex-smoker  quit 12 years ago  prior smoked one pack a day for 25 years  - 10-year history of obesity. Body Mass Index (BMI) - 32 kg/m2  Key Complaints: - Severe chest pain  describing it as crushing  occurring at rest. Pain radiates down the left arm and up into his jaw. - Onset of the pain was sudden one hour prior to his arrival at emergency department. - The pain is associated with sweating  shortness of breath  and a feeling of impending doom. - Pain is not relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin which he took one tablet at home.  The patient is stabilized with initial treatment  but further diagnostic evaluation is needed to confirm a suspected acute myocardial infarction. This case can be used to discuss the pathophysiology of acute myocardial infarction  its risk factors  clinical presentation  diagnostic approach  treatment  and complications.

Case Report  Patient Information: MR. S.  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired lawyer from suburban area.   Past Medical History:  Mr. S has a history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus and is being treated regularly for both conditions for the last ten years. He is a non-smoker but admits to a moderate level of alcohol consumption. His father passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 72. He has no known drug allergies.  Key complaints:  Mr. S presented to the emergency department complaining of acute onset  severe  crushing chest pain of 2 hours duration which radiated to his left shoulder and arm. Accompanying symptoms included shortness of breath  cold sweats and a feeling of impending doom. He mentioned experiencing intermittent chest discomfort over the past two weeks  but considered it a symptom of gastric reflux and took over the counter antacids  which didn't provide any relief.  On reaching the emergency department  clinical examination detected a significantly pale and anxious patient  with a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  pulse rate 95 bpm  and respiratory rate 22 breaths per min. There were no noteworthy findings in the physical exam apart from some crackles at lung bases indicating possible early pulmonary edema. In light of the patient's symptoms and risk factors  acute myocardial infarction became the chief differential diagnosis and was further investigated.  Educational Goals and Objectives:  The key educational components of this case are: 1) Recognizing the signs and symptoms of acute myocardial infarction. 2) Understanding the import role of patient's risk profile and medical history in reaching a diagnosis. 3) Learning about the appropriate testing and interventions for suspected myocardial infarction. 4) Explaining the importance of patient education about the symptoms of myocardial infarction  especially in high-risk individuals with previous cardiovascular disease or risk factors. 5) Understanding the short and long-term treatment approaches and the role of lifestyle modifications in managing patients post-myocardial infarction.

Patient Demographics:  Mr. John Smith is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  an active smoker with a 40 pack-year history  employed as a long-distance truck driver. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 30  indicating obesity. He resides in a rural area with his wife and has minimal physical activity.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago. He takes hypertension medications irregularly due to his job necessities. His blood sugar levels are generally poorly managed as he does not follow a proper diet nor exercise  and struggles with accessibility to regular health check-ups due to his work schedule and rural residence. He also has a familial history of cardiac disease - his father died from a myocardial infarction in his 60s. Mr. Smith ignores the significant risk of his smoking habit adding to his pre-existing conditions.  Key Complaint: Mr. Smith presents with a 2-hour history of severe  squeezing central chest pain that radiated to his left arm and jaw. The pain started suddenly while he was loading his truck. It persisted even after he rested and took antacids  suspecting it was just heartburn. Accompanying symptoms include sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath. He denied dizziness  fainting or palpitations before pain onset but acknowledges occasional fatigue and exertional dyspnea over the past few months  which he chalked up to aging and lack of physical fitness. His current complaint now triggers stress considering his father's history. He visited the local health practitioner and was referred immediately to the nearby hospital for detailed examinations.

Patient Information:    Mr. Thomas  58-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  working as an accountant.    Past Medical History:   He has been diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension 7 years ago. He has a family history of ischemic heart disease with his father having suffered from a myocardial infarction at the age of 62. He's been on oral hypoglycemics  ACE inhibitors and a moderate dose of statins for 5 years. There's no history of drug allergies. He's non-alcoholic and his BMI is within the overweight range.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thomas arrived at the ER complaining of severe chest pain that started while he was working two hours ago. The pain was centralized in the middle of the chest  radiating to the left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath. He mentioned it felt like “a heavy weight pressing down” on his chest. He reported he felt nauseated and vomited once before arriving at the hospital. He also mentioned that he initially experienced some discomfort in the chest during exertion about a month ago  which he assumed was due to indigestion.  Physical Examination Findings: Mr. Thomas appeared anxious  heavily sweating with a heart rate of 115 bpm and blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. Clinical examination of the chest revealed no specific abnormalities. Auscultation of the lungs revealed no abnormal sounds  and the heart sounds were normal with no audible murmurs.  Summary:  This case revolves around a 58-year-old man  with risk factors including hypertension  diabetes mellitus  family history  and overweight status. He presents with symptoms suggestive of acute myocardial infarction  which is the intended focus of this case. The goal is to educate medical students on identification  urgent investigation  management  and prevention measures related to acute myocardial infarctions using this real-world clinical scenario.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarfection Case Study  Patient Demographics:  Patient M.J.  a 60-year-old male  Caucasian  is an office executive in a prominent company. He lives in an urban setting and leads a stressful  sedentary lifestyle. He’s a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History: Patient M.J. has a medical history emulative of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin. The patient recalls no allergies to any medication. His father had a similar acute myocardial infarction episode at the same age.   Key Complaints: Patient M.J. came to the hospital complaining of severe  crushing chest pain he rated as 8/10  radiating down the left arm and up his jawline. The pain started two hours prior to showing up at the ER while he was still at work dealing with heightened levels of stress. He associated the pain with shortness of breath  abnormal sweating  and mild nausea. He first presumed the pain as a heartburn and took an antacid  but a lack of resolution urged him to the emergency department.   Suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction  this case poses a teaching opportunity on the importance of history-taking  examination  and combined interpretation of signs and symptoms for diagnosis. This case would further focus on the management and potential complications of MI  along with primary and secondary prevention strategies.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information: - Age:	65 Years Old - Sex:	Male - Race:	Caucasian - Occupation:	Recently Retired Engineer   Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the Emergency Department with a 2-hour history of retrosternal chest pain. The pain was severe  squeezing in nature  and radiated to the left arm and neck. It was associated with diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and nausea.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a significant history of Hypertension  Type II Diabetes Mellitus  and Smoking (20 cigarettes/day for the past 40 years). He has had intermittent episodes of angina that were usually relieved by rest. His father passed away at the age of 60 due to a heart attack. There is no record of previous myocardial infarction  congestive cardiac failure  or other known heart diseases in the patient.  Family History: - Father had a heart attack at 60. - Mother has hypertension and is alive.  Medications: He is taking Metformin for his diabetes and a daily aspirin.  Review of Systems: - General: Diaphoresis  anxiety. - Cardiovascular: Chest pain  shortness of breath. - Gastrointestinal: Nausea. - No symptoms related to the rest of the systems.  Physical Examination: - Vital Signs: Blood pressure: 170/95 mmHg  Pulse: 100 bpm  regular  Respiratory rate: 22 rpm  SpO2: 94% in room air  Body Temperature: 37.1C. - General Examination: Appears anxious and mildly pale  profusely sweating. - Cardiovascular Examination: Heart sounds (S1  S2) present  no murmurs  no gallops. - Respiratory Examination: Lungs clear to auscultation. - Abdominal Examination: Soft  non-tender  no organomegaly. - Neurological Examination: Conscious  oriented  no focal neurological deficits.  In this case  the medical students should be taught to recognize symptoms  manage immediate emergencies  and involve specialists quickly. They should also understand the importance of a quick diagnosis using an ECG test and blood tests for cardiac enzymes. They should be made aware of the fact that time is of essence in the management of Acute Myocardial Infarction cases  with the aim being to reestablish blood supply as soon as possible.

CASE REPORT: Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI)  PATIENT DEMOGRAPHICS: Name: Mr. John Doe   Age: 65 years   Gender: Male   Occupation: Retired Accountant   Lifestyle: Sedentary    Ethnicity: Caucasian   Living condition: Lives alone in a suburban area    PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension for which he has been on an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor for the past ten years. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago which is currently managed with metformin. He has been a smoker for the last 40 years  consuming about a half pack per day. He also has a family history of heart diseases – his father had a myocardial infarction at age 70.   KEY COMPLAINTS:   Mr. Doe was brought in by the ambulance after he complained of a sudden onset of severe chest pain characterized as pressing in nature and radiating to his left arm. The pain seemed to worsen with physical activity and relieved a bit on rest. He described it as 'the worst pain he has ever experienced' and it was prolonged  lasting for more than 20 minutes.  Along with the above  Mr. Doe had additional symptoms such as profuse sweating  shortness of breath  feeling faint  intense fear  and a sense of impending doom.    Hence  it is a clinical presentation likely consistent with an Acute Myocardial Infarction.    Please sign off this case file as per your review.  MEDICAL EDUCATOR: ___________________ Date: ____________

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Profile: - Patient's Initials: J.C. - Age: 65 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired accountant  - Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian - Marital status: Married  Past Medical History: - Hypertension managed with lisinopril for the past 10 years. - Hypercholesterolemia managed with atorvastatin for 8 years. - Type 2 diabetes  well controlled with metformin for 5 years. - Past smoker who quit 15 years ago  history of heavy alcohol use but now in moderation. - No previous cardiac events or surgeries.  Presenting Complaints: J.C. came to the Emergency Department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm  which started an hour ago while he was mowing the lawn. He describes it as unlike any pain he had experienced before. He also reported feeling sweaty  nauseated  and light-headed. Despite resting  the pain did not subside.  These symptoms along with the patient's age  gender  and past medical history are suggestive of acute myocardial infarction  necessitating immediate medical attention. Further evaluation to confirm the diagnosis and determine appropriate management strategy would include an electrocardiogram (ECG)  blood tests to assess cardiac enzyme levels  and possibly coronary angiography  depending on the findings and overall clinical picture. This case should spark discussions on early recognition of heart attack symptoms  immediate interventions in the ED  and long-term management post-AMI  including lifestyle changes to avoid any future events.

Case Study: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Details:   - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 58 years - Sex: Male - Occupation: An accountant - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe is a known hypertensive. He has been diagnosed with high blood pressure for the past 10 years which is controlled with medication. Additionally  he has also been dealing with type II diabetes mellitus for the last 6 years. He is a former smoker  having quit about 2 years ago  but has a 25-year pack history.  His family history is significant as his father had a heart attack at the age of 62. He exhibits a sedentary lifestyle and maintains a diet high in trans fats and sodium.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with a heavy  squeezing chest pain radiating to his left arm and the back of his neck. The pain has been progressive  intensifying over the course of the last 3-4 hours prior to admission. He rates it a 9 on a scale of 1-10. In addition to chest pain  he also complains of nausea  profuse sweating  and shortness of breath. He mentioned experiencing a similar but significantly less severe pain a few weeks prior while climbing stairs  which he attributed to his sedentary lifestyle and general unfitness.  Brief:  This case study aims to guide medical students in handling a patient suffering from an acute myocardial infarction (AMI). It revolves around Mr. Doe  a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a significant history of chronic diseases like hypertension and diabetes. His unhealthy lifestyle and family history further increase his risk. His symptoms include a progressively severe  gnawing chest pain radiating to his left arm and neck  along with nausea  heavy sweating  and shortness of breath. These symptoms strongly suggest an episode of AMI and highlight the importance of prompt diagnosis and proper treatment in the management of this potentially fatal condition.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics: Name: Robert Johnson Age: 57 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Truck driver  Ethnicity: African American Residence: Urban Marital Status: Married Smoking Status: Former smoker (quit 5 years ago)  Past Medical History: - Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 7 years ago  on oral hypoglycemic agents.  - Hypertension for 10 years  currently under medication (ACE inhibitors  thiazide diuretic). - High cholesterol diagnosed at routine check-up 2 years ago  diet-controlled. - No history of previous cardiac disease. - No significant family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson presented to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain that radiated to his left arm and jaw. He described it as a ""tightening sensation""  10 on a scale of 1-10  with sudden onset while he was loading goods onto his truck at work. He also reported associated feelings of overwhelming anxiety  profuse sweating and shortness of breath. The symptoms persisted for more than 30 minutes despite rest. There was no nausea  vomiting  or palpitations. He denied any history of similar episodes before.   This case scenario will allow students to navigate through the patient’s symptoms  risk factors  and past medical history that strongly suggest an acute myocardial infarction. With the provided clinical information  they should further propose a management plan including immediate measures and investigations to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the patient's condition. They also need to consider possible complications and long-term management to reduce recurrent events.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. John Anderson  a 64-year-old Caucasian male from Chicago  is a retired construction worker who lives with his wife.   Past Medical History: Patient has a history of controlled hypertension and Type II diabetes managed through drugs and lifestyle changes. He is a former smoker  stopped smoking approximately ten years ago after smoking a pack a day for roughly 35 years. He does not consume alcohol. There's no known allergy to any type of medication. His family history includes his father who died of a heart attack at 68 years old and a brother who underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) in his early 60s.   Key Complaints: Mr. Anderson presented to the Emergency Department reporting severe  crushing chest pain that started about an hour prior to his arrival. He characterizes the pain as 8/10  provoked and unrelieved by rest. Lying down exacerbates the pain and the pain radiates to his left arm and jaw. Accompanying symptoms include a sensation of doom  sweating  nausea  and slight shortness of breath. He denies other common symptoms of MI including fatigue  palpitations  syncope or pre-syncope  cough or wheezing  and swelling of legs.  Developing this scenario further should allow students to practise identifying symptoms of an acute myocardial infarction and to consider how factors such as the patient's past medical history and lifestyle may impact diagnosis and treatment plans. Particular attention should be given to understanding ECG changes  roles of cardiac biomarkers  and the timely application of thrombolytic therapy in the management of myocardial infarction.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction   Patient Demographics: Name: John Smith  Sex: Male  Age: 63 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Army Veteran  Marital status: Married Location: Rural Midwest  USA  Past Medical History: - Hypertension diagnosed 12 years ago - Type 2 Diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago - Hyperlipidemia diagnosed 8 years ago - Family history of coronary artery disease: father died of myocardial infarction aged 66 - Ex-smoker (30 pack-year history  quit 5 years ago) - Occasional alcohol consumption  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith presented to the emergency room with a 3-hour history of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and lower jaw. The pain started while he was gardening and persisted despite rest. It is associated with shortness of breath  cold sweats  and a feeling of impending doom. He had multiple episodes of vomiting at home. He denies any chest trauma  fever  cough  or other significant symptoms.   Annotation: This case focuses on a typical presentation of a patient suffering an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack). The subject is a high-risk individual given his age  male gender  history of hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and strong family history of cardiovascular disease. Distinguishing features include severe chest pain that radiates  perspiration  a sense of impending doom  and episodes of vomiting. It is essential for students to recognize these key symptoms and understand the criticality of prompt intervention in such cases.

Patient Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Details: Patient's Name: Robert Smith (name changed for confidentiality) Age: 60 years Sex: Male Occupation: Retired school teacher Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: Robert has a significant past medical history including Hypertension controlled on Lisinopril  Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus managed with Metformin  and High cholesterol managed with Statins. Alongside these  he also has a 10-year history of smoking. He has no known allergies.  Chief Complaints: Robert presented to the emergency department complaining of a severe  unrelenting chest pain  described as a heavy pressure 'like an elephant sitting on his chest.' The pain started about an hour ago while rest at home and has been constant since.   He also mentioned experiencing episodes of lightheadedness  profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and a significant feeling of unease. He denies any recent injuries  fever  cough  or abdominal issues.  Upon further questioning  he revealed some instances of milder  similar chest discomfort in the past month while climbing stairs or during stressful situations which relieved on rest. He didn't seek any medical advice previously thinking it to be a result of his ‘stress and tiredness’.   End of Presentation: This case is designed for medical students to understand the presentation  progression  diagnosis  and management of Acute Myocardial Infarction  with a patient exhibiting classic symptoms along with significant risk factors like age  hypertension  diabetes  high cholesterol  and smoking history. This patient’s case will help students learn about appropriate history taking  physical examination  interpretation of diagnostic tests  and understand the urgency and importance of timely intervention.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Smith Age: 65 years  Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer Ethnic Background: Caucasian  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a 15-year history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  currently managed with Metformin and lifestyle modifications. He also has a history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years prior  but smoked for 20 years total. His father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith came to the emergency department with sudden and severe chest pain that started while he was reading a book at home. He describes the pain as a pressure sensation in the center of his chest  radiating to his left arm. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath  a feeling of impending doom  and profuse sweating but no nausea or vomiting. The pain was not relieved with rest. His last meal was 4 hours prior to symptom onset.  Vital signs upon arrival were: Blood Pressure: 165/95 mmHg Pulse: 115 bpm Respiration Rate: 25 breaths per minute Temperature: 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit (37 degrees Celsius).   The preliminary EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  suggesting an anterior wall ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)  which prompted immediate referral to the Cardiology team.   This case scenario is designed to familiarize medical students with the presentation and initial management of acute myocardial infarction  including interpretation of symptoms  recognition of risk factors  basic understanding of EKG changes  and the importance of immediate referral for definitive care.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a 62-Year-Old Male  Patient Demographics: Name: Patient X Age: 62 years Gender: Male Race: African American Marital Status: Married Occupation: Retired firefighter  Past Medical History: 1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - Diagnosed 12 years ago  on Metformin therapy  well controlled. 2. Hypertension - Diagnosed 8 years ago  on Lisinopril therapy. 3. Hyperlipidemia - Diagnosed 5 years ago  on Atorvastatin therapy. 4.Smoker - Average of 20 cigarettes per day for 40 years. 5. Family history of coronary artery disease (Father and Brother).  Presenting Complaints: Patient X visited the emergency room complaining of chest pain for the last 4 hours. The pain was descried like heavy pressure in the center of the chest  radiating to the left arm and jaw. Associated symptoms included shortness of breath  sweating and sense of impending doom. He also mentioned the pain was not relieved by rest or by taking his usual antacids.  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and sweaty. Vital signs were as follows: blood pressure 165/95 mm Hg  heart rate 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 93% on room air.  Investigations to be done: EKG  cardiac biomarkers (troponin)  complete blood count  lipid profile  kidney function tests  chest X-ray  echocardiography.  This case study exposes medical students to a classic presentation of acute myocardial infarction  and allows them to learn about urgent diagnostic procedures and therapeutic measures in patients with suspected AMI. Emphasis should be placed on risk factor management  lifestyle modifications  and understanding the pathophysiological basis of the disease.

Patient Information:  Name: John Doe Age: 69 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired engineer  Residential location: Chicago  Illinois  Past Medical History: 1. Smoker (which he gave up 10 years ago) with a 25-pack year history 2. Longstanding hypertensive  diagnosed 15 years ago  on medication 3. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled with oral hypoglycemic medications  4. Family history of heart diseases (Father suffered from MI at the age of 66)   Key complaints:   Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain of sudden onset that radiated to his left arm and jaw  combined with shortness of breath. The pain began while he was shoveling snow outside his home  gradually intensifying over an hour. His pain was described as 'crushing' in nature and not relieving with rest. He also reported feeling nauseous and broke into a cold sweat.   Note: These symptoms are classic for a myocardial infarction (""heart attack"")  especially the crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  which is often associated with physical activity or stress. Also  patients may describe other symptoms such as feeling lightheaded  faint  or experiencing sudden heavy sweating. These symptoms should be treated as an emergency situation and patients should be advised to go to the nearest emergency department immediately.

Case Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics: Name: John Doe Age: 58 years old Gender: Male Race: African-American Occupation: Bank Clerk Social History: Non-smoker  Teetotaler   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  with irregular medication compliance. He is also a type II diabetics for the past 10 years. There is family history of CAD (father  died of MI in his late 50s and brother  diagnosed with CAD at age 52).  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented to the Emergency department with a complaint of ongoing central chest pain which he describes as a 'heavy' and 'crushing' feeling. The pain  8 on a scale of 10  radiates to his left shoulder and down his left arm. The patient also complains of associated shortness of breath  nausea  and cold sweat. The symptoms began suddenly while he was at his desk working  approximately 2 hours prior to hospital admission.   These complaints should then be followed by a thorough physical examination  lab tests  and imaging studies as deemed necessary. The learning objectives of this case would include recognizing symptoms of acute myocardial infarction  understanding the importance of urgent diagnostic procedures and early intervention  the role of cardiovascular risk factors and patient’s history in diagnosis and management.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is Mr. Scott Davis  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  who works as a high school teacher. He is a smoker with a significant smoking history of 30 pack-years and moderate alcohol drinker. He is married and lives with his wife and two teenage kids. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases – his father died from an acute myocardial infarction (AMI) at the age of 54.  Past Medical History: Scott was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medications for the past seven years. He does not exercise regularly and has a BMI of 32  indicating obesity. He has been on lisinopril and metformin  but is not under any other regular medication.   Key Complaints: Scott presented to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain that started approximately an hour ago while he was gardening at home. He describes the pain as crushing  located in the center of his chest  radiating to his left arm  and associated with shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea. He initially thought it was a bout of indigestion and ignored it. But when the pain persisted and intensified  he started feeling extremely anxious  which prompted him to seek medical help. His wife noted that he had been pale and clammy before they arrived at the hospital. The patient denied any syncope  palpitations  or vertigo. He also denied any cough  fever  or urinary symptoms.   This case features a male patient with a typical clinical presentation of AMI  including the classic symptoms  significant risk factors (smoking  uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of premature CAD)  enabling students to learn about high impact preventative lifestyle and treatment measures.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarriage  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 58 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Corporate Job  Sedentary lifestyle Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Urban  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is known for his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  especially the high levels of low density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and low level of high density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. He has been on Enalapril 10mg twice a day and Atorvastatin 20mg once daily since the last 3 years. He is also a former smoker with a 30-pack year smoking history  but has quit smoking 5 years ago. Mr. Doe reported failing to maintain regular physical activity and has an unhealthy diet rich in processed food and saturated fats. Family history reveals his father experienced a heart attack at the age of 60.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe chest pain for 3 hours  which he described as ""an elephant sitting on the chest."" He also shared symptoms of diaphoresis (excessive sweating)  shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. Mr. Doe's symptoms were not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. His pain was located in the center of his chest and was radiating to his left arm and jaw. On arrival to ED  his vital signs were BP 150/90 mmHg  pulse 92/min  respirations 20/min  and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air.  In this case scenario  the main goal is to train medical students to identify the risk factors and typical presentation of an Acute Myocardial infarction (AMI)  interpret patient’s symptoms  initializing prompt treatment  and discuss lifestyle modifications to prevent future events.
